commentBody:
An awful lot of magical thinking on display re this media
event of media events...It is beyond hilarious the administration's uniform spin on this...the rhetorical emphasis upon winging it, intuiting the sincerity after a few minutes, high confidence, so much blah blah blan...such silliness. And we're supposed to think this is being done by serious people? No wonder this guy went through four bankruptcies...

They've presumably already prepared their conclusion. It's hopefully designed to keep things from blowing up afterwards. But with bolton around who knows....There'll be a vague promise to engage with denuclearization efforts. Perhaps there'll be some opening of economic or cultural exchanges as confidence building gestures for future more substantive negotiating. Surely a promise not to test any more weaponry during this period.

That by itself would be of value, provided it is not accompanied
by promises to withdraw forces from the peninsula unilaterally,
or language easily read to mean regime change. Selling S. Korea down a river to enable withdrawal of U.S. forces prior
to verified denuclearization is probably not on the menu...though it would be interesting to see some symbolic
withdrawal early as part of confidence building...could
people like bolton or pompeo actually agree to that?

If the dynamic within NK leadership really is towards
an opening, and who can really tell from outside?,
then this is a valuable exercise, and not just a media stunt.

The whole idea of trade and denuclearization between two tempetuous leaders who do not carry out promises when they do not feel such agreements are in their best interests seems preposterous. The USA seems to approach this as a matter of whimsy; Kim, too, proferred a deal, took it back, put it out there again. As Eero stated, what does the USA get, other than another picture setting of POTUS and another leader, both now rather infamous for impetuousity, or belligerence, not adult or responsible actors on the world stage.

A small, isolated country with nuclear weapons that has watched what happened to Libya after they gave up theirs, will be looking for some pretty iron-clad assurances before giving up their only chess piece. Since it's Trump offering those assurances --with his track record on truth and trustworthiness --I expect they'll be hanging on to that chess piece with the whitest of knuckles.
Their playing him for legitimacy on the world stage. That's why no former president would take the bait. I mean, really, does anyone in the world think North Korea would actually be safe if they acted like they do, but without nuclear weapons?
Trump's flying in on gut, no plan necessary. He'll know Kim's motives in a minute, just like George W. knew Putin was a good guy, with a good soul, simply by looking into his eyes. It's all so simple...What, me worry?

Call it "the Trump advantage"--advantage over his predecessors, that is. Trump can afford to offer very generous terms to Kim because Trump is negotiating from a different posture than, say, Obama or even GW Bush.

Previous presidents were concerned about much more than N. Korea's nuclear weapons capability; their caution and restraint--and their resulting demands on the N. Korean government--were also based on deep disapproval of N. Korea's dictatorship and suppression of personal freedoms. Impasse was inevitable.

Donald Trump doesn't care about any of that and is likely comfortable with N. Korea's politics and leadership continuing as before. Indeed he seems to admire autocracy as practiced by leaders like Kim and Putin and Hungary's Orban.

People tend to forget that Trump doesn't come from the same ideological mold as his predecessors and is concerned only with gaining at least the appearance of a diplomatic victory for himself. That gives him far more room to maneuver towards his much more limited goals vis a vis N. Korea than any president before him.

In all my years of witnessing our Presidents representing this country I am worried and fear Trump will not only continue to embarrass us but make some very terrible mistakes we will all have to live with for a long time.

I bet all the tea in China that, no matter what happens at the Singapore Summit, Mr. Trump will be emerging from the meeting triumphantly claiming total victory and unmatched success.

I see no reason for him requesting to have a "private" meeting with Kim Jong-Un, except for him to persuade Kim to go along with his declarations of success, even though there will be no concrete agreement of any sort or no actual achievement.

Let's think for a moment: why is Mr. Trump is the only one who is highly confident of the meeting's success? There is only one rational explanation for that. When you are offering to the other side something extremely valuable at no or very little cost, there is no reason for the other side to refuse.

So, Mr. Trump's goal of his "private" meeting is simple: convince Mr. Kim that it is good for both sides to go out and tell the rest of the world that they have reached an important historical agreement ("historical" will become the new mantra). And what is that historical agreement? They will declare an end to the Korean war - which, in practical terms, means very little - and agreement to negotiate denuclearization of Korean Peninsula (whatever that means!) and work out all the issues between the two countries.

And then, in preparation for the up-coming election, Mr. Trump will be putting his propaganda machine (which includes FOX News and friends) into high gears to sell "his historical achievement" to the US public and the rest of the world.

Recalling the Cuban Missile Crisis, with this being perhaps the closest the world has come to revisiting the harrowing possibilities that were ultimately averted through diplomatic measures, one can only hope the eventual outcome will be similar - the realization that a nuclear holocaust was a very real possibility and needed to be avoided for the good of mankind. Sadly on this the 50th anniversary of the death of Robert Kennedy, he or his brother won't be present - voices of reason, sanity and intelligence.  Even more concerning is the man who now sits in the White House, along with most of those seated at the table (the exception being Kelly and Pompeo), possibly hold the future of the Country in their hands, and they do little to  inspire respect or confidence at this pivotal period in our history

Well, I truly hope something can be done to rein in Kim's ambitions to be a nuclear power. And for once this administration seems to be "getting" the concept of diplomacy and negotiations. It would seem to be expedient since two major powers - China and now Russia - are perhaps urging for their own self interests the less experienced and more mercurial Kim to "beware" of all things American particularly all things Trump.

But I seem to be returning to the same solution as abhorrent as it is to this DC group. That is that the only way it will "work out very nicely" is to follow the same original format as the Iran Nuclear Deal, albeit now on life support because of Trump's ignorant and downright stupid actions. This present enterprise needs to be multinational, with nuclear scientists on the team, and with the understanding that it can not be done overnight. And there is the fear. That is that if Trump can not have his childish and immediate self-gratification it will all come to naught with him further alienating Kim.

The North Koreans are playing the U.S. against China to preserve the Kim regime and for economic advantage. For this to be successful they will likely try to prolong the negotiations exacting benefits, in turn, from the two bidders.  Trump calls the shots, as we saw in Malbaie, Quebec. There he demonstrated on the international scene what we have come go expect from him domestically viz. ill-informed, irrational behaviour.  What is new is that a cadre of hawks and sycophants like Bolton, Navarro and Kudlow is encouraging him.  My bet is that he will not have the patience or insight to achieve anything close to a breakthrough, even with visions of Stockholm and a peace prize in his head.  But it's a no lose situation for Kim who will get his money and improved trade from the China.

As I wrote earlier, regardless the personality and, out-in-left-field, tactics of President Trump, this historic summit has the opportunity to end a 65 year long conflict, which in the last decade, has threatened world peace.

I predict that these two leaders will surprise, and shock, the doubting Thomases, and end this summit with an agreement which will see, among other things, a real peace treaty signed, sanctions ended, verifiable denuclearization begin, open border between North and South Korea, all manner of aid starts flowing to North Korea, exchange of diplomats with embassies opened in the parties respective nations, and thereafter by year end, a similar deal with Iran will be well along, which, in my opinion, began a few days after Trump announced his decision to no longer honor the previous fatally flawed agreement.

If anything, Iran is desperate to become regarded as a modern reasonable world trading partner, and watching North Korea achieve the nearly impossible will be the catalyst that ends the alienation of Iran.

Why so optimistic ?

Simple really; the opportunity for the United States to literally be present in all of a unified Korea, is priceless, in terms of countering China's regional influence, and the worldwide economic benefits from the massive trade which will occur is dramatic, and for Kim, he will be the Gorbachev of Asia, in every sense.

So ease up, help in the form of positive perception management, in this instance, is a good thing.

He can work it out nicely with a brutal dictator, but Canada is a national security threat and Trudeau is a back-stabber, is that right?

Were through the looking-glass, people.

A potentially important event. The meaning of it is still to be seen. Apparently, the U.S. has agreed to suspension of exercises, which isn't as much of a giveaway as it seems. Asking for de-nuclearization while engaging in wargames at their border is a tough sell. Holding back on that this long was a good move. If N.K. shows ill will, it will be easier to resume military exercises. Sanctions remain. The test now is whether N.K. is serious. Trump has removed objections without compromising the main things. Now we must wait to see if Kim is not playing games.

As much as legitimacy for the N. Korean gov't this action also brings them out of the shadows. Again, we will see if the N. Koreans are serious. If they aren't it will be on them, not us, not Trump.

This could even work against China. Who knows? I'm willing to see what happens and not bash Trump in knee-jerk fashion.

You can't make this up. Key quotes - the remarks about the condo prospects. Always an angle, Donnie J. Seriously?

When you think about it, that's his orientation to everything. Not surprising, really. He should just go live there and never come back.

It's 'his peeps' he is developing, lately - a real band of bro's - Donnie and the World Crime Mob with Zhynah, Pootin, and lil' Kim... 'World Toasted', their upcoming No. 1 hit...

I suspect this will diminish America’s clout in the region, and it’s the second time in less than a week we sold out our allies.

North Korea will likely pull out at the last minute, benefitting from easing sanctions while preserving nuclear capability (it wouldn’t be the first time North Korea reneged).

Japan and South Korea will likely no longer depend on us for protection, and to hedge their bets, they may directly reach out to North Korea and China to make their own agreements.

Trump should have prepared.
“Stick with me, Kim baby, and you’ll be driving Cadillacs.”

If Trump wasn’t afflicted with those nasty bone spurs of his, he could have gone to Vietnam and made a 5-Star hotel out of the Hanoi Hilton and changed the course of history.  It can’t get any easier than that.  Just like the kids game of Monopoly - not much thinking, roll the dice, hope you land on the right spot, buy more hotels till you get tired of winning.

Sure, North Korea will give up its nuclear weapons.

I've got a bridge that I'd like to sell to President Trump.

Trump would have done better not to mention Otto Warmbier, who was detained, tortured and died at the hands of the North Koreans.  This bogus agreement is bad enough without reminding us of the cruelty and ruthlessness of the dictator he was playing pals with.
It was a mighty fine show, The Kardashians could have not done much better. Well, maybe they could.
This made for Fox News summit is as phony as everything else about Trump.
" The Presidential Apprentice: Dictator Summer ".  A VERY special episode.

Trump made a “promise” - Big deal!

Two dictators met. Both liars. What’s new?
Sure sounds like an appeasement concession to Kim.
Trump is a fascist.  I'm sure the CIA and FBI have had secret meeting in case this does not end well.  And it won't.....for anyone.
Did the video included a pitch for Trump Hotel in Pyongyang, or a Trump resort in the mountains?

I have a bad feeling about this episode of OUR DAILY REALITY SHOW.

Maybe because the the 2 who signed this meaningless agreement are lying dirt bags with hidden agenda's, one is a brutal but clever Dictator and the other is a grifter conman who would sell his mother for a nickel.

Extra, Extra, Trump sells out South Korea!! Read all about it.

Another Republican Victory!

Oh wait- this is a Trump deal. It may or may not be real. Only Kelly Conway knows.

Trump has accomplished 4 significant things:
1. Demonstrate to the world that there is a payoff for developing the capability of hitting the United States with nuclear weapons, never mind if there is any possibility of actually using them without committing suicide. The "crisis" thus created in the U.S. will lead to a shower of free goodies. Iran is no doubt taking notes.
2. He has exchanged for a vague promise by NK to give up nuclear weapons which are militarily worthless because they are not usable for offensive strikes (as every nuclear power already knows) for giving NK for free a specific promise by the U.S. to eliminate its most important real military deterrent against it, namely maintaining battle-ready troops on the Korean peninsula. The deterrent value of 30,000 U.S. troops in SK is much if they are not allowed to maintain combat readiness by performing joint exercises with SK troops.
3. He has brought Kim one important step closer to his overarching goal of dominating the Korean peninsula through conventional military means.
4. He has pleased China, which has long wanted American forces removed from the Korean peninsula, or the next best thing, rendered unprepared for combat.
The U.S. is unilaterally dropping South Korea’s largest assurance of peace on the peninsula. Without warning. Do you want a nuclear armed South Korea? Because, Mr. Trump, this is how you get one.

One con man meets another.
Classic.

Trump: unprepared in 2016, unprepared in 2018.

What did 18 months of presidency teach Trump? Nothing. Bad teachers? No, bad student.
If I was in Tokyo or Taipei, I would be seriously nervous.

Based on trumps actions toward our enemies vs our allies, it seems pretty clear that Russia, China, and NK coordinated this dog and pony show for maximum effect. Alienating friends and dropping military readiness in S Korea is something all three of our new best friends would welcome.

So, what's Trump's NEXT move with the military going to be? Training to invade Canada?

It's shocking that a president would just fling away such a vital aspect of our defense posture as military training exercises with our ally. What kind of foreign policy is this? Breaking up with long term democratic allies and going all kissy-kissy with despotic and murderous adversaries?

Don't cry for me, America! For I've elected Trump as my Loathsome Leader.

Trump totally ignored the issue of "human rights" in NK, which is and always has been an American value. Kim Jung Un assassinated his half brother and uncle. He has been recommended in a report by a UN commission in 2014 for crimes against humanity and was recommended for accountability for these crimes by the International Criminal Court. But Trump said he purposely didn’t bring it up.

But Trump closed Cuba to Americans due to "human rights" issues after Obama had opened it up in order to allow US business opportunities to compete with Russian influence. So now Russia is investing in Cuba and has a geopolitical advantage.

The point is......"human rights" is really not important to Trump.
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/31/world/americas/cuba-trump.html

The only reason this meeting took place is because putin wanted it to.

DJT works for putin not the American people, so it’s easy to understand his disdain for the G7 but he meets with one communist dictator (Un)
and proposes that another (putin) should be readmitted to the G7.

His actions are treasonous and his very words are not close to believeable! DJT has no interest in the well being of this nation and its people

I will support any and all candidates that seek his removal from office.

Nothing more, nothing less than a publicity stunt.  That's all Trump knows and does.  Anything that comes of it, good and bad, will be an accident.  Trump will risk anyone's capital to agrandize himself.  For the Trump, it's virtually risk free.  For the rest of us...?
Mission Accomplished!

I'm no fan of Trump, but I'm willing to withhold judgement to see what the end result is. Trump did the job of breaking the ice, but it's time for him to step aside and let the more competent people work out the real details.

Does Trump even realize that the statement coming out of his summit is a warmed over hodgepodge of past sentiments?

I give Trump his due for trying something new here - going leader to leader early on being the only truly different element. Then I bristle when he and his supporters try to cast the event as 100 times more than it really is. Why does everything Trump does have to be called "the greatest", "the first", "the best", etc., even if trivial or even untrue? If he had gotten anything more than he did, I would be highly suspicious of it. It just isn't possible to have gotten more so quickly.

When North Korea actually denuclearizes and this is verified by inspections -- then Mr. Trump will be vindicated.

Until then, frankly this looks like a farce.

Just ask yourself the following question: If you had a weapon that could save your life, and someone like Donald Trump asked you to hand it over saying he wouldn't harm you and even make a "deal" to help you, would you?  This why this whole talk, and no action, about disarming and dismantling North Korea's nuclear program is a pipe dream. Once a member of the nuclear club; always a member [Remember: Libya and Iran were never real members and you know how that worked out]. And, when you're dealing with a volatile and untrustworthy man who just arrived from tweet-trashing his closest neighbor and ally in the back just after stiffing the other major world powers who'd signed the Iran Nuclear Accord, you'd be insane to do so.  So, as his father and grandfather before him, Kim Jong-un will never denuclearize for Donald Trump or probably for anyone else either.

As with all policies, the devil is in the details, execution, and unanticipated consequences, not the tweets, pronouncements, or contemporaneous punditry.

Perhaps the "success" of this meeting is based not on the fact of Trump's alleged deal-making ability but, rather, that Kim is not the person portrayed for many years to the American people by our government and media. Perhaps what he appears to be now is precisely who he has been all along. It is extremely unlikely that an essentially absolute ruler who is the incompetent, egomaniacal buffoon portrayed over the years by our government and media would have been able to successfully organize and preside over a nuke and missile program that many countries with greater financial and material resources can only dream about.

Perhaps we are so surprised because we have been kidding ourselves for many years. Perhaps we may be where we are today precisely because our government came to believe its own spin on North Korean reality. Self-delusion rarely works out well.

I do not know how this all started, whether successive administrations chose to believe self-serving analyses from an intelligence community that no President has chosen to hold accountable, or that good intelligence was superseded by political myopia and self-delusion, or something else. In any case, it is imperative that out government and media consider the possibility that, like it or not, Kim may have been a very capable and savvy leader all along.
I do respect Trump’s willingness to meet in person with Kim Jong un but his celebratory tweets are the stuff of fairy tales.

Let us take a simple example.

Say, you want to kiss and make-up with your former enemy. Would you, in your first meeting, want (a) all the concrete details on moving forward or (b) broad abstracts on the future.

President Trump, for once (maybe by mistake), dumped the mindset of cold warriors and took the correct path. This needs to be applauded.

A Great Leader once said, “... the notion that somehow not talking to countries is punishment to them — which has been the guiding diplomatic principle of (the American) administration — is ridiculous.".

This is what Trump is doing. He has set broad abstracts: (a) “denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula”; (b) “lasting and stable peace regime on the Korean Peninsula” and (c) “commit to recovering POW/MIA remains”. [The last one is quite concrete]

Trump, knowingly or unknowingly, is following this great leaders footsteps. Let him go!

I voted for Obama but was no fan of his foreign policy. That said, Trump's foreign policy is FAR worse and FAR more dangerous.
Look at the precedent that has now been set.
All any foreign entity seeking concessions from the US has to do is build a nuclear arsenal and point ICBMs at the US.
Not to mention alienating every ally we have while inviting Russia, RUSSIA, to the table.

Trump has accomplished exactly ZERO, so I don't know what accomplishments you are admiring. The fact that he had lunch with a dictator who "loves his people" so much that he starves them?

Important to clarify that the only reason this summit was historically "unprecedented" was because no president before Trump was willing to meet, thus elevating a despot like Kim to the world stage and turning a blind eye to criminal actions against his own people. Trump sees no harm in that.

If you hold your baby out the second story window, then bring her back inside the house, are you a good parent?

Why praise Trump for creating substantial trouble, then doing the bare minimum to rectify the situation?
I want peace in the Korean peninsula once and for all please people. I am tired of the wars and war mongering in our government.

I support success in this effort (whatever that might eventually mean).  Max Weber famously said "For every opinion there are extremely inconvenient facts, no less for mine than for yours."  Success in this endeavor may well be an inconvenient fact, particularly for those of us not happy with his presidency.  However, I certainly hope that it is achieved, nevertheless.

One commentator, a person who has visited North Korea many times, Stanford’s Siegfried Hecker, predicted that it could take as long as 15 years for a deal of any kind to be made. This process will not be easy and by demanding that the North Koreans denuclearize immediately the chances for failure are very considerable.

It was never off. He just said it was. The other parties never acknowledged that it was off.  Things don't happen just because he says they don't happen. It is beginning to look like China and the Koreas are playing the President...and doing it quite well...

Now you see it, now you don't. Diplomacy in the form of a carnaval barker's game. Place your bets, ladies and gentleman. Keep your eyes on the ball, while the game is played elsewhere.

We are in the era of politics by distraction, and both Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim seem to be expert players at distracting attention from what it is that they are doing--meetings that are scheduled, cancelled, re-scheduled, payoffs to pornstars that he didn't, but did, but didn't know about, agreements about the Dreamers that he committed to, but didn't commit to, and on and on it goes, and we all spin our attention from one form of madness to another, from kneeling at NFL games to Rosanne, to whatever is tomorrow's silliness, while the poor get more poor, programs get gutted, payoffs get pocketed, schools deteriorate, and on it goes. Same, I suspect with the third Kim in his dynasty. I suspect he's happy to have meetings scheduled, cancelled, and re-schduled ad infinitum as he cements whatever it is that he is trying to cement, and at some point he and Donald will sign some paper promising that soon enough promises will get made to do something that will not get done, but the military-industrialists will continue of cash their checks, and rescheduling all gets reported as serious news and we all get too dizzy to attend to what is being done to us.

Hasn't Donald already shown that the U.S. can't be relied on to adhere to treaties and agreements with foreign powers? We agreed to the Paris Accord and then withdrew. We agreed to TPP and then withdrew. We agreed to JCPOA and then withdrew. We agreed to NAFTA and may withdraw. We agreed to meet Kim and then withdrew.

Now, the meeting's back on and nobody knows what constitutes success.

What is our policy? Are we considering removing American forces from South Korea in exchange for denuclearization?

Before Donald shows up for this meeting, I, for one, would like to know what he wants and what he's willing to give up to get it.

Otherwise, it's like Kim Kardashian. A photo shoot.

I hope for all our sakes, this meeting goes well, because the stakes are so high. Both men have volatile personalities, are narcissistic, and are given to acting precipitously, and therein lies the problem.
We are becoming isolated from our western allies, as Trump seeks to build more of an Asian alliance, with authoritarian dictators known for their brutality. This makes me wary and uncomfortable.
I have a lot of questions. If Kim Jong-un vows to give up his nuclear weapons, who will verify this? Will Kim Jong-un allow inspectors to enter North Korea? Will sanctions against North Korea be lifted as a result of this meeting? Or will nothing much change?
I only hope that this summit does not turn out like the G7 meeting, because the consequences could be dire.

With that handshake Trump scores what he perceives to be a massive public relations point with his supporters, who think that the mere fact of this meeting demonstrates (in the words of another commenter) that "this man has gone where no other presidents have, the extra mile, to make life better for the entire world, but America first." [Whatever that signifies, other than blind faith.] Meanwhile Kim scores a massive public relations coup. With that handshake, Trump pulled him out of the abyss of being an international pariah and granted him equal stature with the President of the United States. For anyone who knows anything about the tyrannical, murderous way that Kim treats his enslaved populace, that's a ill-considered gift. Trump and his supporters imagine that this is a first step toward something else. Kim looks down at his hand and sees that he just took the gold ring.

I remember seeing the Berlin Wall fall.
It was gratifying to see Obama win.
I thought I would never see a triple crown winner and ended up seeing two of them.
Now! It is truly remarkable to see this happen.
I hope it will be Israel-PLO and India-Pakistan next!

“It’s gonna be a great discussion and I think tremendous success. I think it’s gonna be really successful and I think we will have a terrific relationship, I have no doubt.”
Well, this is the easy part. The momentous handshake, the expression of goodwill, exchanging pleasantries, relishing the spotlight. Really, what were the chances that either man would turn this down?
But what follows takes a lot more depth. The North Koreans will have to abide by an agreement to contain their longstanding nuclear ambitions. Trump will have to do the homework he's eschewed. The United States will have to determine what North Korean requests we can safely accommodate. And both men will have to remain committed to any agreement, long after the cameras have left.
Given how eruptive and erratic Trump is with longtime allies, and how isolated Kim Jong Un and his nation have been, the latter part seems especially dubious.

While I admire any peace and conciliatory effort if it helps North Korean people - I only regret that Kim, who is a despotic ruler, will now be seen as a normal ruler. However, we do have such despotic rulers as friends now and in the past (Middle East), so may be there is nothing to regret about.
America's closest allies get the cold shoulder and gratuitous insults. A dictator he meets with for the first time is greeted warmly. So it goes.

In a single year Trump walks away from an agreement with one rogue nation, Iran, because, he says, it is weak and unenforceable, and then turns around and signs a weak and unenforceable agreement with another rogue nation, North Korea.  The first agreement was signed onto by seven other Western powers and seemed to be working.  The second was seemingly dreamed up whole cloth in the mind of Donald the First after a night of heavy Foxnews binging.  I can hardly wait to see how this all plays out.  What do you suppose is behind curtain #3?

As President Trump always says : "we'll see... " .

It is up to him to work out an arrangement that will be solid and clearly beneficial to all concerned . Let us give him time to do it . It is way too early to pass any judgement .

I am however sure that anything he does - if he does - will not be as weak as what President Clinton and Secretary Albright did with NK in earlier times , or what President Obama did with the awful Ayatollahs in Iran...

As much as one of the news articles said that burgers weren't served, this was a nothingburger. WHEN are the prisoners being released. Does Trump actually know how many launch sites Kim has? What exactly is building relations with NK...don't we have sanctions (which no one said were going to be lifted) against them? And finally, what a slap in the face to curtail or cease military exercises with South Korea absent their leader at the table. Then there is that little crumb about what great beaches NK has and wouldn't condos be great there? This whole thing is making me sick. Kim, on the other hand, not only got his multiple photo-ops but got to play on the big-boy international leader field, and has been promised a trip to the White House. Sorry, as much as I wanted to be able to give Trump credit for a breakthrough, this is no different than previous agreements with NK....except both leaders got a lot of press and both were treated by the international press as "normal". Neither is normal.

Kim seems to be gaining some degree of credibility for agreeing to maybe perhaps eventually someday possibly think about beginning a legitimate process of denuclearisation. Trump will continue to be viewed as an important statesman by his loyal followers, and will be able to use this "accomplishment" to win votes from wavering Republicans in November.

There will be no legally binding treaty coming out of today's meeting. This is just a photo op, and an opportunity for Trump to propose a hotel and golf course in Pyongyang.

Reminds me of when the Berlin Wall fell, and Reagan (and his supporters) seemed to take all the credit, as if they did it all by themselves in just an instant -- instead of nearly 40 years of incredible, unified, terrifying effort by the Allies, led by the U.S., to freeze out the Communist powers in Eastern Europe.  Same with North Korea today -- Trump swoops in, declares personal victory, while riding on the shoulders of giant, 50-year multilateral efforts by the U.S. and our Asian allies to  bring the North Koreans to the brink of total collapse.  As Trump would say, "sad, very sad."

As many others have already stated, this is a good first step but lacks any kind of details as to how the process will go forward. And, the devil is always in the details. Noticeably absent from this meeting was South Korea who must feel that they and their concerns have been bypassed in exchange for a photo op between Kim and Trump. And, with no apparent consultation with South Korea, Trump has suspended military exercises which he deems "provocative". Already, he is taking North Korea's side. What a surprise.

And while heaping praise on Kim, a dictator who eliminated hundreds if not thousands in his own country, Trump has again attacked our long standing allies, notably Canada and Mr. Trudeau. I chalk that up to Trump's attraction to strongmen (which he is not) and his own hope to become more authoritarian in the future which is worrisome.

My feeling is, if this beginning progresses to real negotiations, they are going to look eerily similar to the Iran deal which was a long, hard trek with all of the safeguards to ensure compliance by Iran. What irony would that be if it does occur.

Kim Jong Un will be in power for a good 30 or 40 years. He was raised from birth to be a dictator.

He, like Putin, knows how to play Trump, who will be around for just a few more years.

There is a very good reason previous presidents did not put Korean dictators on the world stage.

Ask our (former) friends at the G7 conference.

I have just read the full statement of the agreement reached by the US and the DPRK . In truth, there is less to it than I thought . It is a joint statement of good intentions on both sides, which commits neither side to any real action .

But could anything more be expected ? Probably not, as no real preliminary diplomacy took place . Two meetings between the Secretary of State and Mr. Kim, and a flurry of discussions at lower levels were not enough to develop a realistic framework for diplomats to engage in substantive consultations .

Of particular concern, of course, is the lack of definition of what "complete denuclearization" signifies . It is remarkable that whilst trump talks about the denuclearization of North Korea, the statement calls for the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula .This may just be semantics, but I don't for one minute believe so .

By meeting Mr. Kim without preconditions, trump is doing what no former US President , perhaps with good reasons, agreed to do .

To put North Korea on the world stage on an equal basis with the United States in this manner is a huge gamble . Whether or not trump realizes it, he has now conferred legitimacy to the government of the world's most repressive nation . Whether that will have a positive impact on North Korea's policies is unclear . I am not optimistic, but I want to be hopeful .

To those in these pages who dismiss the whole effort out of hand, though, I urge you to take your partisan blinders off .

History is not on Mr. Trump's side. North Korea has promised us several times to de-nuclearize, obtained concessions snd then welched on the promise.  Previous administrations, Democrat and Republican, have been outfoxed and disappointed by the Kim regime.  The President has made a substantial concession in suspending joint military exercises with our Asian allies.  Mr. Kim has, at this point, conceded nothing.  The score at this early juncture is North Korea; 1, USA; 0.

It isn’t “courage.” It’s a betrayal of American values to legitimize a murderous dictator on the world stage the way Trump just did. Any past president could have done the same thing and chose not to, for obvious reasons. The only thing more disturbing than this sellout (for which we got nothing verifiable) is how easily Trump followers are fooled by it.

This is Trump's response to W Bush's catastrophic Iraq invasion, HRC's bumbling of Libya and Obama's Iran deal which helped fund terrorism and reward a country hell bent on Israel's destruction. This is how diplomacy can be done without spending trillions of dollars and thousands of lives only to make things much worse. This is what Trump promised during the campaign.  This is the exact reason I voted for him despite all the character assassination 24/7 coming from the media. And I'm sure glad I did.

I don't have a problem with a U.S. president talking to a dictator or a Saudi king or an ayatollah. I do have a problem with him glorifying a dictator. displaying his flag alongside the Stars and Stripes that so many Americans died to defend and participating with him in an orchestrated global media event that accords him equal moral standing with the United States of America. President Trump has demeaned and embarrassed the United States by making this meeting with Kim a spectacle.

"Trump Sees Shared Path After Meeting Kim"

Yeah, after meeting him for some minutes.

While our long-time, natural partners and allies that have shared our ethos, ideals and values for a century or more are thoroughly trashed and insulted as he tries to escape to Air Force One.

Knowing all what we know and have observed, trump simply seems to be running with, and implementing Putin's and Xi's agenda. Not the agenda and priorities of the United States, or any of its long-standing allies.

I'll just say that the Munich Agreement was largely praised when it was made. FDR sent Chamberlain a telegram wishing him well in the talks. This newspaper praised Chamberlain for getting Hitler to moderate his demands. Czech president Benes was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. Even Churchill is reported to have said he might have done the same thing had he been PM at the time.

North Korea is not 1930's Germany. Kim lacks the ability to overrun entire continents. But if he can get US troops off the peninsula this easily, we can be assured he is not done making demands.

Yes, maybe.
Imagine the reaction of Republicans to a Pres. known as No Drama Obama. A man without any scandals or indictments after 8 yrs. A Christian, happily married, with two great kids. A man that drove America out of the worst recession on record.
And look at the, to this day defragment of Trump supporters. They elected a known grifter, spousal abuser, cheat, draft dodger, 5 time bankrupt casino operator, who is pals with thugs, crooks, Mafioso's and traitors. A man with 23 (?) indictments and 6 guilty pleas and 3-4(?) doing jail time in his circle.
A NY City elite, born with a silver spoon in his gob, and has never worked with his hands a day in his life.
Oh, and to top it off, he lies over 9 documented times a day to the American Public.
This is the Result of Pres. Obama Derangement. And they/you are proud of it.
So...yes, D's might have issues for years to come. Look to your own side for needed examples.

While I admire any peace and conciliatory effort if it helps North Korean people - I only regret that Kim, who is a despotic ruler, will now be seen as a normal ruler. However, we do have such despotic rulers as friends now and in the past (Middle East), so may be there is nothing to regret about.
America's closest allies get the cold shoulder and gratuitous insults. A dictator he meets with for the first time is greeted warmly. So it goes.

In a single year Trump walks away from an agreement with one rogue nation, Iran, because, he says, it is weak and unenforceable, and then turns around and signs a weak and unenforceable agreement with another rogue nation, North Korea.  The first agreement was signed onto by seven other Western powers and seemed to be working.  The second was seemingly dreamed up whole cloth in the mind of Donald the First after a night of heavy Foxnews binging.  I can hardly wait to see how this all plays out.  What do you suppose is behind curtain #3?

As President Trump always says : "we'll see... " .

It is up to him to work out an arrangement that will be solid and clearly beneficial to all concerned . Let us give him time to do it . It is way too early to pass any judgement .

I am however sure that anything he does - if he does - will not be as weak as what President Clinton and Secretary Albright did with NK in earlier times , or what President Obama did with the awful Ayatollahs in Iran...

As much as one of the news articles said that burgers weren't served, this was a nothingburger. WHEN are the prisoners being released. Does Trump actually know how many launch sites Kim has? What exactly is building relations with NK...don't we have sanctions (which no one said were going to be lifted) against them? And finally, what a slap in the face to curtail or cease military exercises with South Korea absent their leader at the table. Then there is that little crumb about what great beaches NK has and wouldn't condos be great there? This whole thing is making me sick. Kim, on the other hand, not only got his multiple photo-ops but got to play on the big-boy international leader field, and has been promised a trip to the White House. Sorry, as much as I wanted to be able to give Trump credit for a breakthrough, this is no different than previous agreements with NK....except both leaders got a lot of press and both were treated by the international press as "normal". Neither is normal.

Kim seems to be gaining some degree of credibility for agreeing to maybe perhaps eventually someday possibly think about beginning a legitimate process of denuclearisation. Trump will continue to be viewed as an important statesman by his loyal followers, and will be able to use this "accomplishment" to win votes from wavering Republicans in November.

There will be no legally binding treaty coming out of today's meeting. This is just a photo op, and an opportunity for Trump to propose a hotel and golf course in Pyongyang.

Reminds me of when the Berlin Wall fell, and Reagan (and his supporters) seemed to take all the credit, as if they did it all by themselves in just an instant -- instead of nearly 40 years of incredible, unified, terrifying effort by the Allies, led by the U.S., to freeze out the Communist powers in Eastern Europe.  Same with North Korea today -- Trump swoops in, declares personal victory, while riding on the shoulders of giant, 50-year multilateral efforts by the U.S. and our Asian allies to  bring the North Koreans to the brink of total collapse.  As Trump would say, "sad, very sad."

As many others have already stated, this is a good first step but lacks any kind of details as to how the process will go forward. And, the devil is always in the details. Noticeably absent from this meeting was South Korea who must feel that they and their concerns have been bypassed in exchange for a photo op between Kim and Trump. And, with no apparent consultation with South Korea, Trump has suspended military exercises which he deems "provocative". Already, he is taking North Korea's side. What a surprise.

And while heaping praise on Kim, a dictator who eliminated hundreds if not thousands in his own country, Trump has again attacked our long standing allies, notably Canada and Mr. Trudeau. I chalk that up to Trump's attraction to strongmen (which he is not) and his own hope to become more authoritarian in the future which is worrisome.

My feeling is, if this beginning progresses to real negotiations, they are going to look eerily similar to the Iran deal which was a long, hard trek with all of the safeguards to ensure compliance by Iran. What irony would that be if it does occur.

Kim Jong Un will be in power for a good 30 or 40 years. He was raised from birth to be a dictator.

He, like Putin, knows how to play Trump, who will be around for just a few more years.

There is a very good reason previous presidents did not put Korean dictators on the world stage.

Ask our (former) friends at the G7 conference.

I have just read the full statement of the agreement reached by the US and the DPRK . In truth, there is less to it than I thought . It is a joint statement of good intentions on both sides, which commits neither side to any real action .

But could anything more be expected ? Probably not, as no real preliminary diplomacy took place . Two meetings between the Secretary of State and Mr. Kim, and a flurry of discussions at lower levels were not enough to develop a realistic framework for diplomats to engage in substantive consultations .

Of particular concern, of course, is the lack of definition of what "complete denuclearization" signifies . It is remarkable that whilst trump talks about the denuclearization of North Korea, the statement calls for the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula .This may just be semantics, but I don't for one minute believe so .

By meeting Mr. Kim without preconditions, trump is doing what no former US President , perhaps with good reasons, agreed to do .

To put North Korea on the world stage on an equal basis with the United States in this manner is a huge gamble . Whether or not trump realizes it, he has now conferred legitimacy to the government of the world's most repressive nation . Whether that will have a positive impact on North Korea's policies is unclear . I am not optimistic, but I want to be hopeful .

To those in these pages who dismiss the whole effort out of hand, though, I urge you to take your partisan blinders off .

History is not on Mr. Trump's side. North Korea has promised us several times to de-nuclearize, obtained concessions snd then welched on the promise.  Previous administrations, Democrat and Republican, have been outfoxed and disappointed by the Kim regime.  The President has made a substantial concession in suspending joint military exercises with our Asian allies.  Mr. Kim has, at this point, conceded nothing.  The score at this early juncture is North Korea; 1, USA; 0.

It isn’t “courage.” It’s a betrayal of American values to legitimize a murderous dictator on the world stage the way Trump just did. Any past president could have done the same thing and chose not to, for obvious reasons. The only thing more disturbing than this sellout (for which we got nothing verifiable) is how easily Trump followers are fooled by it.

This is Trump's response to W Bush's catastrophic Iraq invasion, HRC's bumbling of Libya and Obama's Iran deal which helped fund terrorism and reward a country hell bent on Israel's destruction. This is how diplomacy can be done without spending trillions of dollars and thousands of lives only to make things much worse. This is what Trump promised during the campaign.  This is the exact reason I voted for him despite all the character assassination 24/7 coming from the media. And I'm sure glad I did.

I don't have a problem with a U.S. president talking to a dictator or a Saudi king or an ayatollah. I do have a problem with him glorifying a dictator. displaying his flag alongside the Stars and Stripes that so many Americans died to defend and participating with him in an orchestrated global media event that accords him equal moral standing with the United States of America. President Trump has demeaned and embarrassed the United States by making this meeting with Kim a spectacle.

"Trump Sees Shared Path After Meeting Kim"

Yeah, after meeting him for some minutes.

While our long-time, natural partners and allies that have shared our ethos, ideals and values for a century or more are thoroughly trashed and insulted as he tries to escape to Air Force One.

Knowing all what we know and have observed, trump simply seems to be running with, and implementing Putin's and Xi's agenda. Not the agenda and priorities of the United States, or any of its long-standing allies.

I'll just say that the Munich Agreement was largely praised when it was made. FDR sent Chamberlain a telegram wishing him well in the talks. This newspaper praised Chamberlain for getting Hitler to moderate his demands. Czech president Benes was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. Even Churchill is reported to have said he might have done the same thing had he been PM at the time.

North Korea is not 1930's Germany. Kim lacks the ability to overrun entire continents. But if he can get US troops off the peninsula this easily, we can be assured he is not done making demands.

Yes, maybe.
Imagine the reaction of Republicans to a Pres. known as No Drama Obama. A man without any scandals or indictments after 8 yrs. A Christian, happily married, with two great kids. A man that drove America out of the worst recession on record.
And look at the, to this day defragment of Trump supporters. They elected a known grifter, spousal abuser, cheat, draft dodger, 5 time bankrupt casino operator, who is pals with thugs, crooks, Mafioso's and traitors. A man with 23 (?) indictments and 6 guilty pleas and 3-4(?) doing jail time in his circle.
A NY City elite, born with a silver spoon in his gob, and has never worked with his hands a day in his life.
Oh, and to top it off, he lies over 9 documented times a day to the American Public.
This is the Result of Pres. Obama Derangement. And they/you are proud of it.
So...yes, D's might have issues for years to come. Look to your own side for needed examples.

Trump made no deal with Kim-Jong-un. He made a concession on the cessation of "war games" with S. Korea, which incidentally, has been on Putin's agenda for a number of years. The US got nothing from Kim in return. Trump was too lazy to do any research on our long history with North Korea; had he done so, he'd have known how many times NK has agreed to denuclearize. This was a glorified photo-op.

The only lasting result of the meeting is that the world has been given a green light to engage with North Korea and Mr. Kim. North Korea and Mr. Kim have been normalized; they are no longer pariahs on the international stage. Now there will be pressure on the US to ease up on sanctions.

This is a very significant and lasting win for Mr. Kim. And it cost him nothing, not even the air fare to and fro and lodging while in Singapore. That my friends is the Art of the Deal North Korea style. I'm impressed.

If the summit were compared to a football game, I would say the singing of the national anthems went off without a major hitch. That is far too little to declare, as the president did, that North Korea is "no longer" "our biggest and most dangerous problem." It is also far too little to declare the president's initiative a failure.

All we really know is that the team's have taken the field, and the game itself is about to begin. Like the beleaguered citizens of North Korea -- and the good people of South Korea, Japan, China, and the U.S. -- most of us have no better option than to sit in the stands and hope the game goes well.

But above all, we mustn't be lulled into thinking the game has been won, or even started.

I to am glad that Trump and Kim aren't hurling nuclear threats at each other like angry children. It's better to have a happy pageant than an embarrassing brawl.

However, I won't be at all surprised when they start up the theater again to keep those ratings up. Wrestle-mania!! Reality Show, Here We Go!
Let's be honest, there is no way Kim is going to give up those nukes. He's not stupid.

All I could think of was the wasted years of my father's life, as a Korean War veteran, when he was on security of the Alaskan border in extreme conditions. Many people have made sacrifices to rein in the violence inflicted by North Koreans. There are also terrible sacrifices made by South Koreans, especially those who cannot see their loved ones in the North. Yet, Trump, who never made any sacrifices or gave military service in his life, thinks it's a chance to back-slap and get really good ratings for himself (maybe a Peace Prize) toward 2020. I also thought of Otto Warmbier, when I saw all of the flags, and how he was treated for pinching a small poster. Trump has elevated Kim the despot and given him everything for nothing because Trump doesn't recognise all of these sacrifices.  John Kelly, who does, had a face on him at the table which said it all.

The realpolitik of the situation is that Kim has no reason to give up his nuclear capability and it would be against his personal interests to do so. North Korea is not Iran. It makes sense for Iran to trade its military advantages conferred by nuclear weaponry for entry into the world community; Iran wishes to be engaged with the rest of us. Kim (who is North Korea as we know it) has no interest in opening up his country to an inflow of goods and ideas that would make a lie of North Korea's socio-political structure and lead to his own and his dynasty's destruction as it inevitably would. Trump is playing for headlines and his puerile need for attention, but Kim is playing for his life and he dearly loves the life he leads now. To put it in terms Trump might grasp one might say that Kim really has no interest in selling, he's just trying to raise his property's perceived market value in the eyes of his bankers, the Chinese. Let the games begin.

One major concern of mine is Trump's overconfidence in his ability as a negotiator. It is one thing to strike a real estate deal; it is very much something different when dealing with a dictator of one of the most repressive nations on earth.

I am relieved that we are not on the brink of war.  I am happy that talks will continue.  But, I am dumbfounded that the President seems to think that he has made a huge international deal.  He described, in the past, that the deal that Obama and Kerry, and our allies, made with Iran as "the worst deal in history."  If you compare the deal made with Iran and the non-deal Trump just made with Kim, and if you are honest, this one would go down as a fiasco.  There was no tit for tat, no give and take, only concessions by Trump.  That's "The Art of the Deal?"  Phooey, and you can quote me!

The major point here, unspoken by all the pundits, and not mentioned here, is that the world has changed. From reading media like this, you might conclude that Donald Trump is the only one who understands that.

Virtually all the western post-war structures that exist today were built in a different era and for a different purpose. The US military engagement in Korea and the G-7, both in the news currently, and all other western post-war economic and military agreements and alliance, are weapons in a the cold war that we won. They were designed to strengthen and defend the west against an existential communist menace that has now disappeared.

It's high time to re-evaluate the utility of an international framework that is now obsolete because, like all those US Navy warships that were scrapped in 1946, it has already served its purpose. That Trump is doing so, in his crude and graceless manner, is a service to the nation and, ultimately, probably for the whole world. It's far better to have a crass loudmouth change course than to have the smooth and mellifluent Barack Obama, or his successor, continue to plunge us down a path that leads to ambush after ambush, for no purpose.

The old western international order achieved it's purpose. The west won, and it is time to understand and appreciate that victory, and to put down the swords.

The Koreans have a long memory and won't ever trust the U.S., especially in the North, due to its total destruction by American troops.

That American troops are still occupying Korea, after 70 years, seems a bit like overkill. If the two Koreas want to unite, it's a positive step forward. Also, ending the constant air drills -- the shows of force -- would release Koreans from a decades-long reminder of war.

I get why Kim Jong Un wants the U.S. to step down their nuclear force -- it's a fair thing to ask, given the U.S.'s lopsided, "You denuclearize, we'll trade with you" offer. Kim's nuclear force may be small compared to the U.S.'s, but he has "friends", China especially.

The U.S. military should withdraw, if both Koreas want it, and should formally end the war. I like the idea of reunification centers, as well as Kim's willingness to disarm.

Now, Kim could have Moon "disappeared" and take over the South. He's kind of like Trump, and does lie, but he's more intelligent and aware of geopolitics than Trump even wants to be.

I think his goals in this case are sincere, vis-a-vis the peninsula, but of course will have a nuclear weapons plant, until the U.S. agrees to capitulate to some of his demands. Trump, Bolton, et al, are intransigent bullies, and no country likes to be bullied.

May have to wait for Trump and Co. to be voted out before real diplomatic and denuclearization progress can be made.
Hopeful to see the two Koreas speaking to each other in the absence of Trump. Their path to reconciliation clearly does not lead to a path through Trump’s ‘swamp’.

I really like the Koreans commenting here rejoicing and hoping for a new tomorrow. Some of you gave us more detail about the document than what NYT did.

I salute you Koreans. I already read your rejoicing in your newspapers. I also read your dreams of a trans-Korean railroad connecting the world.

However, there is some cold water that needs to be thrown.

First, from the US side, the denuclearization process might make it impossible for the Koreans to get their dream. It might turn out to be an impossible ritual.

Secondly both USA & North Korea have entrenched Cold Warriors who are looking for ways to torpedo the process. They are supported by a substantial population who equate peace overtures with Chamberlain.

Lastly, South Korea has a ‘Franco’ past. The South Korean ‘Franconists’ still exists and they want to maintain status quo. They are against any unification talks.

Wish you Koreans the best. You need it!

Why do they want to repeat the same thing?
Kim Dae-jung visited North Korea to smile with Kim Jong-il two decades ago.
Kim Dae-jung recieved the Nobel Prize for this visit.
But, the secret money of about 4 hundred million dollars sent to NK was used to develop nuclear weapons.

From Kim: “Thank you, President Trump, for creating the opportunity for this meeting. Without the extreme sanctions you got China and others to agree to, we'd still be launching test missiles toward Japan and threatening the West. Without your agreeing to meet me in Singapore, we'd still have no personal connections between me and President Moon. And, my bet is that you will use the leverage you have created in trade with China to offer terms to help them so long as they are keep me focused on de-nuclearization."

I believe Chairman Kim is taking positive steps in the right direction. I understand the human rights violations that has happened/ are happening in North Korea. But let us be optimist. Let a chance be offered. If not for him, be it for the people of North Korea, who have suffered untold brutality.

Though I am shocked at the way a peaceful nuclear treaty with Iran is being torn apart by the Trump administration, I believe, they are doing a good job whilst dealing with North Korea. If Chairman Kim is able to convince the world that the nuclear sites are indeed destroyed, all sanctions should be revoked. I am saying this for the sake of poor North Koreans who remain isolated from the outside world.

LiIkewise, if peace treaty is signed in near future, ending the Korean war, which I hope happens, then the trio, viz., Trump, Kim and Moon deserve noble peace prize.

Speaking at a joint annoucement Mr. Kim said he would visit Seoul in the near future if there are no special circumstances, indicating his trip to Seoul is not definite yet.

Mr. Moon, on his speaking turn, said as an explanation to the trip that the near future means "within this year."

In my view, those special circumstances include the absence of a second Trump-Kim summit and a declaration of an end to the Korean War-- which remains ceased with a truce treaty involving the U.S. and China and two Koreas.

And most of other items on inter-Korean cooperation from the joint communique requires a breakthrough between the U.S. and North Korea for realization.

The U.S. still holds the key to easing sanctions on the North, which China and Russia make the case for relexation in an endeavor to keep their clout on the Peninsula.

That's why attention is now shifting to Mr. Moon's upcoming meeting with Trump and Trump's response amid high-level skepticism by his security advisors.

Is it possible for Trump and Kim to take everyone else by surprise as the U.S. President said before?

It appears that Trump longs for a diplomatic victory that would assure him of a deal maker title in a bid to buoy his stagnant approval ratings when the mid-term election is approaching as the anonymous Op-ed and the controversial book Fear hit Trump hard.

Let's see what will happen.

However out of place Trump might find himself in the China scripted geopolitical power play in the Korean peninsula, the two Koreas agreeing to negotiate border peace and normalcy in bilateral relations appears worth a trial diplomatic initiative by Moon Jae-in and Kim Jong-un, pregnant with immense possibilities and peace dividend for the people in the region.

Even if Mr Moon and Mr Kim honour their promise to denuclearize the region,will the U.S. accept Mr Kim's condition to denuclearize and the answer is no because China in that case will become a nuclear superpower as it will not agree to denuclearize and even if it does one cant trust its leaders.

US got nothing from this meeting.
We will see how Trump handles this deal.

You know what?

Good for them. Good going.

Who knows, it might just work.

Give this a chance.

Very unlikely to have happened without the strategy that Trump used to help bring them together.  Can you all stop hating Trump so much?  It is getting very old and very unseemly.  Just think, a denuclearized Korean peninsula!!

Sounds like the two Korean states are doing it "By Our National Itself" but wait until the national security warmongers and their obediant media poor cold water on it.
SK seems to be loosening the leash the US has had on it since 1945, a prospect that frightens those who fear peace and need that $700+ war budget.

It is unfortunate that this article explains only partial agreements on the joint announcement. One of the most impressive progress is article 3 of the joint statement. "The south and north have decided to step up humanitarian cooperation to fundamentally resolve the issue of separated families"

The south and north have been separated for more than 65 years. The two countries have agreed to open a reunion facility at Kumgang. Now separated families can finally meet each other at will. The Korean War had torn families apart and there are not many family members alive that could meet face to face.

Article 2 states economic cooperation and exchange. It talks about connecting railroads and roads. But with the current sanctions this would not be possible.

The western media focuses on nuclear dissarm. Which is very important but there is also humanitarian process going on. As a Korean, the closest I have gotten to the north is when I served at the DMZ for 2 and a half years. But now the two countries are talking about humanitarian and economic transactions. Peace progress is continuing and the leaders are meeting with new agendas every meeting.

The north is changing and as a Korean this a change that as come to us for the first time in 65 years. It would be a shame to lose this opportunity.

Kim Dae Jung paid $500,000,000 to visit Kim Jong Il in North Korea.  Am I the only one who thinks that Kim Jong Un is going to pocket a huge sum before he visits South Korea, and that he has already charged Moon for visiting him in the north?

“Tuesday’s crowds were clearly mobilized to demonstrate the North Koreans’ adoration for Mr. Kim and their support for his uriminzokkiri, or “among our nation,” policy of stressing inter-Korean cooperation while the North engages in a nuclear standoff with the Americans.”

Choe is such a coward yet vain.

North Koreans’ adoration for Kim.

Moon is a fool. He's the Korean Chamberlain. This charm offensive is all a ruse. Kim isn't going to give up anything. You have a better chance of convincing Pakistan to give up its nukes.

I supported the Singapore summit and giving diplomacy a chance but it is becoming rapidly apparent that the Singapore deal is beginning to unravel, not that it ever had any real teeth to begin with. Trump is trying to push the Chinese into actually doing something with his tariffs but they are standing pat. It demonstrates where Beijing's true intentions lie.

This is all an elaborate ruse. Once American troops leave Kim will be free to "unify" Korea by force, if it comes to that. Although with Moon at the helm in the South he might be able to get South Korea to capitulate without firing a single shot.

Xi and Kim are trying to wrest South Korea from the US & Japan. If Kim had peaceful intentions he wouldn't have ICBM and nuclear weapons programs.

It is trite to label the sentiments of the Koreans across the Divide as "ethnic affinity"! Koreans are One People, and one wishes that they too can state that One People Indivisible!  Let the Two Koreas become the natural One Korea-united, secure, and taking her place in the Hall of Nations!

It is unfortunate that this article explains only partial agreements on the joint announcement. One of the most impressive progress is article 3 of the joint statement. "The south and north have decided to step up humanitarian cooperation to fundamentally resolve the issue of separated families"

The south and north have been separated for more than 65 years. The two countries have agreed to open a reunion facility at Kumgang. Now separated families can finally meet each other at will. The Korean War had torn families apart and there are not many family members alive that could meet face to face.

Article 2 states economic cooperation and exchange. It talks about connecting railroads and roads. But with the current sanctions this would not be possible.

The western media focuses on nuclear dissarm. Which is very important but there is also humanitarian process going on. As a Korean, the closest I have gotten to the north is when I served at the DMZ for 2 and a half years. But now the two countries are talking about humanitarian and economic transactions. Peace progress is continuing and the leaders are meeting with new agendas every meeting.

The north is changing and as a Korean this a change that as come to us for the first time in 65 years. It would be a shame to lose this opportunity.

Now that President Donald J. Trump visited North Korea.  Could it be that the South and North Korea leaders are looking for a nuclear deal?  Instead of North Korea striking the United States.  North Korea will focus on being ally even though South Korea already is an ally with North America.

Is Moon of South Korea really a peace-and-freedom loving and democratic politician who has a lofty goal of unifying the North and the South as suggested by some comments here?  Absolutely not. This is what has happened in South Korea since his sudden ascendance to presidency of South Korea last year. He has jailed his two predecessors, Park Geun-Hye and Lee Myung-bak, along with many dozens of senior government officials. The predecessor's governments had a hard line policy toward North Korea because of North Korean provocations as opposed to Moon's current policy of appeasement. They are treated like an enemy of Moon's and North Korean regimes. Also under Moon's government South Korean news media are afraid to voice opposing views, causing people to turn away from major newspapers and TV news. Don't be fooled by Moon's smiling face and nice talk. He has a hidden goal of transforming free, democratic South Korea into a society like the North. He never explains the goal of his PEACE PLAN to South Koreans! Who would want unification under the North Korean system besides Kim Jong Un?
The crowds in the picture are waving the North Korean and Korean Reunification flag while the South Korean flag is nowhere to be seen. What's up with that?

The US does not want Koreans united because they and China will gang up against Japan which is a puppet regime installed by the US after WWII. It is our interests to keep the Korean divided and so we can control and manipulate the division. Korean war was long over, and we should just pack up and go home to rebuild our own country.

As much as we can desire reconciliation on the Korean Peninsula, it's not going to happen any time soon given the current trajectory or the past damage caused by leaders like trump and Kim. Kim won't denuclearize unilaterally - of that we can be certain. We, the U.S., certainly won't - even under trump. So the logical way to lower the risk of nuclear hostilities would have been the Iranian model negotiated by Obama, but with trump reneging on that carefully crafted arms control deal, the current White House occupant destroyed any hope that other nations will trust America's word in the future. The damage trump has caused this Nation is incalculable.

The Koreans have a long memory and won't ever trust the U.S., especially in the North, due to its total destruction by American troops.

That American troops are still occupying Korea, after 70 years, seems a bit like overkill. If the two Koreas want to unite, it's a positive step forward. Also, ending the constant air drills -- the shows of force -- would release Koreans from a decades-long reminder of war.

I get why Kim Jong Un wants the U.S. to step down their nuclear force -- it's a fair thing to ask, given the U.S.'s lopsided, "You denuclearize, we'll trade with you" offer. Kim's nuclear force may be small compared to the U.S.'s, but he has "friends", China especially.

The U.S. military should withdraw, if both Koreas want it, and should formally end the war. I like the idea of reunification centers, as well as Kim's willingness to disarm.

Now, Kim could have Moon "disappeared" and take over the South. He's kind of like Trump, and does lie, but he's more intelligent and aware of geopolitics than Trump even wants to be.

I think his goals in this case are sincere, vis-a-vis the peninsula, but of course will have a nuclear weapons plant, until the U.S. agrees to capitulate to some of his demands. Trump, Bolton, et al, are intransigent bullies, and no country likes to be bullied.

May have to wait for Trump and Co. to be voted out before real diplomatic and denuclearization progress can be made.
Hopeful to see the two Koreas speaking to each other in the absence of Trump. Their path to reconciliation clearly does not lead to a path through Trump’s ‘swamp’.

I really like the Koreans commenting here rejoicing and hoping for a new tomorrow. Some of you gave us more detail about the document than what NYT did.

I salute you Koreans. I already read your rejoicing in your newspapers. I also read your dreams of a trans-Korean railroad connecting the world.

However, there is some cold water that needs to be thrown.

First, from the US side, the denuclearization process might make it impossible for the Koreans to get their dream. It might turn out to be an impossible ritual.

Secondly both USA & North Korea have entrenched Cold Warriors who are looking for ways to torpedo the process. They are supported by a substantial population who equate peace overtures with Chamberlain.

Lastly, South Korea has a ‘Franco’ past. The South Korean ‘Franconists’ still exists and they want to maintain status quo. They are against any unification talks.

Wish you Koreans the best. You need it!

I am thinking about removing North Korea from the list of state sponsors of terrorism, which was also done by the Bush Administration back in 2008.  That might be enough to break the ice and get both sides to bigger concessions.

A reunification of North and South Koreas with a Democratic government is the most desirable outcome, irrespective of denuclearization. Koreans are no less responsible in safe guarding the nuclear weapons than China, Pakistan, India, Russia, USA and western nations.

"...they fell far short of what American officials have demanded".

There's yer problem...

Its been decades since America could demand anything.

We have a military blind to its record of astonishing incompetence, inefficiency, and over-reach.

They also missed the part where they threaten some "mother of all cataclysms" (because we steal terrorist rhetoric to make ourselves sound tough) against historic enemies, who smile, quiver obligingly, and proceed to do what we wish they wouldn't.

Then he goes on threat-sprees of his own. Threats so dire and, uh, threatening they have the Euros spitting wine through their skyward-facing noses as they contemplate the ridiculous idea we might actually do something.

We have Republicans inviting Bibi to invade Congress and mock our President.

We have McConnell madly in love with whatever dictator Trump is in love with.

We invest our pride and prowess in threatening football players who "disrespect the flag, the anthem, the veterans": this from a President who makes a habit of mocking veterans and their suffering, blames their surviving families for being sad.

Pity the world at large. It can't be easy pretending to fear clowns and fools, yet one must. It won't do to risk provoking the Big Man.

Empty, dusty, airport parking lots don't come cheap.

Ask yourself this one question as an American:

"Prior to Trump taking office, did I ever, ever once feel just a little bit scared that North Korea would start a war by attacking the USA, with a nuclear strike or otherwise?"

As with "American Carnage," MS-13, immigrants, refugees and Muslims, an imminent nuclear war with Korea was another irrational fear manufactured by Trump to make you believe he is needed, working, and solving these issues.

And while he distracts us with Tweets and hyperbole, the GOP Congress is happy to let him steal the show so they can do what they want while nobody's looking.
