For far too long the US has been bearing the brunt of the cost of a NATO whose primary purpose is to protect Europe. This is inexcusable.  Europe is rich. Germany is filthy rich. Yet it is American coin and American blood that is being expended while Europeans take their 8 week vacations and charge huge tariffs on American goods. Hopefully with the current administration America will cease to be the patsy, and cut back its contributions to NATO, UN, UNESCO and all the other blood and life sucking organizations that do precious little for US citizens while primarily serving the needs, interests and, often nefarious,agendas of nations that spit in America's face.

What should be clear to all is that Trump is a traitor to these United States of America,  He certainly cannot be trusted with the security of the NATO nations.   The sooner Trump is cast from office the better it will be for the world.

Time to prepare for a world where the U.S. is absent. NATO needs to wake up to this reality.

Until the U.S. wakes up to a catastrophic attack on its soil and realizes that it is better to have NATO by its side.

All the crying and worry about Trump just need to be dismissed and members move on without his input.
It's best for the former allies of the U. S. to just ignore trump and work together for the common good. They should definitely not let him drag the world down with us.

The leaders of Europe need to stand up to Trump and begin the process of disengaging from the US for their security. America, under Trump, is abandoning the alliances that provided joint security.  They would be foolish to either and not push back on the deplorable behavior of a President Trump as the damage he is inflicting.

I think it's hilarious how many Americans(and naive Europeans) are demanding Europe's leaders to reject Trump, to kick him out of NATO, and to start treating him like an adversary. it's almost like they have no idea what the real situation is. if you think for a moment that Europe could survive without the US at its back you clearly have no idea what happened after the previous two times the United States left Europe to itself. I'll do a favor and refresh your memory, within a decade the continent tore itself apart... twice. only for America to come back and pick up the mess

"The Trump administration rolled out a long-awaited overhaul of U.S. arms export policy on Thursday aimed at expanding sales to allies, saying it will bolster the American defense industry and create jobs at home."

What's the yearly value of US military sales to NATO allies: tens upon tens of billions....it's long past time the world stopped buying, especially your "allies" who are now a "national security threat".

https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-trump-arms/trump-launches-effort-to-...

https://www.armscontrol.org/print/9232
Our NATO allies should be worried no matter what comes out of Trump's, mouth, because you can't believe, or TRUST, anything he says.
Sad to say it appears something funny is going on with U.S. president Trump openly bowing before the Russians.  Maybe he wants to pay them back for helping him get elected.

NATO is not the place for politicking. That applies to Merkel and Macron just as much as it applies to Trump.

Leave the squabbles about trade on the sidelines, even Trump isn't stupid enough to think that the United States can take on both Russia and China at the same time on her own, we would need Europe. I'm sure it's something Mattis has probably pointed out to Trump.

It's sickening to watch how Trump destroys - not only America - but also the decades long relationship with its allies.
What's worse is that he relishes his power and loves to keep the world hanging, demonstrating his malice in order to gain media attention and to gratify his narcissism and lust for vengence.
He really is on his way to autocracy, meeting Putin, despite its political appropriateness. But he does what he wants, knowing nobody can do anything about it.

Never mind the 2 percent defense spending, with a budget of over $ 200 billion the combined European military effort is beyond reproach. Unlike the USA, Europe does not aspire to be an omnipresent military force, just a credible deterrence will do. An other issue however is the highly inefficient way the money is spent. A series of mergers could do the trick, but be careful  what you wish for: a new German/French ICBM program is not exactly according to Moskou's wishes.

With an enthusiastic and advance announcement of the Trump-Putin summit, close to the NATO summit, Trump has left little doubt that the NATO meet is going to be no different from the previous G-7 meet, both in terms of Trump's negativity and the outcome.

If any civilization on the planet survives trump, with the capability to observe, write and preserve historical records, he will be remembered as the person who destroyed not only the world's largest democracy, but the planet's halting footsteps of progress toward a world united in peace, with every human life having human rights.
What a legacy to the world.
It's pretty simple to see and understand, Trump is doing Putin's bidding pure and simple.
A new Axis of Evil is rapidly forming across the world. This time we are at its center.

Maybe NATO should just cancel all conferences and conduct its business in the European sphere alone. Just cut the U.S. and Trump out. Probably better than providing him a platform and suffering the consequences of his deranged politics.

The newsworthy part of this article seems to be Secretary Mattis's plan for an intermediate time-range joint defense contingency plan against Russia that goes way beyond the "rapid reaction" force previously established to deal with Russia. This would be a huge win for Eastern European countries and a big expansion of NATO's in terms of security competition with Russia. It would likely require substantial commitments from European countries.
My guess is at a usual technocratic get nothing done long drawn out meeting. most members fear be told to pay their dues as agreed, especially wealthy Germany.

Who would have thought that our institutions and traditions could be dismantled so thoroughly by one toxic person in the span of 18 months? I don't know which is the worse realization: that it is happening with the concurrence of a large swath of our citizenry and elected officials or the knowledge that it shows how weak they were in the first place . This week has sickeningly and clearly demonstrated the return on investment in Trump that the purveyors of dark money like the Kochs and Mercers, and those determined to take down the US, like Russia, have gotten. And I thought things were abysmal a week ago! The mind reels, and the heart aches.
Cancel meeting due to ill health and wait until 2020.  Maybe both sides of the pond will luck out and get a human being into POTUS.
As an American, I too dread this meeting.  It's difficult to watch the guy who is supposed to represent our country be so ignorant and insulting to our allies.  An embarrassment, and a tragedy.

I detest Trump and I wish there was a nicer way to correct our Allies behavior . They have become complacent and need to be dragged kicking and screaming to a new reality. One in which we are not a debtor nation.

Not a single country got up and denied that Iran is the world’s foremost sponsor of terrorism. NOT ONE SINGLE ONE! Both in the current milieu and in the era of Obama and earlier, all recognize what Iran is.
Thus, no foundation exists for resisting Israel’s characterizations of Iran, nor Trump’s assertions about Iran.
Does the world wish to stand idly by as Iran helps Hezbollah hide arms in civilian areas in Lebanon? Does the world think for a moment that Iran would not surround Israel with enough missiles to annihilate every blade of grass and every tree leaf in Israel? Does anyone really believe that Iran would not annihilate all Kurds? Nor are Iran’s efforts in Yemen or Gaza inapparent.
DId a single world leader stand up and support Iran’s hegemony?

I am enjoying Mr. Trump's collision with reality. Being shamed and criticized by most of the sovereign states of the world, except Israel, should force him to reevaluate his attitude and actions. Or at least one might think so, but I worry that liberal voters might once again conclude that Trump is such a bad person and president that we can afford not to vote and leave it to others to remove this man before he can damage our country mortally.

Just imagine how delightful it would be to see a sane, intelligent, and well-adjusted liberal win the presidency in 2020. The key to achieving that paradisaical moment is to win enough seats in the next election, Nov. 6, 2018, to deny Trump and his fans any more legislative "wins."

Palestinians rejected partition plans in1948 (the UN plan), 2001 (the Clinton plan) and 2008 (the Olmert plan) that gave them the West Bank, Gaza and east Jerusalem. Instead they offered airplane hijackings, murder of Olympic athletes, suicide bombings of buses and restaurants, thousands of missiles aimed indiscriminately at cities, knifings and car ramming.

And now Abbas is complaining that the real obstacles are the Hebrew language? Jewish holidays? The US embassy?

Oh for peace sake!

Historically there has never been a Palestinian state. Give Gaza to Egypt and the West Bank to Jordan. Palestine is too small to be a stable State. Both Egypt and Jordan are Muslim Arabic countries that share the same language and Arabic culture.

Palestinian terrorists should not be rewarded with access to state power.

The Israelis will not offer anything, not under Netanyahu, not with Trump in the WH, and certainly not at the UN. The Palestinians will demand a state for themselves within the 1967 armistice lines. (Whether they really mean it is a separate issue -- they had been offered something very close to that and refused.) So I have a question. Why 1967 armistice lines? These lines existed for a short period of 19 years during which the term "West Bank" had been coined. Aren't these lines arbitrary?

Well, Me. Kristof, call me “childish.” I don’t trust Donald Trump.

The “summit” in Singapore is scheduled to begin in less than a week. The American president is desperate for the world to see him as a bona fide, genuine statesman, an international leader who possesses the requisite gravitas, the unimpeachable currency as a peacemaker.
That was President Barack Obama. It was even Ronald Reagan; it was Richard Nixon.

It is not easy for me to, like you, cheer Trump’s attempts at finding a way. He didn’t seem interested in reading the laborious, tedious details of the multi-nation agreement from 2015, an imperfect one, to be sure, but one with an interest in stifling a budding nuclear program in Iran.

Kim Jong-un has far more weaponry than Iran; yet we are expected to be thrilled with the prospect of an overarching deal next week. Kim, with Trump sitting across from him, will be getting something for nothing.

That’s worth cheering?

Wow, this is rich.

Senate Democrats are forcefully demanding that there be no sanctions relief for North Korea until/unless they "dismantle and remove every single one of North Korea’s nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons" and “end production and enrichment of uranium and plutonium for military purposes, destroy test sites, eliminate ballistic missile programs, and submit to "robust compliance inspections"”.

So, basically Democrats are insisting that there be no phased de-nuclearization, as has been the cornerstone of every attempted agreement in the past. Democrats demand that North Korea must first give up everything before any sanctions can be eased.

Of course, North Korea would be insane to agree to such a deal. It would be like them insisting that the U.S. end all sanctions first, and only then they will give up their weapons and capabilities.

Bottom line? Senate Democrats want to prevent any deal from ever being reached, apparently preferring endless hostilities to a chance for peace.

On the bright side, they supported eliminating sanctions on Iran, despite an agreement that allowed continued development of ballistic missiles and less-than-robust inspections, not to mention broad expansion of Iran’s conventional military activities threatening Israel and our Arab allies.

So - let me see - if Trump does a crazy, reckless, childish, dangerous thing like threaten North Korea with a war that would kill hundreds of thousands of South Koreans, we are then supposed to praise him if he later does something normal and reasonable like engage in talks?

No, Mr. Kristoff, it doesn’t work that way. All Trump is doing now is what any president SHOULD do, and what all previous presidents DID do - work to find a peaceable resolution to the Korean problem. He does not get extra credit for this because he started out by being bellicose and insane.

Beyond that, praising Mr. Trump is giving him exactly what he wants. It’s adding fuel to the fire of his raging, damaged ego. We should actively NOT do this (even in situations where another president might actually merit some praise), because to do it is to fall right into his trap. It is to be manipulated into giving our assent to his dangerous designs.

Korea is an easy one, however: With Mr. Kim, Trump has not, as of now, done anything that deserves special praise, so not giving him any is the reasonable thing to do.

I'm a democrat, skeptical, but still supportive of Trump's efforts to meet with North Korean leaders.

What's bothersome here is the double-standard. President Trump will almost certainly accept a deal with North Korea that is worse than the United States' prior deal with Iran, which he killed. If that happens, then I hope any celebration of the summit is met with a loud cry of hypocrisy and an insistence that the U.S. go back to honoring its commitments in the middle east. Otherwise Trump's scorecard should read 1W, 1L.

Trump brings to the negotiating table a solid record of broken deals, duplicity, dishonesty, breath taking narcissism, lack of attention to detail, and questionable motives. The North Koreans are disciplined, intelligent, savvy, and have been outsmarting the US at the diplomatic game for decades. What could possibly go wrong?

In terms of Trump the negotiator, what can one expect from such a shallow, ill informed, unprepared, show man, who is also seemingly uninterested in detail and easily distracted and bored? If anything of real substance results from the summit, then the accolades can follow, not before.

I'm a liberal, progressive Democrat and I agree in full with Mr. Krisof on this one. I despise Trump and the ruin he is causing America, but even a broken clock is right twice a day, as they say. This is one of those times.

Trump is right on this one as he's giving Kim a lot of "freebies" that are of little consequence to Americans but highly valued by the DPRK's young leader. In signaling his willingness to meet face to face, Trump is treating Kim as an equal, and to a regime that values face, respect, and it's own inflated sense of self importance, that's a huge concession and a good momentum builder for further talks.

Ultimately, Kim and Trump value the same things, so they may well find a natural rapport. Both value their own family's primacy before all other concerns. If Trump promises to leave Kim alone, secure in power, that will alone reduce tensions and possibly lead to diplomatic breakthroughs in future years. We can also be sure that Trump--who cares little for the needs of others--won't bring up issues of human rights, which have also vexed previous negotiations (obviously, human rights are critical, but demanding action at the BEGINNING of talks has never gotten anywhere).

To be sure, Trump's peace "plan" is a long shot. But it's better than the 70 years of pursuing the same failed strategy. Trump is a fool and easily flattered, but by giving Kim what he desires most--respect, a meeting of equals, a seat at the table, it just might work.

Donald Trump is irrelevant to the peace process, because he is unpredictable and untrustworthy. If peace occurs it will be in spite of Trump, as no traditional U.S. 'enemy' would eschew its only deterrent against a U.S. military attack.

The Koreas will make peace, the North will maintain its nuclear warheads at current levels of readiness, and Trump will claim 'victory' in the same way that a rooster claims credit for the sunrise.

"Democrats Childishly Resist .... " over states the details of your essay. What you apparently would prefer is that Shumer and company would applaud our president's new found penchant for diplomacy. Well, no, they didn't do that, and perhaps for the reasons you suggest.

If Trump manages to get beyond diplomatic theater, then would be the time to urge Democrats to support substantive negotiations. But to lay out conditions in advance for these is not 'petulent' but prudent. Implicitly these senators dignify the president's efforts with a measure of respect in writing anything at all at this point.

I fail to grasp how Democrats giving advice that is certain to be ignored can be construed as a is failure to support the president. Whatever comes of Trump's ham-handed initiatives. however meagre, he will hail as a triumph which can be credited to his genius alone. There is really little to be gained by Democrats emulating the kind of naive cheerleading Trump supporters generate, when the North Koreans got face-to-face talks without agreeing to anything at all, and at one report, were angling to the United States to foot the bill for their delegation's stay in a luxury hotel.

This column represents the worst kind of false equivalence.  Even assuming Trump's meeting with Kim is a good thing, a highly dubious proposition, given what Kristoff admits has been driven by a chaotic process for which the President is clearly unprepared, Democratic skepticism is in no way comparable to Trump's criticism and ultimate withdrawal of the Iran deal.  The Iran deal was a US commitment which included comprehensive inspections and other protections for the US and its allies.  Trump's opposition to the deal was clearly motivated not by concern for US security, but by the fact that the Obama administration negotiated it.   By contrast, Democrats are concerned that an ignorant, arrogant, ill prepared president will enter into negotiations on complex, life and death issues and make devastating mistakes.  One of these things is not like the other.

After the early tweet threats of nuclear annihilation, I don't trust him at all to handle the situation.  He risked ruin of the entire planet; that is a terrible bet even if it pays off.  You should judge a risk manager on the quality of their bets more than their results.  Ruin hides in the unlikely events so the risk won't necessarily appear in the data until its too late.  So far so good... so what.

To this observation:
"Trump’s newfound pragmatism is infinitely preferable to the threat of nuclear war that used to hang over all of us, so it’s mystifying to see Democrats carping about any possible North Korea deal."

I would completely agree if that "threat of nuclear war" (with NK, at least) ever existed before last year.

Kim has no desire to see his country wiped off the map and he knows he has neither the fire power, the resources or funding to engage in any military expedition.

So Trump saving us from nuclear war is just like Trump saving us from "American Carnage" or Muslim invasion or MS-13 or unfair trade.

He creates these illusory crises out of whole cloth or billowing exaggerations, then "solves" them with bluster and horse hockey.

Meanwhile, for real issues that affect real American communities -- like DACA, health insurance, the opioid epidemic, or gun violence -- he uses his usual bait and switch of promising something bigly and beautiful that everyone will be so happy with someday, one day soon, we will see, and then distract us with a thousand inanities until we move on to the next crisis.

But who can trust him (or Kim) at this point?

"How to Break the Impasse on North Korea"

North Koreans are not stupid. They know that Mr. Trump is unstable and can change his mind with every breath he takes. They saw how irresponsible and irrational he can be, when he withdrew from Iran's Nuclear Agreement - a multi-national agreement that the US was a signatory. So, at this stage, they will try to go through the motions, do little things here and there to allow Trump say that things are moving along. In the meanwhile, they will be extracting as many concessions as they can get out of Trump. But like many other nations, in reality, they are just waiting for the next administration.

If Trump was rational, before doing anything, he would have asked North Koreans to provide a clear statement of what they actually think "denuclearization" means. Mr. Trump, in his haste to have a foreign policy "win" and possibly to receive a Nobel Peace prize, intentionally left such issues on the back-burner. He wanted a photo-opt and an appearance on the world stage as a seasoned deal-maker. He got the first, but he has no credibility to get the latter.

Trump will achieve little on the Korean peninsula beyond driving North and South together prematurely and terrifying our allies in the region.

Meanwhile, Kim will increase his stockpiles of fissile materials, completed warheads, and all manner of delivery systems. All this will make the price of negotiating away the North's nuclear arsenal that much steeper. That is, if we can ever get around to it.

My fear is the US, as the unreliable partner in the region, will be squeezed out and perhaps happy to leave. That will leave the North as the dominant peninsular military force, and China the dominating regional economic power. Russia will continue its spoiler role, playing Kim's nukes against China and whatever's left of the US presence. Everyone will pay lip service to sanctions, but they'll leak like a sieve.

Trump couldn't care less about South Korea or even Japan. He's had a pointless but showy summit and literally declared victory on the flight home. He's turned it over to Pompeo who'd much rather harass Iran.

The South is probably the big loser, but it's hoping that Kim's tender mercies and the bonds of a common people will somehow protect them from annihilation if not domination.

I, for one, wouldn't trust Kim, Xie, or Putin as far as I could throw them. But I'm not president of the United States. Trump seems just as happy to bring the legions home, so long as he finally gets his stupid parade.

I think the real reason NK met with Trump had nothing to do with sanctions and Trump's tough talk. It was because NK finally had achieved their decades long quest.... Being able to deliver an intercontinental nuclear payload. At that point, they finally had a true seat at the table.

Until the US recognizes that fact, there will be no progress. The US thinks we pressured them into negotiations when that had nothing to do with it. (aka Trump's ego). We think we can continue to pressure them into it, thinking it will work. (not). In the mean time, NK has made a few inconsequential steps to show the world that they are supposedly willing to more forward in negotiations and that they are not the holdup. Kim has presented a new image of one of cooperation whereas the US has maintained an all-or-nothing up front demand that the entire world recognizes as not really a negotiation among adversaries.... it is a take-it-or-leave-it demand that is Trump's modus operandi. In the mean time, Kim now is focusing on economic improvement, using his newly found improved reputation as leverage.

Trump enhances his bully reputation but will get nowhere.
Kim makes international headway and looks more like the victim.
That is not progress in my opinion.

The Kim dynasty presided over the horrific North Korean famine of 1994-98. Kim Jong-il, father of the current plump Great Leader, maintained his military and his own properties in excellent shape, but let the people starve.

So. Donald Trump has now met Kim Jong-un, the dictatorial successor to a murderous authoritarian. And he likes what he sees. Describing Kim Jong-un, Trump said, “... his people sit up and pay attention. I want my people to do the same.”

Ah, the happy Kims! North Korean citizens are denied the power of free speech, threatened with arrest and probable torture if they criticize the government, denied a free press, required to hang big portraits of the Beloved Leader in their houses, instructed to chant and applaud in unison, blasted with public messages exalting the allegedly godlike, paternal Kim, and repeatedly entertained by ponderous phallic military parades that feature a lot of goose stepping soldiers called upon to demonstrate, again and again, the national, natural potency of Kim.

Trump sees this, and thinks, “what’s not to like?”

Anyone who believes that the North Koreans are seriously considering giving up their nuclear weapons is deluding themselves.  Kim has played the ignorant and hapless Trump like a fiddle.  The Art of the Farce.

Let’s give the man his due. This is a good thing. This is healing. Yes it panders to trumps base but yeah they’re human beings too, just like you and they would like the return of their loved ones. As would you.

Sorry folks, rightly or wrongly I fail to see any value in returning US war remains to the US. I have never understood why some people "value" the remains of someone who has died. By all means, remember the loved one but let the dead return to the earth they came from wherever they have been laid to rest.

Kim Jung Un and the Trump person are equally to blame for this cheap political shot at showing a "respect" neither one of these persons are capable of having.
Donald Trump will claim this as a victory.   It is not a "victory " for anyone.   It is, unfortunately, an empty gesture by a ruthless, scheming dictator.  Which could be either Trump or Kim.
...where their 112-year-old parents anxiously await them.

Do we know from what area(s) in North Korea these remains were recovered? There must be many in the Chosen Reservoir area where Chinese 'volunteers' surrounded large units of US troops. The survivors of that debacle are known as "The Chosen Few."

We have the arrogance of MacArthur to thank for leaving these guys vulnerable. He predicted/believed that the Chinese would never intervene. So, he was unprepared when they streamed across the Yalu River.

Oh, well. We should be thankful that some progress on repatriation of remains is occurring.
Excellent news. I'm not holding my breath on denuclearization (though of course, I'm hoping for it), but this development is absolutely positive on its face.

Wonderful for the descendants of the soldiers.
This would be excellent news, if it were true.  However, since trump lies about everything, whatever is in the tiny coffins will probably turn out to be Kim's executed ministers.

Trump said his thanks to Kim Jong Un almost calling him a hero. I find this insane. Kim Jong Un starves his people, and is a ruthless killer who only wants power. No offense Mr. Trump, but that is certainly not a hero.

When Trump wins, he loses.

a good sign for improving relations between North Korea and the United States.

as a South Korean citizen, I hope this news to lead up to more concrete actions of normalising the relationships.

Donald Trump has politicized foreign policy to dangerous levels. Ignoring Russia's proven attempts to sabotage our elections, Trump is now accusing China of "interfering" in our elections. -

This transparently self-serving accusation can serve as a pretext for questioning the legitimacy of the impending Democratic victories in the mid-term elections. The trumped-up charges against China will also stoke patriotic anger among Trump's followers, a move Trump hopes will obscure his failing trade war with Beijing.

No other U.S. president has ever risked international chaos in order to serve his personal and political interests in such a nakedly callous manner. In this respect, Donald Trump stands alone.

The most bizarre aspect of Trump and his backers is that they really think they can beat up on some one else and then they get to claim victimhood when the person strikes back.

People or Nation it works the same way.

Trump attacked China on trade and imposed tariffs as a sanction. China responded. Trump whines. China laughs at Trump.

He thinks international politics is a board game--and the world is thrilled watching him play--beating all those dummies.

He may never have his rude awakening--the UN debacle showed clear signs of dementia--not quite early onset.

As the temporary president of the U.N. Security Council, Trump probably thought that made him president of the world and that it gave him the right to talk down to all the rest of the leaders.
Rash, inaccurate statements that pop into his otherwise empty cavity are an embarrassment to all Americans.
There must be at least a few people that voted for him that must have a red face by now.
Now's the time to start laughing AT trump and distract him permanently from anything important.

Trump is having fun with the Democrats doing the Hillary.

I would suggest Democrats start thinking up their fake excuses for losing now.

China? Really? They’re interfering in our elections but not Russia?

God help us. We need to remove this loon from office.

As usual, Trump seeks to blame others for his own incompetence. His tariffs are discouraging his own loyalists and negatively affecting GOP chances in upcoming elections, and he wants to blame China for this. Russian interference...good.
Chinese interference...bad.
Got it, Donny.

Apparently election "interference" is not important to Donald Trump when a foreign power is actively working to get HIM elected, namely Russia. But if Trump believes that a foreign power is working against him, THEN it's a major issue to be addressed on an international stage. As usual, Trump's priorities are completely about him.

China is getting a mirror image of their false talk. Anyone check the water supply and air quality in China. While they poison their own people with environmental pollution the wealthy buy condominiums in NYC. Trump is giving them a taste of their own medicine.
China, not Russia!

I have no doubt that nations attempt to influence the elections of other nations. While I generally do not trust Trump due to his frequent, overt lying, I have no reason to doubt him in this case. Whatever the facts, it is obvious that voting systems in the USA are a complete joke. This is not a debatable proposition. If ATM machines were run like American elections, the banks would all be out of business. The flaws of American voting were made plain in the 2000 Presidential election, what with hanging chads, butterfly ballots, etc. For example, it seems most likely to me that but for the confusing butterfly ballot in Palm Beach County, where Pat Buchanan received a inexplicably high share of the vote, Al Gore would have been elected President in 2000. It is well past time for a Constitutional amendment to require uniform, secure voting procedures nationwide. We need to adopt sensible reforms like mandatory voting, making election day a national holiday, increasing the number of polling places, using professionals to operate polls rather than poorly trained volunteers, and using the same, secure system of voting nationwide, etc. In fact, if Bush v. Gore was anything other than a blatant power grab, its logic would demand that we use uniform voting systems nationwide.

"...he reintroduced the notion that a foreign power could alter the outcome of an American election."

Setting the stage for his monumental tweet-storm of false, unfounded and prevaricated accusations in the event the electorate eviscerates the GOP's Congressional majorities come November...

The PRC viewed Obama's pivot to Asia seriously as "Encirclement' with Trump his name provokes a smile at the populist level and likely the same up top. American politics a form of entertainment,
They have a custom of looking into the future as often knowable.

Utter nonsense but not surprising (and quite clever in a way) in view of the predicted mid-term elections results...and regrettably, his base will believe it. Ms Nimrata "Nikki" Haley must be having cerebral convulsions whenever such outrageously implausible statements are made.

How utterly embarrassing and cringe-worthy for us to witness world's delegates laughing at Mr. Trump...

The trumped-up charges against China will also stoke patriotic anger among Trump's followers, a move Trump hopes will obscure his failing trade war with Beijing.

No other U.S. president has ever risked international chaos in order to serve his personal and political interests in such a nakedly callous manner. In this respect, Donald Trump stands alone.

The most bizarre aspect of Trump and his backers is that they really think they can beat up on some one else and then they get to claim victimhood when the person strikes back.

People or Nation it works the same way.

Trump attacked China on trade and imposed tariffs as a sanction. China responded. Trump whines. China laughs at Trump.

He thinks international politics is a board game--and the world is thrilled watching him play--beating all those dummies.

He may never have his rude awakening--the UN debacle showed clear signs of dementia--not quite early onset.

As the temporary president of the U.N. Security Council, Trump probably thought that made him president of the world and that it gave him the right to talk down to all the rest of the leaders.
Rash, inaccurate statements that pop into his otherwise empty cavity are an embarrassment to all Americans.
There must be at least a few people that voted for him that must have a red face by now.
Now's the time to start laughing AT trump and distract him permanently from anything important.

Trump is having fun with the Democrats doing the Hillary.

I would suggest Democrats start thinking up their fake excuses for losing now.

China? Really? They’re interfering in our elections but not Russia?

God help us. We need to remove this loon from office.

As usual, Trump seeks to blame others for his own incompetence. His tariffs are discouraging his own loyalists and negatively affecting GOP chances in upcoming elections, and he wants to blame China for this. Anyone with even half a brain could have predicted this outcome, but Trump does not have the intellectual capacity to foresee the obvious effect of his own actions.

Russian interference...good.
Chinese interference...bad.
Got it, Donny.

Apparently election "interference" is not important to Donald Trump when a foreign power is actively working to get HIM elected, namely Russia. But if Trump believes that a foreign power is working against him, THEN it's a major issue to be addressed on an international stage. As usual, Trump's priorities are completely about him.

China is getting a mirror image of their false talk. Anyone check the water supply and air quality in China. While they poison their own people with environmental pollution the wealthy buy condominiums in NYC. Trump is giving them a taste of their own medicine.
China, not Russia!

I have no doubt that nations attempt to influence the elections of other nations. While I generally do not trust Trump due to his frequent, overt lying, I have no reason to doubt him in this case. Whatever the facts, it is obvious that voting systems in the USA are a complete joke. This is not a debatable proposition. If ATM machines were run like American elections, the banks would all be out of business. The flaws of American voting were made plain in the 2000 Presidential election, what with hanging chads, butterfly ballots, etc. For example, it seems most likely to me that but for the confusing butterfly ballot in Palm Beach County, where Pat Buchanan received a inexplicably high share of the vote, Al Gore would have been elected President in 2000. It is well past time for a Constitutional amendment to require uniform, secure voting procedures nationwide. We need to adopt sensible reforms like mandatory voting, making election day a national holiday, increasing the number of polling places, using professionals to operate polls rather than poorly trained volunteers, and using the same, secure system of voting nationwide, etc. In fact, if Bush v. Gore was anything other than a blatant power grab, its logic would demand that we use uniform voting systems nationwide.

"...he reintroduced the notion that a foreign power could alter the outcome of an American election."

Setting the stage for his monumental tweet-storm of false, unfounded and prevaricated accusations in the event the electorate eviscerates the GOP's Congressional majorities come November...

The PRC viewed Obama's pivot to Asia seriously as "Encirclement' with Trump his name provokes a smile at the populist level and likely the same up top. American politics a form of entertainment,
They have a custom of looking into the future as often knowable.

Utter nonsense but not surprising (and quite clever in a way) in view of the predicted mid-term elections results...and regrettably, his base will believe it. Ms Nimrata "Nikki" Haley must be having cerebral convulsions whenever such outrageously implausible statements are made.

How utterly embarrassing and cringe-worthy for us to witness world's delegates laughing at Mr. Trump...

Trump has berated and accused all parties on every front, China, Japan, Canada, his nominee, without any specifics whatsoever.  He has deals in process on all fronts and willing to make them with all takers.  All critics are damnable.  Again, no specifics.  This is an ego on parade.  Naked, too, by the way.

“It’s rigged folks,...”

There we go again.
45 was told that the Republicans’ performance in the upcoming mid-term election will be a shipwreck.

Planting the seeds of doubts regarding our elections already.
It’s a twofer. The sort of talk that would energize his base. And an excuse for poor mid term performance

The point here should not be that China or Russia or Israel or Saudi Arabia or Canada is trying to sway US voters but rather how can anyone from the US, a democrat or a republican complain about it when US is doing the same in any other country in the world where it's beneficial to American interests!

Finally, a President who knows how to make deals with the art and finesse of a Wharton School alumni , and successful billionaire businessman! Stand firm Mr. President and make them (China) pay their fair share!
Lucky he's not a woman because then we'd have to believe his accusations that have no evidence behind them...
Yup China will interfere with our elections using tariffs and again Trump cooperates with an interfering country,  this time by starting a trade war.

Great. Like the threat of war is going to solve our issues with a country with a working infrastructure, a functioning education system, people with access to real information and what was a pretty good pact: one in which Iran promised to NEVER develop a nuclear weapon. But all of that is based on reality, something our president has a poor relationship with, to put it mildly.

Let's take a look at history. In 1913 the British grabbed Iranian oil and made it their property. Six years later, Britain imposed another agreement and took over Iran’s treasury and the army. During the Second World War, Britain’s requisitioning of food led to famine and widespread disease. Shortly after that war, Iran’s own efforts to establish its nascent democracy and nationalize the oil industry were thwarted. And by whom? Uncharacteristically, Eisenhower joined the systematic British looting, and, sadly, by 1953, the blossoming Iranian democracy was completely destroyed by the covert operation of the American CIA and British MI6, known as Operation Ajax. In place of the democracy was installed Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, a US-British puppet, a despot deeply hated by his own people. His fall to the Khomeini’s mullahs was so precipitated that even today Iranians see it as a British plot, branding Britain as “Original Satan.”
AND NOW TRUMP WANTS WAR!
What can Iranians think?

Tweets and noise aside, the sad fact is that the U.S. has shown it cannot be trusted by anyone, least of all by Iran:

To refresh memories: In the aftermath of 9/11 Iran's President was the first world leader to offer condolences, Iran then proceeded to assist the U.S.-backed Northern Alliance in kicking the Taleban out of Afghanistan (fully documented by U.S. Special Envoy to Afghanistan James Dobbins) and was promptly rewarded with the 'Axis of Evil' epithet ...... while the Saudi perpetrators of 9/11 continued Business As Usual.

The same happened with ISIS, created by U.S. ally Saudi Arabia, whom Iranian ground troops bravely fought with scant recognition from the Western media, let alone from the Congress/Senate.

The history of U.S. betrayal of Iran is too lengthy for this post. Suffice to say I met with many Iranian government officials during my decade (2000 - 2009) as head of a major European bank in Iran, and the term 'Neocon-Zionist Conspiracy' came up time and again as the stumbling block to peace between Iran and the U.S.. The belief is that even the most well meaning U.S. President will/would be powerless to oppose the agenda of the Kochs, Adelsons, AIPAC, etc.,.

So we are literally at a stalemate, one that can be broken only if the U.S. makes the first move and terminates sanctions. More threats will only bring us all closer to Armageddon.

Re Trump’s “determination to use the same approach that he took to engineer a diplomatic breakthrough with North Korea.”

I don’t think it’s accurate to call the North Korea fiasco a “diplomatic breakthrough.” Kim Jung Un had been desparate for recognition from world leaders since his reign began. Not long ago he rolled out the red carpet for none other than Dennis Rodman in order to get that legitimacy he desparately needs. But presidents prior to Trump steadfastly refused to give the North Korean leader or his father recognition without a verifiable abandonment of nuclear aspirations.

Trump simply decided to cave, handing Kim Jung Un not just diplomatic recognition but even outright praise, without a single verifiable concession in return. Trump strapped a saddle on his back and let Kim Jung Un mount him, entrenching Un’s power and cementing Trump’s own legacy as the greatest diplomatic buffoon this country has ever seen.

Diplomatic “breakthrough”? Try “mule ride.”

There is no "Iran policy". There also is no NK policy, or trade policy or immigration policy or any coherent policy of the Trump administration. Trump's "policy" involves whatever strokes his ego at the time. Anything that plays well with the base and gets attention. He revels in creating a crisis (more press) and then "fixing" said self-created crisis (a win). North Korea is the clearest example.
His motivations are either his ego, or deflection from some other crisis he just created. For example, we are no longer talking about the Helsinki debacle, we are talking about Iran. Mr. Trump has nicely deflected the conversation and we follow along like labradors chasing a tennis ball wherever it is thrown.
Trump's interest always has been and will be himself. He cares not two hoots about the US and the majority of it's citizens. The sooner we realize this and stop attributing his random actions to some coordinated policy the better. This dangerous clown king needs to go. Vote!

World politics cannot be solved with a tweet or many tweets. It takes hard ground work and compromises by both sides. This tweet like many others from Trump was aimed at being a distraction, what we don't know and should be very concerned about, is how far will Trump go with his distractions? Is he willing to start a war with Iran if it helps him stay in power? Whether we like it or not Trump is the President and what he says or tweets will affect this country. Impeachment or the 25th Amendment is the only way to remove this incompetent threat from our country.

I am horrified that a relatively mild comment by the president of Iran ("the mother of all peace" or "the mother of all wars") would evoke such an angry response from Trump while the actual attack of our democracy by Russia under Putin's direction has elicited nothing in response at the instigation of Trump.  All sanctions were either congressional or by Obama in origin while Trump equivocates.  Add that much of the ire of Iran is because of the Trump administration dismantling of the accord achieved by the negotiated settlement during the Obama administration.  He is a danger to us all as global citizens.

We must remember that the Iranian government is trapped by its own ideology. The Iranian people are largely innocent bystanders to the activities of their heavy handed theocracy, which is the unintended consequence of the CIA engineered the overthrow Iran's nascent democracy in 1953.

Iranians are a sophisticated people with a rich culture, and a lively interest in western ideas and cultures. When Tehran and Washington try to demonize each other, we should remember that the threats and vituperation are coming from a small minority of motivated by their own interests. The bad blood being ginned up by despots on both sides should not, and does not necessarily reflect an enmity of the Iranian or American people for each other.

Let’s suppose that the foreign minister of Germany gave a speech in which he pledged that Germany would work with the American people to undermine the government of the United State, which was led by a “hypocritical corrupt businessman” (since money is in many ways the god of American capitalists). How would Trump, Pompeo and Bolton regard that kind of threat? And let’s not forget that as much as Iran has meddled in the affairs of their neighbors, our hands are not exactly clean in Iran during the pre-Islamic Republic days. As much as these tweets are worrisome, let’s not forget that they are designed to take attention off the collusion with Russia investigation.

I have a great idea for Trump.  A peace treaty with Iran, where they agree to give up their nuclear program in exchange for a commercial opening.  In fact, there is a really well thought-through draft already prepared, which the Iranians would accept.  He could boast bigly about how he created peace with Iran, and just not mention to his supporters that the treaty was negotiated by Obama and the same he tore up without cause a few months ago.

So let me get this straight. Iran is bad because of “hypocritical holy men,” guilty of looting their country to enrich themselves and finance Islamist terrorism around the world. But North Korea and Russia, also led by hypocritical cult figures guilty of looting their country to enrich themselves and finance murderous shenanigans around the world, those guys are A-OK. Got it.

I know, I know, it's all part of Trump's double-secret intricate plan to bring jobs to America. Or something.

The Trump administration is more of a TV series than a government. At some point in time, the public, even his base, will tire of “The Trump Show”. He will run out of ready foreign villains (there are only so many countries) to vaguely threaten, he will run out of domestic villains(animals, parks, immigrants will be gone) to demonize and people will quit being distracted by the daily shiny objects.  Iran is this week’s distraction which ticks many of the Trump base boxes; foreign, Islamic, mysterious, vaguely threatening. What better country to vaguely threaten in a copy of last summer’s episodes of vaguely threatening North Korea.  The season ended with a shocking finale with Kim and Trump becoming friends.  Although awfully derivative, a similar ending with Iran would be welcomed.

Make no mistake - Trumps' tweet was "LOUD and CLEAR"
Iran gets it, and will continue to get it. Two Things are headed their way. Regime change (protests are still happening) or capitulation. Sanctions are working, and Russian abandonment has happened. Also Israel's recents devastating strikes against IRANIAN forces in Syria have been the icing on the cake. Their economy is tanking and businesses are avoiding IRAN like the plague. Iran's Government sees the writing on the wall, and for all the tough talk, they know the U.S. will make good on it's threats. It's only a matter of time before positive change happens.

Mr. Trump’s threat that Iran would “suffer consequences the likes of which few throughout history have ever suffered before”.
But it only deepened questions about the long-term direction of Mr. Trump’s Iran policy.
What policy? Schoolyard threats are not policy.

What's unclear to me is why the US would even feel threatened by Iran. Iran can barely fight off attacks from it's weak neighbors, much less a superpower. For the love of all that's holy, we need to quit meddling in everybody's business. Leave Iran alone and stay out of the Iran-Israel rivalry. It's a deadly trap that will just consume American lives and treasure with zero benefit.
Ok, then please do not chase the "bait" (the upper case Iran tweet).    Stay focused on 1) the stinky in Helsinki,  2) Storm Daniels, 3) Michael Cohen, 4) his tax returns.

Unfortunately, what you say is spot on. I really thought that disaster in Helsinki would hurt Trump even with the spineless GOP and his lap-dog “base.” Not so. His poll numbers didn’t go down, even though he is sucking up to one of America’s greatest adversaries.

What gives? Is our collective memory that short, or is Trump that convincing? A little of both, probably, but certainly not good for the US.

Find candidates with policies that help all Americans for the November mid-terms, and go out and vote. Yes Trump has a strong base, but it’s a plurality and not a majority. There is room, and a need, for new, well-qualified candidates who will actually protect our Constitution.

If you want to really compare Trump and Obama, consider this. Obama thought about policy, relationships, consequences. Trump doesn't. Trump doesn't even really have any policy of his own. He just negates Obama and calls it a day.

Obama had more than his share of problematic actions, but I'd take him in a heartbeat. Obama was brains and pragmatism; Trump is ego and impetuousness.

And as pointed out in other media outlets, the irony is that the Right lambasted Obama for making concessions to Iran for little more than a promise not to build a nuclear bomb for 10 years while looking the other way as it builds it ICBMs, finances terror proxies with billions in cash Obama allowed released (the excuse being it was Iran's money plus interest to begin with, but conveniently forgetting the US had garnished a larger amount in damages against Iran inflicted on US property and American lives but Obama dropped the claims), while looking the other way as the mullahs cracked down bloodily on pro-Democracy demonstrators and publicly hung gays. All with the hope that the atmospherics would eventually lead to peace.

Now Trump has made a few concessions to North Korea, the main one being a suspension of US/South Korea war games (which can be easily restarted if necessary) but has not dropped sanctions. And he didn't bring up human rights abuses except it's reported discussing kidnapped Japanese citizens to be repatriated. Instead, the hope like Obama with Iran is that improved atmospherics will lead eventually to real peace. And like clockwork, the Trump haters -- the very same times that gushed over the same Obama strategy with Iran -- are lambasting Trump for doing similar.

The benefit of the Iran deal was Iran dismantling its nuclear program and facilities and subjecting to international inspections. It worked.
That’s nothing like what Trump did, which was to accept Kim’s assertion of a desire to denuclearize someday as a “deal”, and downgrade our alliances in the region faster than you can say “Munich”.

Obama was a realist and was detail oriented.

Obama made deals to benefit the US and the world, particularly our allies.

Obama maintained good relationships with our allies, and let our enemies know where they stood.

Obama was brave.

Obama was smart.

Obama was graceful.

Obama was honest.

Obama was and remains a loyal American, who would not sell America's interest to benefit himself or his family financially.

Trump is none of those things.

Obama thoughtfully nurtured and repaired the frayed relationships with our important traditional allies that were damaged by W's administration.  Trump is trashing those relationships in a way that may be irreparable in favor of obsequious advances to brutal dictators.  Any comparison between the two is ludicrous.

Obama was not 'seeking an accommodation with Iran' - Obama was dealing with allies who were ready to break ranks on harsh sanctions PLUS the U.S. Courts had ruled that the U.S. had to return to Iran $ 1.5+ Billion$ per the SCOTUS ruling:

https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/04/20/474962528/supreme-cou...

which Obama and our allies were smart enough to try and keep Iran from using such funds to develop their nuclear capabilities, by concocting the Iran Nuclear Deal in advance of releasing the funds:

http://foreignpolicy.com/2015/07/30/congress-iran-nuclear-deal-obama-vet...

Obama didn't have very many options, since keeping our allies in line regarding harsh sanctions on Iran was becoming more and more difficult.

It is much much too cavalier an airbrushing of history to reduce these actual facts and details to 'seeking an accommodation with Iran'.

This is gibberish.

We can understand the Obama-Trump voter as a person who is so fed up with the political system as it is that they are willing to give the newcomer outsider a chance.

As far as the foreign policy argument, President Obama had a coherent foreign policy that can be summarized as just peace pragmatism outlined in his Nobel Lecture. (History will tell US why he never named it such) He understood the importance of multi-lateralism in global affairs and worked to strengthen both regional and global multinational organizations.

Thus, he was able to achieve the Paris climate accord that every nation on earth now supports except the Trump administration. He brokered the TPP, a deal that is going forward without the US and without our values thanks to Trump. President Obama brought European nations together with China and Russia to craft the Iran nuclear deal that Iran kept and the United States violated thanks to Trump. President Obama brought the world together to lock down loose nukes. I doubt if Trump even knows that such a program existed.

President Obama organized sanctions against Russia for its military theft of Crimea and put it out of the G-8. Now Trump wants to allow Russia back.

Both President Obama and Trump understand the limits of American power, however, President Obama worked toward a world working together with American leadership solving problems. All Trump has is petulance, ignorance, insubstantial flash, and possible treasonous criminality.

Our embargo of Cuba for 60 years is a national disgrace. Barack Obama couldn't do anything about that, thanks to a hostile Congress, and what little he did do had no real effect. Nothing is happening with Cuba. Nothing probably ever will.

North Korea is a different story. There's no way to ignore them and their provocations and do business with them. Donald Trump had to do something about it. And he's no huckster. He knew the thing to do was make a bold move and see what the reaction is. (Just like Napoleon Bonaparte: "First you move and then you wait and see.") We'll need to wait a while before we see.

I suspect Donald Trump will surprise many by reaching a lasting deal with North Korea. That will mean that he deserves a Nobel prize. Sadly, Barack Obama won one without ever doing anything to deserve it.

There is in this column a kernel of insight, which is that both Obama and Trump came into office with a sense that the old shibboleths of statecraft badly needed a refresh.

But, I think Douthat's thought process soon derails due to two omissions. The first is that Obama never, as far as I can remember, fawned over authoritarian despots like Putin, KJU, Erdogan, et al. You could not ever reasonably conclude that Obama wanted to replace the Atlantic Alliance, TPP, the Paris Accords and international relations with a strategic turn to strong-arm, one-man leaders.

Second, Douthat's case for Trump's attempt to upset the applecart of traditional diplomacy would make more sense if Trump actually favored the Iran nuclear deal. Talk about doing something completely different in the Mid-east! But Trump tore up the deal and in doing so, cast all his marbles with the increasingly reactionary Bebe Netenyahu and the Israeli police state.

Trump's foreign policy (and his domestic plans) are actually driven by avenging Barack Obama's clear distaste for him. Trump is driven by visceral hatred, and his policies are intentionally shaped by doing away with everything his predecessor tried to do. Thus, one can conclude, Obama was the adult, Trump is the petulant child.

This is painfully foolish logic. Worse, it misses the danger we're already in.

The fear among foreign policy cognoscenti, the Washington elite that Mr. Douthat dismisses, was Trump would give away the store in his tete-a-tete. A sigh of relief could be heard when the empty-of-substance statement emerged. Then came the hiccup, Trump's unilateral offer to stop joint US-South Korea military exercises, those with bombers. But that seems less serious that offering to pull US troops out of South Korea.

This analysis isn't too complex, it's too simple. The danger with Trump isn't a grand promise. It's that he breaks promises. Trump will have to walk back his commitment to cease joint exercises, because the US and S. Korean military will demand it. Kim will insist that Trump negotiates in bad faith. Trump, humiliated, will go ballistic.

The risk with Trump isn't facts, it's emotions. He's seriously corrupt, morally unhinged, and a narcissist. Obama was nothing like him. Trump won't have the spine to buck demands that he break his concession of no joint exercises. He'll lie outright, deny he made any commitment, and the N. Koreans and Chinese will flip. They're not bamboozled by his con-man style.

We're in the middle of a slow-motion crash, which is what all crashes feel like. Mr. Douthat is distracted by the strangeness of it all. I hope we're lucky, and avoid oncoming traffic. But don't hold your breath.

I don't blame Ben Rhodes for trying to bring out any similarity between Mr. Obama and Mr. Trump. He dishonestly suggests that Trump needs to have "racism and misogyny" stripped out leaving the two men with a view that Hillary Clinton is "part of a corrupt establishment that can’t be trusted to bring change.”

It is Mr. Obama that was part of the corrupt establishment for eight years. Putting aside his race, he was unable to move the economy or create jobs for those most in need. When it came to international trade he put intellectual property first and jobs second because Obama didn't put people first - ever. Even Hillary reluctantly concluded that it was time to put America first, but Trump had already won that contest.

Obama led on Cuba but he didn't care about the Cuban people or the Cuban economy. Obama respected Castro's decision to let communism rule. Trump is working with China, South Korea and Japan to Offer North Korea a business model that can work without a military - Something which Kim knows from his years in Switzerland.
Trump is a "longtime huckster" to some who invested in his businesses; but he is America's huckster now. Wish him luck.

Let's see. No definition of denuclearization; no timetable; no verification; no mention of ICBM dismantling; no mention of taking conventional artillery aimed at Soeul off hair-trigger status; nothing about human rights abuse; no apology for the family of Otto Warmbier. Ponder what his family must feel about the gushing praise just heaped by our president upon this brute.

For this we voluntarily removed a crucial anchor of American and Asian security from the world's hottest flashpoint and we accord the dictator of an all but failed nation, who is perhaps the world's most brutal tyrant, equal status with the most powerful and civilized nations on earth.

Slaying family members with anti-aircraft machine gun fire? Killing another nation's soldiers completely unprovoked with submarine torpedoes? Launchong missiles into the civilian areas of a non-combatant neighbor? Conducting cyber warfare worldwide? Hey, everybody does it; what's the problem? Anyway, Kim is a really funny guy; he makes great deals. You see, Trump has this instinct.

Just imagine this for a brief second. If Barack Obama had returned from Singapore with such a deal the Greek chorus of the GOP would have screamed bloody murder without cease, without mercy, and without a scintilla of shame.

Donald Trump himself would have ripped-up such a deal in the blink of an eye.

Why are so many commenters willing to give this group of unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats authority over American soldiers and U.S. policymakers? Are the largely European members of that "court" so much more morally pure than American counterparts? Is not the U.S. system of justice adequate for addressing egregious violations of humanity's norms?

In terms of those violations, certain European countries yet have much to answer for, high-minded hypocrisy notwithstanding.

Bolton's rhetoric against ICC is why the US credibility in the world has been eroding not just in the era of Trump, but for decades. On the one hand, the US is supposed to the champion of an international rule of law. On the other hand, the US continues to be above the laws it supposedly champions. "One set of rules for me, and another set of rules for thee." Or, put another way, "do as I say, not as I do." It's no wonder dictatorships like Russia and China, as well as extremist ideologies like Jihadism, have so much material to use in their propaganda.

This undermines US diplomatic efforts. It makes US efforts to promote international law seem like a fraud and a charade. It tells countries like Iran there is no real benefit to playing by supposed international rules. What would be the point? When they see this kind of might-makes-right behavior, their conclusion is to arm themselves with nuclear weapons so they can set their own rules.

Why stop there? Let's withdraw from the UN and close its offices in New York, cut all foreign aid and use the savings for tax cuts to the "makers" and provide more military aid to our real friends in Saudi Arabia so they can keep bombing Yemen. Now that's tough leadership that will Make America Great Again!

Under Trump, American exceptionalism, as seen by him and his followers, has reached perverse perfection akin to his self image. Neither he nor America can ever be wrong, whatever he or America under him does is unassailable and always right. His and Americas action cannot be criticized and outside scrutiny is threatened by sanctions, legal action or worse. To him and his followers anybody outside or within who do not follow his twisted notion of patriotism or do not adhere to his bizarre interpretation of the constitution is vilified, humiliated and threatened. This country has stopped being a member of the family of nations: we castigate our allies like foes and tolerate the behavior or even praise some of our foes; we have become a totally self-centered nation under Trump -  we have abandoned our moral high ground and become rudderless in the view of our allies and friends. I am utterly embarrassed, and it only seems to be getting worse.

Every military strongman or national government charged with war crimes or crimes against humanity has denied the legitimacy of the International Criminal Court to try them.  Bolton always opposed the Court because, he said it was only really set up to prosecute the US for its military interventions, direct or indirect. This fits a worldview that international criminal law is a sham motivated by politics, jealousy or hatred. This cynical attitude comes across as The Rules Don't Apply to US to the rest of the world.

The Framers of the Constitution once again are rolling in their graves.  The careful and balanced work to build a form of government and a society that is democratic, thoughtful, and against tyranny for Americans and an example to the world is under attack.  America has always strove to operate in the daylight with a real effort to openness to get it right.  ANY Republican or Democratic Administration prior to now would work with the court, make corrections and amends for provable wrongs.  While imperfect, the court, the UN, and many other entities exist as a check against those governments who take actions and advantage towards others.   WE, helped set up many of these stablizers and checks, and now American thugs want to weaken them for the only benefit of greed and arrogance.  America is better than this.

So many things wrong with our current policy, never mind the things that are wrong with Bolton and Trump.

NOTHING has been accomplished with N Korea that the US has done. Trump, with his phony buddy-buddy talk and the Singapore "summit" only gave Kim what he wanted ... recognition that he was a world power as evidenced by a meeting with the US president. South Korea, on the other hand, seems to be working out their own differences with NK without any help from the US.

Our support of Israel while dumping on Palestinians is not a path to peace.

As to the disregard of the International Criminal Court, I wonder how long it will be before the arrogance shown by GWB and reinforced by Trump's ego will take us out of the UN and NATO as well. And how long before WE are the ones charged with human rights violations.

As we become more isolated, we become more vulnerable. Someone needs to tell Donald (and those who think he's wonderful) that being a bully is not synonymous with being strong.

Bolton's threats against the Judges of the International Criminal Court are despicable. It is one thing to have an honest debate about the jurisdiction of the Court, but for Bolton to say, without any legal basis, that the U.S. will subject the judges to sanctions including being barred from the U.S. and having financial limitations imposed on them if they investigate any alleged war crimes by Americans is so contrary to the principles that have guided this nation. We respect the law and judges. We may disagree, but respect is important to the working of an international legal system.

Does Bolton claim sanctions will be imposed on the judges on the grounds of national security? Is he saying that no matter what conduct is being investigated, the U.S. will retaliate? Bolton brings Trump's bullying to a new low.

Time for a reality check. Most of your responders seem to support a form of the argument made by one responder (Robert Dole) who said that the US refusal to sign onto the ICC "means that the United States considers itself entitled to commit war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide with impunity." That is a total distortion of facts and simply untrue.

The US is fully committed against all those things and its courts are empowered to take action against individuals who commit those acts. What your responders either fail to recognize or refuse to accept is that the US refusal to sign onto the ICC is based ENTIRELY upon an unwillingness to subordinate its sovereignty to the rule of a bunch of foreigners or to subject members of its military forces to the spurious judgement of those same foreigners.

This is nothing new. It is entirely consistent with long held US positions. For example, neither the US nor any of the other major members of the UN (i.e. the five permanent members of the Security Council) ever would have joined EXCEPT for the fact that: 1) all the real power rests with the Security Council (the General Assembly is more of a coffee klatch), and 2) ANY permanent member of the Security Council can veto any action it disagrees with, thereby having an ironclad protection of its sovereignty.

The ICC offers no similar protection of US sovereignty. So for that reason, and that reason alone, the US is not a member and does not recognize its authority over the US.

Folks in the states of the following representatives should be mad and telling their reps to stop trying to waste time by persecuting Rod Rosenstein and let him finish the job he is paid to do. They are wasting your tax money and distracting from what needs to get done. They are the bullies behind trying to "impeach" Rosenstein (which is silly they can't so see they are just trying to muddle up the works)

These clowns are probably part of the GOP that is involved in the Russian money. The congress knocked their attempts down thank goodness. But be careful folks in Ohio, Jim Jordan wants to be the next speaker of the house!

“It is the case that the president calls the ball,” Mr. Pompeo said. “His statements are, in fact, policy.”
-- Secretary of State Mike Pompeo

So we can understand the following as the policy of the United States:

"You look at what happened. [The Russians] were plotting against my election." (Looks like U.S. policy contradicts the nation's intelligence agencies on this particular point.)

"...hopefully I'm in the process of beating very dishonest intelligence because, what they did was incredible." (In case you needed confirmation of U.S. policy on this.)

"You go into the FBI and take a poll of the real FBI -- not the scum on top, not Comey and that group of people that are total thieves." (So it is U.S. policy that the leadership of the FBI is "scum," and, incidentally, that the way to assess the effectiveness of the FBI is to take a poll and find out how many of them swear fealty to Donald Trump.)

“We will be stopping the war games.” (So U.S. policy now states that military exercises in the South Pacific with allies Japan and South Korea have actually been, for all these decades, "games" that can now be halted.)

“I may be wrong [about trusting Kim Jong Un], I mean I may stand before you in six months and say, ‘Hey I was wrong.’ I don’t know that I’ll ever admit that, but I’ll find some kind of an excuse.” (U.S. policy is to take a known despot at his word, and if that turns out to be wrong, figure out a way to blame someone else.)

Wow. Mr. Pompeo refused to tell America what Mr. Trump agreed to in his secret meeting with Mr. Putin. Trump's press conference after the secret meeting was treasonous. It looks more and more like Pompeo is collaborating with Trump's betrayal of the nation. Trump's destruction has furthered every one of Putin's aims. This White House including Pompeo has done nothing to protect us from ongoing and future Russian interference in our elections. Given that, how can Pompeo claim (really, lie) that the administration is being tough on Russia? How can Pompeo claim the administration and Trump are one and the same when Trump's words and actions--including whatever he agreed to in the secret meeting--are altogether untethered from what Mr. Coates et al. are telling us? Senator Corker is right. Trump was submissive and servile in that notorious press conference. Just look at what this White House is doing. In their video record of the press conference, for instance, they have already deleted the part in which Putin says that he wanted Trump to win.

Come Senators stop playing the American people for being just plain stupid and instead recognize how frustrated the entire electorate is with dysfunction.
What did you think Sec. Pompeo was going to say in an open hearing? The stage is clearly set on the DJT administration's side; DJT tweets and bluster are either lies or nonsense; SHS stands at her podium ever ready to gaslight the assembled media; the Cabinet and assorted staff stand ready to twist DJT and SHS utterances into a facsimile of a coherent policy and establish some improvement to their intelligibility. After decades of surrendering Congressonal authorities to the Presidency, Senate hearings are and will continue to be a side-show until either Congress recovers its Constitutional role with veto proof legislation or it zips the American pocket-book shut to trillon dollar deficit spending sprees.

Pompeo’s performance yesterday was appalling. He clearly demonstrated his preference for party over country, even when Republicans were asking pointed questions.

Pompeo sang the typical party line of “the prior administration didn’t do this or that...”, turning a blind eye to the treasonous actions of the Conman sitting in the White House and the danger the Conman poses to US democracy and democracy around the world.

Pompeo’s performance was a disgusting and sycophantic display of Party over Country.
Its just not good enough, Mr. Pompeo. The public has a need to know what transpired there.

When Pompeo sit in front of Senators trying to answer their questions, what was in his mind?

He thought nothing but how to please his boss and how to preserve his job.

From this vintage point, one can easily understand why he was so eager to defend Trump.

He is Trump's flunky first. Secretary of State second.

That's his priority.

Pompeo, the company man, 'spent much of the hearing insisting that it was the Trump administration deeds and not the president's words (I will add tweets here as well) that Americans should be listening to'. Is it me or did Pompeo call Trump a pathological liar who should be ignored as the WH administration is working around him for the sake of America and Americans?

If you can't trust the word of your own president, why is he still in office?

I would daily defend our president if he was out there defending our country, defending our Constitution, defending our democracy, paying attention to intelligence briefings about the ongoing Russian threat, as well as other foreign enemy power threats to our cyber space, defending our DOJ, defending our intelligence community, defending our right to a secure vote, defending our Free press, and defending the inalienable rights of the majority of Americans.

Trump is doing none of this and he is indefensible, Mike Pompeo. Your duty is to your country and not your career. Say and do the right thing by America and Americans. Do not sell out your country to the likes of a Trump.

Shame on Mr. Pompeo - a heavyweight by anyone's standards - for doing the bidding of this puppet president.  Shame on all those who prop him up, many of whom should know better.  History will damn you all.

The Senate hearing should have included a simple question: Does President Trump consult in depth with his foreign policy, defense, security team before and after making policy statements and meeting privately with foreign leaders ?
Pompeo insisted a president is allowed to have private talks--executive privilege.
But he never fully addressed the apparent loose canon quality to Trump's tweets & spontaneous public assertions.
After firing most of his team that seemed rational, expert, experienced and more savvy than he was-- he is left with Pompeo, Bolton, Mattis and Coats.
How often does he meet with this team to thoroughly review options & consequences ? Do they all accept the likelihood of hearing policy decisions after they're announced in tweets or FOX news?
Do Hannity, Miller & Conway provide the actual consultation to Trump on complex matters ?
Egad.

It appears that Mr. Pompeo has no idea of what was discussed in Mr. Trump's private meeting.  It is frightening that this is happening in my America.  I am past disgusted; I am more afraid everyday.  I love the USA and I think my President should love us, too.  SAD!
after watching Pompeo's condescension, short fuse and medieval sense of entitlement at this hearing, I am not all confident he is the person to rebuild the State Dept.

are now part and parcel of the dismantling of our democracy, no matter what you're telling yourselves in the mirrors.

What remains is for the NKs to fire these missiles into space and (a) develop the means to ensure that the alleged "warhead" can re-enter the atmosphere without disintegrating, and (2) then, once in the atmosphere, go on to accurately hit their target.

This means that either NK will continue firing its missiles, or covertly ship them to a neighboring country to have them tested.
