After the G-7 experience the European leaders should have been better prepared to take Trump for what he is or whose game he is playing. So Trump's wild card entry into the NATO summit is unlikely to spring any surprise except perhaps some more complaints and frustrations from his side.

The foundation of the Alliance is the strategic nuclear doctrine of mutually-assured-distruction. No NATO member trusts America's nuclear deterrent.

NATO doctrine has always been that a Russian invasion of Western Europe, would force NATO to utilize theatre nuclear weapons first in order to repel Russia's conventional forces, given the established (and accepted) asymmetry of conventional forces between NATO and Russia.

A use of theatre nuclear weapons invites and risks the use of strategic nuclear retaliation by Russia which is only deterred (according to NATO doctrine) by America's triad strategic nuclear land, air and sea based forces.

Trump has entirely undermined NATO's doctrine of deterrence and everyone from Moscow to Ottawa knows it.

NATO's non-American members will now build a new military alliance: one that is no longer dependent on America. This new alliance will be focused around the UK's and France's independent nuclear forces as the new guarantor of the West's strategic nuclear deterrent strategy.

It is entirely within the realm of possibility that Canada will now too seek to build its own independent nuclear deterrent force.

This Canadian force may be billed publicly as securing Canada against its Northern neighbour, Russia. But, it will also serve as a deterrent against possible aggressive military threats from America. Canada too has taken to heart Trump's comments, and like North Korea we have learned that Trump responds to military strength.

"Playing into Putin's hands"?  Well,  if what is meant by that is government of the rich; by the rich; and for the rich, then ... yes.  But it's not just Putin's hands that are being played into.  It's every dictator in every country in the world.  This explains Trump's admiration for every murderous thug dictator in the world and for trade policies which will raise the price of everything and keep everyone but the very rich struggling financially.  And, apparently,  as long as he keeps hugging the flag, his supporters will just keep refusing to recognize him for what he is.

There are no longer any illusions among EU and NATO allies regarding the Trump administration. Trump sees chaos and disorder as an advantage, giving him room to maneuver and employ leverage and extract concessions, even if he has no clear idea of what those concessions might be beforehand. Narcissism does not recognize the value of human relationships, and EU leaders now know they will not have good relations with this American president. All of which begs the question: this will make America great again??

Diplomacy is often clouded with secret protocols, side deals based on a wink and a nod, and other arrangements "not for public consumption". But this time around with the NATO summit meeting, the stakes are right out on the table for all to see. Although not present for the meeting (obviously), the goal of the Russian Federation is glaringly obvious: the ultimate breakup of NATO. The more dissension and squabbling among members, the more the RF - and of course its leader, Putin - love it. Putin is a revanchist, determined to restore some semblance of the old USSR. A fractured Western Europe would be a giant leap toward that goal, and if all it takes reams of flattering letters to stimulate Trump's role as an insider agent provocateur, he'll do it. Trump is painfully easy to manipulate, especially now that he's blown up like toad from a mere "birther" to a head of state, hob-nobbing with genuine national leaders. I'm sometimes tempted to think of Trump as a "useful idiot" - a term probably invented by Vladimir Lenin - at the end of Putin's puppet strings. Vodka and caviar all around in Moscow after the summit? Very likely.

Trump seems prepared to get along with our enemies while trashing our allies. It's not only embarrassing, it's very dangerous.

It would not be surprising for Trump to blow up the NATO meeting, then go on to complain to Putin about our allies.

He is a very dangerous man, especially since he doesn't read or take advice from others.
Is there a single person who believes that N. Korea will denuclearize?  Furthermore, now that it's "OK" for the border between them and China to be more porous, what impact will sanctions have?

To sum up: No more military exercises between the US and South Korea. North Korea isn't a nuclear threat anymore, according to Trump. Because the justification for sanctions has been removed, China, from which 90% of North Korea's imports flow, is getting ready to re-open the spigot of goods. Kim is now a rising star and world-class leader.

So, what's next for Kim? Attend more meetings with other world leaders, smile a lot, and praise Donald Trump's excellent negotiation skills, toughness, and trustworthiness. Direct his negotiators to delay, postpone, obfuscate, and issue vague promises to the Americans. In secret, continue producing more fissile material, improve bomb and missile designs, build new test site, missiles, etc. Above all, he'll bide his time: Trump could be out of office in 2-1/2 years and Pompeo will certainly be out in less than that.

And Trump, what will he do? Bring up his triumph in tweets, statements to the media, campaign-style rallies, etc. Praise Kim as courageous and talented. Remind everyone that no other president could have done this. Above all, bask in the adulation of his cultists.

What I see in all this is, Kim gains the upper hand. Though the U.S. states no sanctions lifted until complete denuclearization. However, China implies it will soften it's stance on sanctions. And what about Russia? I'm sure they'll have a hand to play in this game of diplomacy.

I'm not convinced we gained any ground, but North Korea sure as heck did. With all the pomp and ceremony Kim will look like Mr. Diplomat with his people. Meantime, we here in the states have to continue to listen to our "Liar and Chief" tell us all is just "great" and we can all sleep knowing we're safe from a nuclear attack.

I'm not worried about North Korea, it's the U.S. that's got me frightened! That's what keeps me up at night.

Compare the "brilliant deal maker's" (Trumps') agreement with North Korea with the "worst agreement ever" - the Iran deal President Obama struck along with the EU and Russia to prevent Iran from getting nuclear weapons. Kim made the same promises his father and grandfather have made and broken for decades. He made unverifiable claims to close a nuclear testing and a missile-testing site. In return he: is keeping his nuclear weapons and missiles; has gained world-wide recognition; broken the economic sanctions that took years to create and were finally biting; and got the U.S. to stop military exercises with our South Korean allies.  In the Iran deal, Iran: decommissioned thousands of centrifuges used to enrich fissionable materials that could be used for a nuclear bomb; agreed to not proceed with creating a bomb for at least a decade; accepted international observers and monitoring equipment to VERIFY that it was complying with the deal; and sent highly enriched uranium out of the country.  Inspectors have consistently found Iran in full compliance. In return the U.S. and Europeans were to lift sanctions [which would have benefitted all participants' economies] and return Iranian funds that had been frozen to Iran. The U.S. did not fully lift sanctions and withdrew from the deal and is trying to re-impose sanctions even after bashing our European allies. Iran no longer is obligated to not develop nuclear weapons. Great wins by Trump.

“Iranians Wonder: Why Won’t Trump Talk to Us?”  Very simple, Trump, quite erroneously, thought he could “negotiate” (manipulate and bully) “rocket man,” not realizing that the Korean dictator was way ahead of him and far smarter. Well, Kim got everything he wanted (for personal and home consumption) without so much as to even promise verification of denuclearization in the near future. Additionally, Kim now sits next to the president of the US, something his father and grandfather only dreamed of. Now Trump, the perennial clueless, will have to ease sanctions and embargoes lest of Kim reneging his “commitment.” Not bad for Little Rocket Man. Guess who is the loser. Iranians, on the other hand, have proven that they are really tough negotiators something Trump The Clueless is actually afraid to face. No possibility of golf courts or hotels in Tehran but great potential in Pyongyang.

Dunno about a few people from the posse down in LA, but the vast majority of Korean Americans are progressives/liberals (75% according to the poll) and they are wecoming the thawing  relationship, including the suspension of the military exercise. You certainly count me in it.

"Asked if he had been watching the news coverage, he pointed at the pool hall’s television with a slight shrug; the program on display was a Korean talk show. “Kim Jong-un is evil,” he added, and he did not need to watch the news to make up his mind about that. He soon returned to his game.
Lee Inho, 20, who moved to the United States when he was 5, said he was not even aware there was a meeting happening. “That’s something Americans care about,” he said with a smile, before walking back to a pool table to take his turn"

Certainly seems like these guys are thoroughly Americanized in terms of their engagement with current events.

Trump is cozying up to dictators and autocrats and alienating our democratic allies.

Re North Korean: peace, yes; denuclearization, yes; but also freedom and the respect of human rights.
A handful of Korean-Americans are pessimistic. Meanwhile, polls show that South Koreans are optimistic and hopeful - but US journalists somehow think they know better.

The mural pictured, of Kim coming to America, sent chill down the spine, especially after reading today’s op-ed “First They Came for the Migrants” (a must read for all Americans and (traditional) allies).
Whether or not Kim ever actually steps foot in America, his style and preference for inhumane governance is already gaining footholds in America, thanks to his buddy trump and his backers. Today we have a whole population of North Koreans trapped in their own home and asylum seekers at our borders begging to be let in. One fears that, if current trends are allowed to continue, tomorrow it may be Americans crowding our own borders, begging for asylum.
Steven Colbert could give a better speech and get even more laughs!

Korea has signed the Amendment to the FTA, which is nothing more than a good will gesture.  Nonetheless, Trump still insists on alleged unfair sharing of defense expenses.  US Forces in Korean peninsula is for the defense of US.  Korea has borne a substantial part of the costs for their presence and recent relocation.  Trump is demanding more like a crying baby.  Execution of the Amendment was a wise negotiation strategy, it is doubtful.

The U.S. appears weak and stupid with this republican president. Its a fact, no matter which ideology, movement, or belief one believes in.

Hope the republicans out there get the neutral message - from Switzerland!

"We are also standing up for the world.”

You are? How? And why would you when you're whole credo boils down to Trumpian America vs. The World?

The thing about irony is that someone needs to believe in what is being asserted. This is just meaningless rhetoric. Covfefe!
The Declaration of Independence called for "a decent respect to the opinions of mankind."  It is in the first paragraph but Trump never read that far.

Trump speaks, the world laughs.

It's so easy to destroy things. I guess that is why Trump is so good at it.

I wish that we could package Trump, and his devout followers, and send them off the globe. They could create their own world, where they would:
- Pray while shooting one another over minor disputes
- Men would be men and women would be nervous
- The sky and water would reek, but somebody in Trump
World would make millions off of dirty energy
- Citizens would be blessed with two jobs each, at least, to
support the oligarchy
- Arms dealers would make trillions
- Forced prayer and forced births would be the norm
- Hopefully no one would be allowed out, as well as in

The rest of us on Earth could then go forward, to great things, while the squabbling, simple minded, self-centered theocracy of Trump World implodes.
Dangerous words from POTUS about international institutions not having any legitimacy. It’s really a shame he speaks for us.
He's a Uniter! (And a divider!)
Actually Brazil speaks first because the first GA president, Oswaldo Aranha, played an important role in the creation of Israel.

The world laughs at Trump - it would bring me great joy to see his balloon busted but unfortunately it's tethered to us all as well - thus, the world is laughing at us.

His hopelessly delusional mind will likely only see more allies turned "traitor" and will continue to rub shoulders with despots, dictators deplorables.
Remember the good old days, when we had an intelligent, eloquent and yes, elegant President ???  Seems like decades ago.    SAD.    Vote in November.
Where’s the bit when the audience laughed at his boast about achieving more than any other administration ever?
I would like to thank the UN for giving Trump the greeting they gave him, we here in the United States know he's a laugh a minute, now thanks to you the rest of the world knows that too.
An important, yet mess of an organization.

A column cries out to be written explaining why this particular silliness spouted at this time and upon this world stage to be met with this laughter.  One theory--refusing to pay for "social entitlements" at home and abroad covers the fact that the money that would have sponsored society-building programs has already gone to the rich, leaving a vast empty space in the cookie jar, something like a bald spot one tries in vain to cover as the wind blows away all pretense.

Three to ten is an insufficiently robust signal and fails to satisfy the "blind" justice most women seek. Sadly Cosby will survive this brief interlude unrepentant in effect giving the finger to the system which he successfully outmaneuvered throughout his life. His wife is likely a co-conspirator. She's defiant in her defense of criminal behavior, still.
If Iran doesn't want criticism of  its nation then the hypocrites and psychopaths should stop writing, down with the USA, on the side of their military parade vehicles in Iran.
I am so disgusted with this administration and the piece of trash leading it. Something needs to be done already because this is not funny anymore-it never was.

Trump says that the leaders of Iran “do not respect their neighbors or borders or the sovereign rights of nations”.... To anyone with a basic understanding of Middle East history since the 20th century, this statement is a ludicrous farce coming from the U.S.A.

Who would believe in trump when he said in almost two years he has accomplishes so much no one in History of United States have ever done that.

The crowd roared back in laughter.

Trump made a mockery of an institution( United Nations)  which deserves what it got. It is corrupt, toothless and irrelevant in our present world. They  have done nothing nor did they stop anything. I think we should move it out of NYC. That would save millions of dollars which we can use to provide to some of the Ebola rescue teams in Africa. Just imagine the cost of security for the past few days! That is enough to help with emerging crisis in Africa.

Our PM talked to Trump about tariffs on NZ
www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/367283/pm-has-brief-talk-on-tarrifs-wit...
His speech was about promoting patriotism over globalism. You can have both and that's why our PM got voted in as our new PM, as in globalisation you have to compromise and see that other sovereign nations are also looking to protect their nation and retain their sovereignty from the tentacles of big business and pharmaceutical companies that put life saving drugs out of the reach of their citizens. This PM is looking out for NZ citizens. It's give and take in trade deals. Even Canada is looking elsewhere for global trade deals and is still in the TPP.

22 items suspended from original TPP deal

POTUS called out our enemies: Iran and Venezuela. what about those other enemies which have attacked democracies and their institutions....i.e., cyber attacks, poisoning and election meddling throughout the world including US. Specifically I refer to
Russia, to name one. Why not mention them, Mr. Trump.
I've never been so ashamed of my nation and president in my lifetime.

Being laughed at after he repeated his ridiculous, unfounded claims about his amazing achievements compared to previous administrations in less than two years (it feels a lot more!), tells you all you need to know about the reputation the US had around the world. Being held in contempt by most other countries is not a position that the US is used to occupying.

Thanks to Trump, the country has largely alienated its allies, abandoned its position as a champion of free trade and can no longer be credibly considered “Leader of the free world “.

So yes, it’s fair to say that Trump has indeed accomplished much. Sadly what he has achieved has almost entirely destroyed the reputation of the US, trashed its former leadership position in so many areas. It will take years (decades) to recover from this, if indeed it is possible to do so - in another three years it may be too late.
Steven Colbert could give a better speech and get even more laughs!

The postwar order has not changed because of wolves (plural). It changed because of Trump aided and abetted by a complicit Republican party.

Putin is a wolf, but the Soviet Union / Russia has, with few exceptions, always been run by wolves.

Your other examples: Orban, Duterte and Erdogan may share a wolfish mentality. But when has Hungary, the Philippines, or Turkey ever been a key factor in the postwar order? A protector of democracy?

The postwar order was damaged, perhaps irreparably when your party nominated and ignorant authoritarian and 63 million electoral college advantaged voters elected him.

So now we have a president who does not much believe in democracy, the rule of law, or as it turns out, facts, expertise, and integrity.

And your party's leaders are just fine with it and are actively complicit in dismantling the postwar order by there refusal to constrain this president in any way.

So if you want 'to find ways to restore social trust" I suggest you start by finding a way to convince Americans who still believe in democracy and the rule of law, that the Republican party shares that belief and is willing to protect it

I see no evidence that they do. And I do not trust them. At this point, I just hope the pro democracy side can out vote them.

There is much to like about this thoughtful piece. But when Brooks writes that conservatives became "so besotted with the power of the market that they forgot what capitalism is like when it's not balanced by strong communities," he seems to be repeating the theme he goes to so often -- that in the main it is strong personal relationships and local institutions like faith-based communities that have made our country great. I am all for strong personal relationships and institutions that help us to see beyond ourselves and consider a greater good, but it is not the disappearance of community that has sent us on a downward spiral. It is the debasement of government and regulation that has destroyed community.

Is it really untrammeled meritocracy that divides societies between the fittest and the rest, or is it untrammeled ruthlessness? I have no doubt that the arrogance and narrow vision of some the the highly-educated in our society is a problem, but the bigger problem is the mindset that imagines regulations are simply obstacles to progress. Usurious interest rates, slave wages, environmental pollution and health care and quality education only for the rich, are what we can expect when regulations disappear. Community doesn't just happen; it is built. Shared laws are a big part of what creates the shared values that can then lead to the loyalty and affection Brooks posits.

I disagree with your emphasis on regulation.

It is overregulation that has brought us Trump. People were suffocating under the liberal yoke.

You have to broaden your perspective. You are looking at government as a speedboat, zigzagging the waters and running over individuals who are just considered collateral damage.

I look at government as a supertanker. Steady on course, it sets the general rules of where the country wants to go, without trying to micromanage the people. That set of overarching rules has served us well, but it broke down with the advent of computers, where any bureaucrat with a stroke of a button can create real life hardships for anyone. If you are threatened every day with draconian penalties for not following the master's myriad petty rules, people rebel.

Hence, the government should issue as few specific rules as possible, concentrate on overarching ones, like environmental protection, energy, climate change, health care and social security and leave bathroom policies and wedding cake baking to the strong communities.

We have functioned very well for a long time living by this simple set of rules, before liberal intolerance upset the apple cart and now it has started careening off the road.
Read The Audacity of Hope.  Then read The Art of the Deal.  You now have an idea of how the rules have changed.

"Progressives were so besotted with their own educated-class expertise that they concentrated power upward and away from the people at the same time that technology was pushing power downward and toward the people. "

You nailed it. Deliberately I sent my kids to a highschool that has a 40% share of students with an immigration background, some of them refuges. I believe in a trickle down effect when it comes to education and a trickle up effect when égalité and fraternité, columns of our society, need some nurturing.

The reason for the bitter decline of democracies we experience the last 2 years is the bad job we did decades long by not selling our best product passionately enough to everyone: education.

Trump, Organ, Erdogan these wrecking balls of democracy and christian, western values were only voted in because of the lack of education of the electorate. Education is not a 100% shield against fooleries but can contain the biggest errors.

Progressives (like myself) tend to believe that the 'little man' needs guidance and leadership. But what the 'little man' really needs is education. That would make him strong and independent, would make him great, and foster the values of Enlightenment America and Europe are build upon. We missed that and pay now the price.

If there is someone to blame for the Trumpian age it would be the educated progressives and conservatives who sent their children to private schools.

I agree that Trump would like to be a wolf, but he's obviously taking his orders from Putin, so Trump is more like the wolf cub.  Putin is the alpha wolf, and as Trump toddles about and destroys Western alliances, Papa Wolf praises him, and says, "That's a good cub. Papa is very proud of you."
Wolves are nicer than that- they know how to cooperate. I think 'weasels' is more accurate.

Mr. Brooks, here you accurately describe the state of play--the breakdown of social trust--but your fealty to parity arguments always prevents you from getting to the nub of the matter: Republicans are the problem, and therefore the solution. They are the extremists and nihilists today. Democrats have made mistakes, but they are not the ones trying to blow up the rule based systems.

Therefore, Mr. Brooks, describe the world as it is, rather than how you want it to be to suit your serial moralizing. These Republicans--like all extremists--must be contained until they are defeated or return to the center-right.

It's not clear that Trump plays by any rules. He is not one to study the game ahead of the meet or to abide by traditional norms.

In short, Donald Trump is at best ill-suited and unprepared, and at worst, dangerously, disastrously ignorant.

And to boot, he is unprincipled.

I beg to differ Mr. Brooks - Donald Trump is the most ignorant and divisive leader we have ever seen, certainly in modern times, but I suspect throughout our brief history.  He is doing nothing for the people he serves -- his is all about serving himself and his narcissism.  He's all about dividing and conquering -- the worst president certainly, but is he human -- I really have my doubts.  His mental state is for one to feel sorry for him, but that's not possible -- he's a hateful man who is taking great pleasure and feeding his ego on the backs of the people he serves.

Two Wolves

One evening an old Cherokee told his grandson about a battle that goes on inside people.

He said, “My son, the battle is between two wolves inside us all.

“One is Evil – It is anger, envy, jealousy, sorrow, regret, greed, arrogance, self-pity, guilt, resentment, inferiority, lies, false pride, superiority, and ego.

“The other is Good – It is joy, peace, love, hope, serenity, humility, kindness, benevolence, empathy, generosity, truth, compassion and faith.”

The grandson thought about it for a minute and then asked his grandfather: “Which wolf wins?”

The old Cherokee simply replied, “The one you feed.”

Why wouldn't Donald Trump be distrustful of others?  When you've lied, cheated, and scammed people all your life as he has, I would suspect you're conditioned to believe that everyone else thinks and operates the same way.  A perfectly rational position for an extreme narcissist.

Let's be clear and cut out the verbiage.  Trump is a wannabe dictator who is doing everything in his power to become an actual dictator.  The Republican Party is completely dead; there is only the party of Trump--which is just what Trump wants.  It's not a new world; it's an age old world of people who want a better world and the world of demagogues and dictators and deplorables who hear no evil and see no evil but who are always there to support evil.

Why are authoritarian governments whether of the left or right having such success in the world today, or if not success (can we really call authoritarianism success?) are at least being considered as alternatives to democracy?

The answer seems plain if horrifying to me. Human beings period, our species, has been blowing it politically, culturally and economically since the end of WW2 belief that a fair and just worldwide democratic system can come into being; which is to say the idea was we do not have to be like Nazi Germany or Stalin's Soviet Socialist Republic or Imperial Japan or the like but that we can all integrate gradually toward democracy (continuation of Wilsonian ideas), but our human greed, our foolishness, our out of control breeding and so much else is just leading to unwieldy and diverse masses crying out for leaders and a race to the bottom in attempt to gain power.

The fact is we are being faced with the horrible truth that we, you and I, are really not that much better than Hitler or Stalin and their followers, that all it takes is just to get the cities a little more crowded and confused, to make political and economic life and bureaucracy a little more confused and frustrating, to have the traffic snarl, and people will just sink down to their worst selves, will wonder why they have to put up with other people. We've been blowing human development. Now enters the masters of sheer crowd control, the whip hand in our face. Who can make a citizenry?

Mr. Brooks, do you not even begin to realize the hypocrisy inherent in your silly veneration of the G7 as a chummy, egalitarian expression of brotherly love? The G7 is perhaps the most extreme example of an elite organization imaginable. To be a member, a country has to be one of the 7 richest on the planet. That's just too bad for the 90% of the world's population that is not represented in this group. That Trump thumbed his nose at this elitist claptrap should be celebrated.

Good, and scary, point. Unfortunately, there is no one on the left/progressive horizon who can rhetorically challenge this. For the past 30 years, the left has had only two messages: (1) Diversity and inversion of every past oppression, which, though noble, has provided easy, lazy talking points while sucking up the oxygen for any other thought; and (2) free money for everybody, which is a denial of economic science on par with denial of climate or evolutionary science. When faced with the authoritarian threat that is Trump, the left was shocked to learn that these two messages had never convinced most of the country and certainly won't do that now. But the left has nothing else.

The postwar order has not changed because of wolves (plural). It changed because of Trump aided and abetted by a complicit Republican party.

Putin is a wolf, but the Soviet Union / Russia has, with few exceptions, always been run by wolves.

Your other examples: Orban, Duterte and Erdogan may share a wolfish mentality. But when has Hungary, the Philippines, or Turkey ever been a key factor in the postwar order? A protector of democracy?

The postwar order was damaged, perhaps irreparably when your party nominated and ignorant authoritarian and 63 million electoral college advantaged voters elected him.

So now we have a president who does not much believe in democracy, the rule of law, or as it turns out, facts, expertise, and integrity.

And your party's leaders are just fine with it and are actively complicit in dismantling the postwar order by there refusal to constrain this president in any way.

So if you want 'to find ways to restore social trust" I suggest you start by finding a way to convince Americans who still believe in democracy and the rule of law, that the Republican party shares that belief and is willing to protect it

I see no evidence that they do. And I do not trust them. At this point, I just hope the pro democracy side can out vote them.

There is much to like about this thoughtful piece. But when Brooks writes that conservatives became "so besotted with the power of the market that they forgot what capitalism is like when it's not balanced by strong communities," he seems to be repeating the theme he goes to so often -- that in the main it is strong personal relationships and local institutions like faith-based communities that have made our country great. I am all for strong personal relationships and institutions that help us to see beyond ourselves and consider a greater good, but it is not the disappearance of community that has sent us on a downward spiral. It is the debasement of government and regulation that has destroyed community.

Is it really untrammeled meritocracy that divides societies between the fittest and the rest, or is it untrammeled ruthlessness? I have no doubt that the arrogance and narrow vision of some the the highly-educated in our society is a problem, but the bigger problem is the mindset that imagines regulations are simply obstacles to progress. Usurious interest rates, slave wages, environmental pollution and health care and quality education only for the rich, are what we can expect when regulations disappear. Community doesn't just happen; it is built. Shared laws are a big part of what creates the shared values that can then lead to the loyalty and affection Brooks posits.

I disagree with your emphasis on regulation.

It is overregulation that has brought us Trump. People were suffocating under the liberal yoke.

You have to broaden your perspective. You are looking at government as a speedboat, zigzagging the waters and running over individuals who are just considered collateral damage.

I look at government as a supertanker. Steady on course, it sets the general rules of where the country wants to go, without trying to micromanage the people. But the left has nothing else.

I think it is sentimental folly to expect much in the way of 'remains' to be repatriated.

The US dropped more ordinance on N. Korea than they did in the whole Pacific (including Japan) in WWII. The place was bombed to smithereens, anywhere from 10 - 25% of the population was killed. They didn't have any time for marking the graves of the enemy, they had too many of their own to bury.

I understand that families would like to know what happened, but it is highly unlikely that is going to happen, nobody knows in most cases by now.

This is more distraction.

For the families of MIA American military like Lt. Harold Downes, Jr. this is wonderful news. It is important to all Americans who feel relief by bringing home the bodies of our dead for proper burial and memory.

Thank you NYT for the link to the Detail Rand Report from 1994. My uncle was captured November 30, 1950. It helped to fill in some of the pieces regarding my uncles capture. He had just turned 19 years old. He was a Corporal, Headquarters Company, 2nd Combat Engineers Battalion, 2nd Infantry Division, 8th Army. The Combat Engineers with their heavy equipment were assigned as a rear guard as the 2nd Infantry Division retreated from Ch’ongch’on River thru Kunu Ri to Sunchon. The Eighth Army suffered s major defeat and General Keiser was retired.

93% of those captured (5,961) and 99% of POW’s who died while prisoners (2,638) were captured and died in the first 10 months of the war. My Uncle survived the death march but perished from wounds and starvation in February of 1951.

Reading this report brings more clarity to the bits and pieces that we have been told to us during numerous updates by the DOD and DPAA. Lot’s of money and effort has been made over the last 65 years to identify and retrieve remains. Because of how and where the remains were buried and handled identification has and will remain elusive. I do not think this will change should North Korea give unlimited access to DPAA. Science and maternal DNA has had limited success identifying remains that have been in the governments possession since 1954. My mother is 92 and I am 62. It’s time we have a national day of morning and burial (without remains) and close the book on the POW/MIA of the Korean War.

Wait a minute, let's not ignore what President Trump said in his glowing admiration of the butcher Kim Jong Un, he said he is already sending back all the hero's and taken credit for it already happening, he also said the parents of Korean War MIA were begging him during the campaign to get back their sons......someone better point out that those parent would be 105 to 115 years of age; this is an obvious lie Trump is spreading an he needs to be called out on it by not only the media, but VFW Organizations throughout the country.
Who is less likely to keep the promises made: the country with the dangerous, autocratic leader who is well known for his lying, or North Korea?

This "promise" made during the Singapore summit is extraordinarily low-hanging fruit. Returning the remains of US soldiers who perished in the Korean War 65 years ago is hardly a "win" for Trump, who got little else from the DPRK except vague promises of denuclearization at some yet to be determined date. What Trump gave away included a cessation of joint military exercises between the US and ROK, a declaration that the regime is no longer a nuclear threat 9which it still is) and no systems in place to verify if the North Koreans will actually holding up any of the promises they made to the US. Oh, they got a great picture of Trump saluting one of their generals, which will make for terrific propaganda.

I have a first cousin who was shot down over North Korea on May 12, 1952, as flight leader on a bombing raid, a first lieutenant in the Air Force and a West Point graduate, class of 1950.  Others in the flight saw his plane go down but did not see him eject or a parachute.  They circled the location where his jet went down and was burning.  They saw no sign of life and reported they believed he have been killed in action.  He was hit in the tail by anti-aircraft fire as he pulled up after a dive.  He could not be reached by radio and is suspected of having been hit himself and hopefully killed instantly.  I would hate to think what would have happened if he had been captured.  I met Billy when I was 7 years old and I remember him well.  I am still grieving... never gotten over his death.  I have not expected his remains to be recovered but the Air Force has maintained regular contact with next of kin of their downed pilots.

That families had loved ones die in this conflict is tragic and heart-wrenching. My sympathy goes out to them.

That being said, they are dead and like many who die during a war their remains will never be recovered. And in this case who are the remains being returned to? Not the parents. Siblings?
To claim this as a major breakthrough, with all the problems of the living, is ridiculous.
Golly, I am not one of Trumps "people"

I deeply sympathize with the families.

Is it correct that the Korean government charges the US one million dollars for releasing each soldier's remains? I heard this earlier in the week on the news.

COME ON NYT's...I wish this article had more facts and was more honest with the entire process of repatriation of US Service remains in North Korea.  To say the words "North Koreans turned over the remains" is a very dishonest sentence.  According to Keith Harman of National Director of Veterans of Foreign Wars, the US government pays up to $1 million dollars PER US service Members remains.  North Korea has turned the repatriation of remains into a profit center and to lazily omit this fact is a shame.  I am 100% for returning the remains and giving families closure, but let's not omit the shameful way in which it's being done...
This would be a fantastic and worthy result of President Trump's meeting.  I hope NYT libs can admit this.

We were never told the truth when it came to MIA's and POW's from Vietnam.   Our own government found it too 'inconvenient' to admit that men were left behind (and there is more than enough proof of this).  Do we really expect any 'inconvenient' truths to come out of North Korea - or will we settle for a few bones?

The fact that the Korean missing are long dead I hardly believe the trump claims that thousands of parents begged him to retrieve the remains of their sons. The average parent would need to be at least 100 years old.
Donald Trump claimed that "thousands of parents "of the Korean War KIA "begged him" to get the remains back. Since the conflict ended 65 years ago, they must have contacted him during a seance.

Clinton gave the North Koreans billions of dollars which they used to secretly continue their nuclear weapons programs.

Not one American soldier's remains were returned by NK before Trump despite billions in aid under Clinton. What did Bush and Obama do about North Korea? Why weren't serious sanctions leveled against North Korea by Bush or Obama?

Do you think they will return the true remains?
Ten years ago, North Korea told her family that Megumi Yokota, one of the most famous abduction victims, died and sent her remains. But Megumi's DNA was not found and half of it was dog bone.

My sympathies to the MIA's families.

But Trump's claim that the Korean vets' parents had been clamoring for this is patently stupid.

The average Korean vet is 87 years old.

Bringing home the remains of Korean war dead will be like a big jigsaw puzzle. For sure there are plenty of skeletons, but sorting lout who is who will be a nightmare. All KJU has to is crate up a bunch of bones and Trump will declare success.
Perhaps they'll also be able to recover evidence of yet another of America's great unsolved war mysteries ---- the location and remains of Donald Trump's mysterious 'bone spurs'.

THE TRUMP AND KIM SHOW

Break out the Nobels, mint up the medals! Peace in our time! Who’da thought? Yes, well

Blame in on the Bossanova but, honestly, Trump the great peacemaker? With the certifiable Bolton at his elbow? And all the threats and bluster up to now vanish as if they’d never been and Trump gets the America’s Got Talent Golden Buzzer superpass to sainthood?

So why do I get this uneasy feeling that we’ve all been here before? That Trump’s new paint job, covering over all the grossness, the lying, the stealing, the self interest, the chicanery might have more than a little bit to do with the mid terms and the 2020 dogfight. And Kim, brutal dictator now has no need of elevators to stand tall in front of his adoring (they better!) flock.

Call me paranoid, jaundiced) but isn’t a more likely scenario that this is just another snowjob exercise to misdirect and reprogram the masses? And that the likely reason, given America’s publicly and repeatedly stated objective of invading seven nations, is to set aside North Korea for a later dance and bring forward the invasion/destruction, oops, sorry, liberation of Iran on the grounds of their non-compliance to their nuclear deal. And if Trump, the newly arisen peacemaker, says it’s so … well, so it must be. He wouldn’t lie to you, would he? And through it all, the multibillion criminal and fraudulent armaments trade continues to destroy our world. But, hey … eggs and omelettes … business is business.

Quote of the day - so far.

This from the National Embarrassment, who wants Americans to behave toward him as North Koreans behave toward Kim.

Yes, he actually said this.

“Hey, he is the head of a country and I mean he is the strong head,” Trump said to Fox News on Friday. “Don’t let anyone think anything different. He speaks and his people sit up at attention. I want my people to do the same.”

it's a good chance to construct trusty relationship between the hostile nations, and it was a needed procedure to be preceded to end the Korean War officially.

so many critics and media harshly attacked the summit agreement for not including so-called 'CVID', but I think the excavation clause should get enough credit for moderating the animosity between both North Koreans and Americans.

no trust, no deal. the United States and North Korea need to trust each other, first. the past failed agreements were all the results of lack of trust.

During the Korean War Hundreds of U.S. Marines were buried in mass graves in North Korea at the Chosin Reservoir where they died fighting the Chinese Communists. We should be given access to those burial sites so that those Marine bodies could be returned home.
Never thought I'd say it, but I guess if you can trust Trump and the White House you should have no problem trusting the North Koreans.

I think it is sentimental folly to expect much in the way of 'remains' to be repatriated.

To say the words "North Koreans turned over the remains" is a very dishonest sentence. North Korea has turned the repatriation of remains into a profit center and to lazily omit this fact is a shame.  I am 100% for returning the remains and giving families closure, but let's not omit the shameful way in which it's being done...
This would be a fantastic and worthy result of President Trump's meeting.  I hope NYT libs can admit this.

We were never told the truth when it came to MIA's and POW's from Vietnam. The fact that the Korean missing are long dead I hardly believe the trump claims that thousands of parents begged him to retrieve the remains of their sons. The average parent would need to be at least 100 years old.
Donald Trump claimed that "thousands of parents "of the Korean War KIA "begged him" to get the remains back. Since the conflict ended 65 years ago, they must have contacted him during a seance.

Clinton gave the North Koreans billions of dollars which they used to secretly continue their nuclear weapons programs.

Not one American soldier's remains were returned by NK before Trump despite billions in aid under Clinton. What did Bush and Obama do about North Korea? Why weren't serious sanctions leveled against North Korea by Bush or Obama?

My sympathies to the MIA's families.

But Trump's claim that the Korean vets' parents had been clamoring for this is patently stupid.

The average Korean vet is 87 years old.

Break out the Nobels, mint up the medals! Peace in our time! Who’da thought? Yes, well

So why do I get this uneasy feeling that we’ve all been here before? That Trump’s new paint job, covering over all the grossness, the lying, the stealing, the self interest, the chicanery might have more than a little bit to do with the mid terms and the 2020 dogfight. Quote of the day - so far.

This from the National Embarrassment, who wants Americans to behave toward him as North Koreans behave toward Kim.

Yes, he actually said this.

“Hey, he is the head of a country and I mean he is the strong head,” Trump said to Fox News on Friday. “Don’t let anyone think anything different. He speaks and his people sit up at attention. I want my people to do the same.”

it's a good chance to construct trusty relationship between the hostile nations, and it was a needed procedure to be preceded to end the Korean War officially.

so many critics and media harshly attacked the summit agreement for not including so-called 'CVID', but I think the excavation clause should get enough credit for moderating the animosity between both North Koreans and Americans.

no trust, no deal. the United States and North Korea need to trust each other, first. the past failed agreements were all the results of lack of trust.

During the Korean War Hundreds of U.S. Marines were buried in mass graves in North Korea at the Chosin Reservoir where they died fighting the Chinese Communists. We should be given access to those burial sites so that those Marine bodies could be returned home.
Never thought I'd say it, but I guess if you can trust Trump and the White House you should have no problem trusting the North Koreans.

I think it is sentimental folly to expect much in the way of 'remains' to be repatriated.

The US dropped more ordinance on N. Korea than they did in the whole Pacific (including Japan) in WWII. The place was bombed to smithereens, anywhere from 10 - 25% of the population was killed. They didn't have any time for marking the graves of the enemy, they had too many of their own to bury.

I understand that families would like to know what happened, but it is highly unlikely that is going to happen, nobody knows in most cases by now.

This is more distraction.

For the families of MIA American military like Lt. Harold Downes, Jr. this is wonderful news. It is important to all Americans who feel relief by bringing home the bodies of our dead for proper burial and memory.

Thank you NYT for the link to the Detail Rand Report from 1994. My uncle was captured November 30, 1950. It helped to fill in some of the pieces regarding my uncles capture. He had just turned 19 years old. He was a Corporal, Headquarters Company, 2nd Combat Engineers Battalion, 2nd Infantry Division, 8th Army. The Combat Engineers with their heavy equipment were assigned as a rear guard as the 2nd Infantry Division retreated from Ch’ongch’on River thru Kunu Ri to Sunchon. The Eighth Army suffered s major defeat and General Keiser was retired.

93% of those captured (5,961) and 99% of POW’s who died while prisoners (2,638) were captured and died in the first 10 months of the war. My Uncle survived the death march but perished from wounds and starvation in February of 1951.

Reading this report brings more clarity to the bits and pieces that we have been told to us during numerous updates by the DOD and DPAA. Lot’s of money and effort has been made over the last 65 years to identify and retrieve remains. Because of how and where the remains were buried and handled identification has and will remain elusive. I do not think this will change should North Korea give unlimited access to DPAA. Science and maternal DNA has had limited success identifying remains that have been in the governments possession since 1954. My mother is 92 and I am 62. It’s time we have a national day of morning and burial (without remains) and close the book on the POW/MIA of the Korean War.

Wait a minute, let's not ignore what President Trump said in his glowing admiration of the butcher Kim Jong Un, he said he is already sending back all the hero's and taken credit for it already happening, he also said the parents of Korean War MIA were begging him during the campaign to get back their sons......someone better point out that those parent would be 105 to 115 years of age; this is an obvious lie Trump is spreading an he needs to be called out on it by not only the media, but VFW Organizations throughout the country.
Who is less likely to keep the promises made: the country with the dangerous, autocratic leader who is well known for his lying, or North Korea?

This "promise" made during the Singapore summit is extraordinarily low-hanging fruit. Returning the remains of US soldiers who perished in the Korean War 65 years ago is hardly a "win" for Trump, who got little else from the DPRK except vague promises of denuclearization at some yet to be determined date. What Trump gave away included a cessation of joint military exercises between the US and ROK, a declaration that the regime is no longer a nuclear threat 9which it still is) and no systems in place to verify if the North Koreans will actually holding up any of the promises they made to the US. Oh, they got a great picture of Trump saluting one of their generals, which will make for terrific propaganda.

I have a first cousin who was shot down over North Korea on May 12, 1952, as flight leader on a bombing raid, a first lieutenant in the Air Force and a West Point graduate, class of 1950.  Others in the flight saw his plane go down but did not see him eject or a parachute.  They circled the location where his jet went down and was burning.  They saw no sign of life and reported they believed he have been killed in action.  He was hit in the tail by anti-aircraft fire as he pulled up after a dive.  He could not be reached by radio and is suspected of having been hit himself and hopefully killed instantly.  I would hate to think what would have happened if he had been captured.  I met Billy when I was 7 years old and I remember him well.  I am still grieving... never gotten over his death.  I have not expected his remains to be recovered but the Air Force has maintained regular contact with next of kin of their downed pilots.

That families had loved ones die in this conflict is tragic and heart-wrenching. My sympathy goes out to them.

That being said, they are dead and like many who die during a war their remains will never be recovered. And in this case who are the remains being returned to? Not the parents. Siblings?
To claim this as a major breakthrough, with all the problems of the living, is ridiculous.

I personally don't have a problem with world leaders meeting one another. What I do have a problem with is the doormat diplomacy with illiberal regimes. This administration seems to hold to the line that we should save our harshest criticism for our allies, while taking a more hand in glove approach with our adversaries. This is, frankly, backwards.

Trump calls the EU a "foe."

At the same time, he "hadn't thought about" asking Russia to turn over the indicted hackers.

He calls "much of the media" an "enemy of the people."

He states that he has "low expectations "of his meeting with Putin.

He brags that the RNC computers were better than the DNC's, and gloats that they were hacked.

And he blames the hacking on Pres Obama for being "weak on Russia," but meanwhile he works to undermine the investigation into it.

Of course I'm disgusted by Trump.

But honestly, at this point I'm more disgusted by the Republicans who let him get away with destroying our country and refuse to speak out against Trump's insanity. He's already given Putin a mulligan for interfering in our election; what's he going to concede to him when they meet behind closed doors?

They're all more interested in excoriating Comey and Strzok and McCabe than they are about figuring out how Russia hacked our election, and working to prevent it from happening again. To them, attacking fellow Americans is their way of "winning."

Hillary Clinton was right: They really are deplorable.

John McCain, along with some Democratic Senators, is right: Trump should not meet with Putin, since he is not prepared to defend the United States against Russian election meddling.
A hostile action against our country elicits, at best, a shrug from Trump - and has even been dismissed by him.
If Trump and Putin meet, both will represent Russia's interests.

Americans, at least those whose patriotism has not been occluded by the Republican/Fox information bubble, know that Trump lies at the rate of roughly 7X per hour of discourse and in virtually every tweet that he emits. His recent trips to meet Kim, attend NATO and the G7, have exposed his deceitfulness to the world. With no outside observers to observe his meeting with Putin, he will be free to make up whatever he wants about the outcome. Few, however, will believe Trump's account so it is a foregone, but ironic, conclusion that Putin will have the upper hand in credibility. Once again the Trump kleptocracy will put the USA at a distinct disadvantage.

It is truly embarrassing to see our POTUS humiliating our Country like this. He has insulted our friends and now embraces a man who will indeed play him like a puppet.  Putin is knowledgeable about the world and as a former KGB agent knows the psychology of playing the fool he is about to meet. I only pray that enough GOP Lawmakers care more about our country than using Putin's puppet to further their own personal goals.

"But Mr. Trump, who routinely attacks European leaders and has started a trade war with some of America’s closest allies, is now effectively doing the job for him."

Isn't that why you blackmail someone? So they do what you want them to do...

The only thing that amazes me is that there are still so many Republicans who think Trump's actions are not dictated from Moscow. The fact that the American President is having a private meeting with the autocratic ruler who hacked our election is beyond contemptible.

Putin is putting the world on notice that he owns the American President, Donald J. Trump.

Republicans who fail to defend our elections and the rule of law are aiding and abetting treason.

Trump will have his summit with Putin because he has much to personally lose if he doesn’t. This is not a meeting between the leaders of two opposing blocs. If it was, it would have been cancelled as unviable and inappropriate at a time when it appears inescapable that Russia has unleashed deadly nerve toxins loose on America’s staunchest ally, murdering one of its citizens, desperately wounding three other people. Russia would have been roundly punished for the breathtaking mendacity towards the West, actively engaging in acts of social sabotage in meddling with America’s democracy and other unforgivable transgressions towards other countries. Rather, this is the puppeteer forcing Pinocchio to dance.

Trump and Putin will meet privately and Trump will emerge saying, “Putin has denied all of these acts, and I believe him,” and, for a moment a band aid will be placed on a gaping wound. However, band aid solutions are hardly permanent: both men are increasingly beleaguered, even as Trump metes out chaos in the EU and NATO, even as Putin hosts the World Cup, riding high in front of his people. This charade of an international order is unravelling as the monumentally criminal enterprise that it is.

I am so glad the authors put focus on Trump's treatment of the UK, Germany and Canada. It's when one looks at how he is treating our allies that one sees how bizarre is Trump's treatment of Putin and Russia. The weakening and potential breaking apart of NATO stands to betray the US into the hands of its enemies. Trump's contradictory positions (bashes May one day, loves her the next; bashes NATO one day, supports it the next) has been attributed by some to the push and pull between Trump and his advisors; others have said he must be schizophrenic. I believe that we are seeing a man torn between what is demanded of him to satisfy Putin's leverage over him, and what is demanded of him to make some appearance of being the US President.  It appears he is being veritably ripped into two people by trying to serve two masters. And the quoted analyst, Vladimir Frolov, is sooo right, that "If Trump says, ‘Let bygones be bygones because we have a world to run,’ that is essentially what Moscow needs from this.” Because it will mean that no matter how much the public protests, no matter how much his advisors struggle to keep him from selling out the nation, no matter Mueller's investigation or the warnings of national security officials, the process of selling out to Putin is moving inexorably ahead, and in the process, turning the US into an autocracy.

From the beginning of his real estate career, Trump has always financed his projects...

After multiple financial disasters and four bankruptcies in the 80s and 90s (after which American banks refused to continue funding his follies), he somehow continued to acquire hundreds of millions of dollars with which to pursue his projects...

How?

In 2008, Donald Jr. told investors in Moscow that “Russians make up a pretty disproportionate cross-section of a lot of our assets,” while his other son, Eric, reportedly told a golf reporter in 2014 that the Trump Organization was able to expand during the financial crisis because “We don’t rely on American banks. We have all the funding we need out of Russia.”

In the last few years, Trump has paid many hundreds of millions in CASH for three golf courses in Scotland and Ireland.... Three golf courses that lose tens of millions of dollars every year. Additionally, records show that Trump has sold multiple American properties to Russian oligarchs for amounts that far exceed property values...

If this smells of money laundering it is because no other explanation makes sense.

At this point, there is no way Trump should be permitted to meet with Putin behind closed doors without other Americans present in the room.

Trump is a proven serial liar who ALWAYS puts his interests first...

Mr Mueller, if you have enough evidence for even a single charge, file it NOW...

The hour of our Democracy is growing late.

Could it be as simple as this: that Trump sees “stability” and investment potential in places like Russia, China, and even North Korea — think of all those pristine beaches! — and all that untapped wealth.

This may be a backward way to “follow the money” but in Trump’s case that may be what we’re looking at.

"...Mr. Maduro’s false claim that the collapse of his country is because of a United States-led conspiracy..."

How can these authors make this claim so easily? Methinks reality will disprove their assertion...

Unlike Trump and ignoro-patriots,  Maduro actually knows US military and US intelligence history in Latin America: bloody, repeatedly subversive of democracy and elections, kleptocratic, and impoverishing. History doesn´t go away even when a country´s own press and people don´t know it and lament a prior purity that never existed, but was handled more secretively and more diplomatically.

1) Trump hates brown people
2) The Right Wing Noise Machine has successfully turned Venezuela into the newest buzzword for "Socialism". That millions are going hungry there is one of the greatest things to happen for conservatives in the US.

So he gains nothing in aiding them and has everything gain in joining in the chorus against them.
Well, of course.  White Dictators are great men who should be emulated.  Brown dictators are criminals and tyrants who must be removed.

Mr. Trump is living in the '70s. Back then, according to the be-nighted wisdom of that decade, Latin America was a "mess",  "Puerto Ricans" were all trouble-makers. If you look back in the archives of the Daily News or the Post these prejudicial stereotypes will jump out at you. Trump didn't read the Times.
Evidently, based on migration patterns, Latin Americans must love Trump.
Uhhhh, skin color?
Best Answer: hatred of latinamericans.
Simple: the word "maduro" means "dark" (as in tobacco leaves) and the man is an Hispanic, which means the same to Trump as the term "Untermensch" (sub-human) meant to Nazis.

Ok.

I am Venezuelan. I have been watching this train wreck from the US for 20 years. You have to go back to the beginning to understand why not Maduro. If you are too impatient for the punchline, I will short cut it for you. Trump has the respect for Maduro that one mistress has for another. They are both bought and paid for by the same john.

To understand Maduro, you have to go back to the early 00s, when Chavez discovered Fidel, who in turn introduced him to the Russians. If you've been following Venezuelan politics, as I have, you would know about the flow into Venezuela of all manners of Russian influence: from missiles, to Uzis, to money, to influence, to tactics, to other arms, to ideas.....

In fact, when the Ukraine was burning in 2014, so was Venezuela and at the time, the language and tactics being used to repress where strikingly specifically SIMILAR.

Why Venezuela? Location and oil. Putin rightly understood years ago that Venezuela had a strategic relationship to the US via its oil production and an awesome location from which to wreak havoc.

For Putin, Maduro is the useful idiot that came after Chavez. In fact, sometimes he is a bit uppity so he allows Trump to do the occasional smack down to keep him in place.

If Trump proceeds unimpeded, and if Rosfnet decides it needs to squeeze the lemon harder, I could force a military interaction or two.....enough to strike a blow across the face, but nothing more.

Thanks, Tom Brennan.  That's one more<U+2202><U+2202> "socialist" (or "communist") dictator that Trump doesn't approve.  "Socialist" is the answer to this silly column.  It has nothing to do with Latin America.  (China isn't "socialist" any more, so it's exempt from Trump disapproval.)
Name one "socialist" dictator that Trump approves of.  That is the answer to this silly column.

I remember when with the help of the treasonous Brian Mulroney we were forced to "sell" our highly successful oil company. I am grateful to Trump for drawing back the curtain and letting the world know it is not about values and ethics , it is only about money and power.When Russia became totally committed to neoliberalism Putin's friends were well rewarded. All that remains in Venezuela is how to pretend that Venezuela's oil belongs to Venezuelans when all the money ends up in London and New York.
Because we do not give Russia foriegn aid.One thing about Putin ,he's honest and he doesn't beg. Putin doesn't send Russians here to leach  on the US taxpayer.

Mexico's "perpetual president," Porfirio Díaz, reputedly quipped, "Poor Mexico; so far from God, so close to the United States." Shifter & Toppelberg's compelling op-ed certainly buttresses don Porfirio's words, undergirding them with facts.

Apropos of Venezuela's reigning "caudillo del día "nasty" Nick Maduro, it might be worth noting that Trump's animus toward him, besides stemming from garden-variety Yankee contempt of anything south of the Rio Grande/Río Bravo del norte, could also be the byproduct of his recognition of the Venezuelan exile community in southern Florida's waxing political influence if not power.

After all, there's a growing section of the Miami suburb of Doral that's now called "Little Venezuela." Cuban exile political clout has had a good deal of wind knocked out of its sails these days. Perhaps Venezuelan exiles, as well as Puerto Rican refugees of Hurricane Maria, might step in to replace it.

The reason is that Trump cannot foresee the building of a Trump Tower in Venezuela.   Conversely, a tower in Manila, Moscow, Riyadh etc are all possibilities.  Trump's measure of if he likes you or depends exclusively on whether you can get a Trump Tower built in your country.

"Strongmen Have the Edge With Trump. Why Not Maduro?"

Um, because he's Latin American. It's not that hard. Trump is a racist with particularly venomous views of African Americans and Latinos.

"Secretary of State Rex Tillerson called the Monroe Doctrine — which in 1823 unilaterally established the region as an exclusive United States sphere of influence... “as relevant today as it was the day it was written”

The best and the brightest... but what is dismaying is that the quote reflects the point of view of a significant, deeply ignorant portion of the American population.

Dear reader, know that your country is not immune to the forces of extremism and can be crushed under the wheel of changing world power arrangements. In this dear reader, know that America will someday suffer for the sin of arrogance exemplified in the above quote, and brought low.

If Trump is not impeached and re-elected you will reap the whirlwind.

Vote. Democrat.
Trump is a fan of oligarchs the world around but not of those in our hemisphere displacing his own real estate speculation interests (and/or that of his funders).

Trump should mot be congratulated for ANYTHING
He wouldn’t remember it anyway

A. Yes, it does "mean that Mr. Trump can’t have acceptable working relations with democratic leaders." Just look at the G7 and NATO meetings, and his state visit to England.

B. Even Trump can see that Maduro is a hopeless loser. Trump wants to associate with strong leaders who are winners, because he thinks it rubs off on him. What actually rubs off on him is the stink of brutality and corruption.
Maduro looks Mexican, strike 1,2 and 3 with Trump.
