This was not the considered speech of a president: it was the monologue of a bad stand up comedian playing to his crowd and filled with his usual lies and slurs.

Putin was with the KGB for 16 years, recruited in college, trained at the Red Banner Institute and School No. 401 as a spy and interrogator, engaged in counter-intelligence and suppressing dissidents.

As recently as March, Putin showed an animation with a Russian nuclear weapon annihilating Florida, and almost 1500 nuclear missiles are aimed at the U.S. He is no friend to America.

Russia helped put Trump in office, recently confirmed by the Senate intelligence report. No, Putin is not "fine" but a murderous dictator, and the white supremacists whom Trump praised as "very fine people" are not fine either.

In the same manic monologue, Trump said that Sen. Warren should be forcibly tested with a "kit" for lying about her Native American ancestry. He said he would donate a million dollars. This parallels his birther lies about Pres. Obama, with a similar spurious offer to make a multi-million dollar donation. That turned out to be a lie. Sen. Warren's family has an oral history, and I have a similar one from my Tennessee relatives with vague references to 19th c. Cherokees. Many in America have mixed backgrounds.

Praising Putin and insulting a woman and Native Americans, Rep. Waters, Sen. McCain, and the Me Too movement in the space of a few minutes is typical of Trump.

A thousand points of darkness.

Stomach turning.  At one level, I understand the factors that would make the spectacle of a Trump rally appealing.  At another, I feel deep disappointment and sadness that the people in these crowds continue to take such joy in obvious racism, sexism, meanness and corruption.  I still waver between wondering if they do it in spite of it or because of it.  I used to think the former, but now I am resigned to the latter.  I just don’t know whether he’s merely uncovered it and channeled it or whether he is actually teaching it and growing it rally by rally, tweet by tweet.  Either way, God help us, because he’s not stopping anytime soon.

I can come up with many reasons to criticize and ridicule the man because I despise him and what's become of the Republican party, but perhaps Democrats could learn from this too. At least he's reaching out to these far-flung places and supporting his party at the local level. Perhaps if Obama or Hillary had done more of that, the Democratic party wouldn't have fallen so far out of favor with rural voters.

Bill Shine hired as White House Communication Director.

Trump goes out and renews attacks on a woman he fears, Senator Warren including a racial slur and now begins mocking the #metoo movement.

Dots connected. Expect to see a lot more of this, the Trump base wants it, loves it.
It boggles the mind that so many people are okay with all this.

When did we stop having the conversation that this kind of campaign rally doesn't warrant national coverage, except to raise larger questions about his followers or expense? Let's not forget the media's role in giving oxygen to this dumpster fire.

One more rally to boost Trump's spirits--and the cult of his personality.

Trump has held at least twenty-eight of them since his election--nine "thank you" rallies to bask in the glow of victory and nineteen more since his inauguration. Like yesterday's, most of his post-inaugural rallies were ostensibly in support some candidate or other, but all were invariably devoted virtually totally to a promotion of Trump himself.

Every one of them roars through the litany of crowd-rousing lies about Hillary Clinton, the "Fake News" media, specific Democrats (like "Pocahontas") and lawless, borderless, M13-supporting liberals in general. Every one of them roars through the litany of his record-shattering crowds and his earth-shattering accomplishments--things "only" he, of all in human history, has ever done or could possibly have done. Not one of them touches on his policies beyond their utility as vehicles for self aggrandizement. Not one of them focuses on policies he hopes to accomplish beyond vague promises of "making America great again" or more coded ones of preserving "real" Americans' white privilege--promises serving no other purpose than to draw yet more adoration of himself and himself alone.

They are plays straight out of the autocrats' handbook--relating to the crowd as one of their own while positioning himself as extraordinary, even godlike, and thus worthy to carry their and their nation's destiny.

The crowds roar and the GOP's silence is deafening.

This stuck out to me: Trump with his comment that "We are going to do it gently because we’re the #MeToo generation, so we have to be very careful," further undermines the #MeToo movement and the idea that we should believe women. Either he fundamentally misunderstands how DNA samples are taken or he is implying that something as innocent as collecting a spit sample could be misinterpreted by what he sees as the multitude of women who over-zealously claim sexual assault. A depressing moment, considering that sexual assault is so widely under-reported. And this is thematic for him. Undermine belief in sexual assault victims, in the press, in any institution that might cast critical doubt on him.

And yet, reading about Trump's reaction to the damning news that Representative Jim Jordan knew about wrestlers being abused and did nothing, I was struck by Trump's immediate support: "I don't believe them at all. I believe him. Jim Jordan is one of the most outstanding people I've met since I've been in Washington. I believe him 100 percent."

"the roaring crowd."
Like many media outlets, the NY Times seems has doubled down on its now 1 1/2 year campaign to cover the Trump administration as a disaster. This means relentless coverage of every word, every decision, every action as if it is the worst thing a leader could possibly do. The thinking seems to be that if we are inundated with this information, how could we every re-elect him. This is the wrong approach. WE will never re-elect him but WE are not the only people voting. And this article waits until the final paragraph to point out that the crowd was "roaring" even as Trump's speech seems to have been, at once, incoherent and offensive. How is this happening? Well, a large chunk of the population is getting its information elsewhere. And, if this is the case, the NY Times can't directly do anything to influence the election unless it can solve the problem of a fractured news media. We should be reading articles every day about how the information on these pages differs from the information consumed by readers of different publications. We need to understand where everyone is coming from and, from there, capitalize on the fact that the downfall of Trump is in the interest of all Americans.

Just a few questions:

Who's paying for these trips that pretend to be about supporting a Republican candidate, but are really just another Trump 2020 campaign rally?

What's the threshold for determining when a presidential trip paid for by taxpayers should really be paid for by the president's re-election campaign? Number of words/minutes of the speech devoted to himself versus those promoting the candidate he's come to support? The signage used? It sure looks like Trump campaign stuff to me.

Why is the NYTimes not delving into these questions instead of chasing the by-now old story that Trump's speeches traffic in insult and outrage and lies?

I can only hope that Trump continues to fight back. From Day 1 (even prior to announcing his candidacy) he was treated with contempt, condescension and, at times, outright falsehood. The left prefers a doormat. It is good that he disabuses them of the notion.

I've been away at school for many years, but this story about my home state struck a nerve. I grew up in Montana, and always thought Montanans were special. Although leaning more toward the libertarian-conservative side of the spectrum, we were always open minded and pragmatic. It seemed like the harsh landscape tempered everyone's extreme tendencies, forcing us to reckon with the limits of our knowledge and experiences. Montana also has fewer than (or now, roughly) 1 million people, and it is hard to go anywhere in this enormous state without finding common connections with another Montanan. These shared connections seemed to always smooth over politics.

But I don't know what's happening these days--I don't recognize these people as I browse the Trump Rally photos, and I don't recognize the hateful passions that fired up the crowd. These are not my people.

I think the most distressing part of the Trump era are the new, ugly facets that are exposed on parts of the country that we thought we loved. I don't know how we can ever go back.

I was born in Montana and grew up there. Most of my family still lives there. My feeling is that while many Montanans voted for Trump in 2016, many are also rethinking their positions now. Montanans are honest and fair-minded. They like people they feel they can trust, which is how Tester got elected. Access to health care is also very important to Montanans. Trump's lies and constant bragging about himself are starting to wear thin. Most Montanans will not welcome Mr. Trump's comments about Pocahontas, Sen. McCain and former President Bush. I don't expect the election to be close. Tester will win handily.
When Trump nominated Jim Mattis, many of us breathed a sigh of relief.  We should all of us have the opposite reaction, if Trump ousts one of the only competent members of his cabinet.
Let’s just hope that Mattis, when fired, will do what others didn’t: denounce Trump and tell the world publicly what he saw and why he thinks Trump is dangerous.
Perhaps Trump is afraid of someone invoking the 25th Amendment and wants to clean his cabinet of anyone who might vote him out

Good God. Asking the defense secretary to appear on Fox and Friends to praise the president's agenda?

Congress, when will you put a stop to this madness? You got your GOP playbook -- immoral tax cuts and ballooning deficit -- now it's time to save some last shred of American principles.

Secretary Mattis has only himself to blame. One can’t feel pity for someone who chose and continues to direct his own fate. If Sec. Mattis is subverting the will of the elected president then he should be fired. He wasn’t elected. He was hired to do a job. If he’s not doing the job or if he’s secretly working against his boss then he needs to go. This isn’t the way government is supposed to work.

This article contains many contradictions. I detest Trump, but he genuinely seems reluctant to involve the US militarily in places like Afghanistan and North Korea. Not sending more troops to Afghanistan and suspending wargames with South Korea would not throw the world into chaos. It’s the opposite of a belligerent foreign policy. If these are policies that Mattis is actively campaigning for then I certainly don’t support him.

I remember when Democrats were against the illegal wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and in favor of pursuing diplomacy with North Korea.

Resign Man!

Anyone who at this point is still working for this criminal is going to go down with him as a criminal.

Get out, do it for your family at least.

"Using his folksy manner, Mr. Mattis talked the president out of ordering torture against terrorism detainees "

What?!? Torturing detainees? Isn't this the bigger story?

It's the kiss of death when Trump tells an employee "He’ll stay right there." Mattis won't be our defense secretary for very much longer. We're only left to wonder when, how, and who will follow. Trump already tapped Bolton. Who's left operating in the traditional quack circuit? The applicant pool must be extremely shallow. I'm actually amazed someone like Mattis has suffered Trump for this long.

For an ex-marine, you would think commander bone spurs would have received a resignation letter in an uncomfortable place six different times by now. I suppose Mattis feels he is fulfilling a duty. However, you have to wonder at the man's motives this far along into Trump's presidency. Is he really helping the Pentagon by hiding Trump's incompetence? I don't feel any safer knowing about Mattis' arrangement with the president.

Donald Trump thought he was getting "Mad Dog". Instead he got 4-star Marine General James Mattis. Gen. Mattis probably believed he could make a positive contribution and assist a new president in better understanding the US Military and its place in this country.

They were both wrong.

I doubt that Trump had any concept of how Mattis's self-discipline, intelligence and commitment to the US and its Constitution would shape his tenure as Secretary of Defense. These are not things that previously existed in Trump's world. Trump's constant harping on the "Mad Dog" sobriquet initially was an exemplar of his own cartoonish view of the military.

Gen. Mattis probably wanted to believe that the Trump impulsiveness, lying, and ill-informed opinions weren't what Trump was at his core. He's probably hung on both from a deep sense of duty and with a hope he could provide some mitigation of the worst impulses of this man unfit for the office he holds.

Our adversaries, our enemies and our former allies are now eagerly arranging a world without the United States of America. They get the picture: we're done. China is getting its soybeans elsewhere, Mexico it's corn from South America. Europe and Asia can produce all the computers, airplanes, high speed transit and smart phones the world needs; China too, plus the windmills, solar panels, and electric cars impoverished Americans will soon be buying - on credit, of course - from our good friends at Wallmart. The world is fed up with our arrogance, our hypocrisy, our fecklessness, our phony baloney Christianity, our pedantic lecturing, our especially about human rights, which we practice selectively, our endless idiotic election cycles, our perpetual military misadventures and our infantile nutjob president and his neo fascist warmonger climate change denying political party. We have gone from the indispensable nation to a disposable pernicious dinosaur country and the Fox addled morons and bigots who voted for Republican liars, charlatans, criminals and traitors will shortly be in for a rude awakening. They voted Republican: and they are going to get everything that's coming to them.

This kind of thinking that "at least he is shaking up the status quo" is mindless. Throwing a monkey wrench into the works would have a similar effect. Trump is an extremely ignorant man who knows next to nothing about things he should know a lot about. And he thinks it isn't important to know stuff -- saying it is not important to prepare for the Korea summit because it is all about "attitude."

Trump is not just ignorant, he is unable and unwilling to learn. He can barely read or write and cannot listen or pay attention. He is severely deranged and like a toddler he is constantly pushing the boundaries of his world, and no one is stopping him. Very very bad things are in store for us all unless his enablers face the truth.

New Zealands three top nations we export to are China, Australia, and the European Union.
Since our new government and the Republicans putting tarrifs on metal from NZ but not from Australia, our new PM went on a public relations tour of England and Europe and the EU have said that it's very likely they'll consider a free trade deal with NZ. So thanks Trump! One countries loss is another countries gain!

Hats off to the editor who selected the lead photo, which so perfectly reflects reality. Trump -- alone, physically removed from the group, scowling, not engaging anyone else. How we as a nation are headed under his incompetent navigation.

At least he's not shoving anyone out of the way this time.

Donald Trump is too intellectually lazy to do his homework on any subject. His famous deal-making prowess is the stuff of fiction. He is not an accomplished deal maker, and his vaunted negotiating skills exist only in his head. So he will go and reveal his profound ignorance of the world. Next to real world leaders, Trump comes off as an uneducated schlub.

Punish our Allies with Tariffs, Mr. Trump?  Those Allies will reciprocate and impose Tariffs targeting Republican controlled states (Kentucky Bourbon, Mr. McConnell).  Meanwhile Trump wants to save jobs for Chinese company ZTE for his  BFF, president Xi. Next week, Tump meets with Kim Jong-Un, an honorable man, who murdered his uncle, his half-brother and has starved his country while building his toy nukes.

Yes, Trump is the black sheep but only because he is mostly clueless on issues. His understanding of the deeper things required for any POTUS to lead is based on Fox News, Hannity and the other inputs for which he has no original thoughts.
He seeks attention so he stirs things up. He'll say one thing, then another. He just keeps talking, saying little. Clearly he knows he's out of his depth. Antagonize and they pay attention.

Maybe that is the only way the other world leaders will either talk to him or avoid him. Looking at the body language in this accompanying photo he is uncomfortable and alone. Merkel looks like she'd only talk to him if in a one on one meeting.
Trump seems to think that he will destroy our alliances and replace them with Putin. What he doesn't seem to get is that Putin is using him. The allies will be back when Trump is finally gone and there is a real leader in his place. Putin will stay as long as he has his hooks into our democracy and his buddy Trump.

I find it very odd how the Trump administration keeps trying to frame this as a "family" spat, or a "trade dispute" or a "disagreement between friends".

The actions of the Trump administration are not the actions of friends. They are the actions of an administration who cares so little for their own soldiers, citizens, and workers that they are willing to destroy relationships just for press.

The actions of the Trump administration are the actions of the ungrateful, who truly believe that everything should be handed to them on a silver platter. They are the actions of bullies, who push everyone else around and then start screaming for teacher as soon as another child stands up for themselves.

It's not a "family issue" when one country tries to hurt another country's jobs, industries, and people.

We sent tens of thousands of soldiers over to Afghanistan over to fight in a war caused by your country. We just promised to send another deployment of Canadian soldiers over to Mali to cover your backs in Niger. We don't stay friends after your administration pretends we never bled in your wars.

If trade is so unfair and loaded against the USA how is the US, a country with only 5% of world population enjoying 25% of world Wealth? We are eating many peoples fair share of their lunch. And when China and India with 1/3 of Entire human population are only now beginning to get back their fair share of world wealth we feel like we are actually losing when we are only giving up the share that never belonged to us to begin with.

My 101 grandmother once referenced how unastute Herbert Hoover was as a president in the early 1930s  and afterwards campaigning against Roosevelt’s New Deal programs. I actually had to look Hoover up. I suppose there’s always an unfavorable president in each generation, though this one is just eye poppingly ludicrous and embarrassing, especially for our image and stance in the wider world. In a modern parallel, I would hope this administration is eventually regaled to a sad footnote in American history for us to learn from and hopefully not repeat.  Democracy is worth it and it’s terrifying to see it denigrated daily.

We just returned from Portugal and the burden of having to answer for this idiot almost spoiled our trip.  As well intentioned as most questions were, they all asked, “how could you let this happen?”  Think I’ll see if I still have that old 60s pin which said, “don’t blame me; I didn’t vote for him.”

There's more to the picture than the character of Donald Trump, more than the betrayal of the US traditional allies. Let's call that the blunt pragmatism of two empires, one declining, the  other on the rise. The Donald brashed  about China but does negociate. There is no other alternative. China will make business with Iran. Same with tariffs. China has got the cards and Donald Trump knows it. That leaves blunt bilateral realism between the two countries. China wins in the end.

Calling President Trump the estranged sibling picking a fight with his relatives just before dinner hardly characterizes the familial squabble we are witnessing. A more appropriate analogy would be a father telling the entitled children he has supported into adulthood that its time to start paying room and board or move out of the house. Predictably, Trudeau, Macron and Merkel are responding like the 31 year old who sued his parents when they dared tell him it was time for him move out, grow up and assume the responsibilities of adulthood.

You say "isolation from the leaders of the world’s largest economies" but I can tell you that Mr Trump is not isolated from great parts of the general population of the UK and the rest of Europe and in fact there is wide admiration for how Mr Trump is standing up to the rest of the world because it is true that there is an unfair balance of tariffs.

To watch Mr Trump handling politics like big business is refreshing and an experiment that is long overdue. My only qualification is a hope that Mr Trump keeps ego out of it and is pragmatic.

Mr.Trump needs our traditional allies and cannot beat them at a trade war.We, as a country will suffer- the economic success he thinks he has will disappear.The economy is good until it suddenly isn't when our industries suffer trade retaliation.Mr.Trump will find that the allies he has alienated will not step in to help us.

It will be very gratifying to see the leaders of the other great democracies give our president the lambasting he deserves. I hope they pull no punches, and send him reeling out of the conference even earlier than scheduled.  I'm not taking the side of other countries against ours; I'm siding with leaders who represent reason, fairness, and the rule of law against a base and mindless bully who is bent on destroying our hard-won place in the family of nations.

Since the end of World War II, our president has been at the center of the Western Alliance, but as is clear from the photos of this event, Donald Trump has so thoroughly alienated our allies that he is ignored. Could anyone imagine Eisenhower, Kennedy, Reagan, Bush, or Clinton being ignored at a group event of world leaders? That would have been unthinkable.

A man without followers, is just a guy out for a walk. That is Mr. Trump at the G-7 summit. One can only hope that his supporters here in the US understand how diminished is our standing in the world.

Our adversaries, our enemies and our former allies are now eagerly arranging a world without the United States of America. They get the picture: we're done. China is getting its soybeans elsewhere, Mexico it's corn from South America. Europe and Asia can produce all the computers, airplanes, high speed transit and smart phones the world needs; China too, plus the windmills, solar panels, and electric cars impoverished Americans will soon be buying - on credit, of course - from our good friends at Wallmart. The world is fed up with our arrogance, our hypocrisy, our fecklessness, our phony baloney Christianity, our pedantic lecturing, our especially about human rights, which we practice selectively, our endless idiotic election cycles, our perpetual military misadventures and our infantile nutjob president and his neo fascist warmonger climate change denying political party. We have gone from the indispensable nation to a disposable pernicious dinosaur country and the Fox addled morons and bigots who voted for Republican liars, charlatans, criminals and traitors will shortly be in for a rude awakening. They voted Republican: and they are going to get everything that's coming to them.

This kind of thinking that "at least he is shaking up the status quo" is mindless. Throwing a monkey wrench into the works would have a similar effect. Trump is an extremely ignorant man who knows next to nothing about things he should know a lot about. And he thinks it isn't important to know stuff -- saying it is not important to prepare for the Korea summit because it is all about "attitude."

Trump is not just ignorant, he is unable and unwilling to learn. He can barely read or write and cannot listen or pay attention. He is severely deranged and like a toddler he is constantly pushing the boundaries of his world, and no one is stopping him. Very very bad things are in store for us all unless his enablers face the truth.

New Zealands three top nations we export to are China, Australia, and the European Union.
Since our new government and the Republicans putting tarrifs on metal from NZ but not from Australia, our new PM went on a public relations tour of England and Europe and the EU have said that it's very likely they'll consider a free trade deal with NZ. So thanks Trump! One countries loss is another countries gain!

Hats off to the editor who selected the lead photo, which so perfectly reflects reality. Trump -- alone, physically removed from the group, scowling, not engaging anyone else. How we as a nation are headed under his incompetent navigation.

At least he's not shoving anyone out of the way this time.

Donald Trump is too intellectually lazy to do his homework on any subject. His famous deal-making prowess is the stuff of fiction. He is not an accomplished deal maker, and his vaunted negotiating skills exist only in his head. So he will go and reveal his profound ignorance of the world. Next to real world leaders, Trump comes off as an uneducated schlub.

Punish our Allies with Tariffs, Mr. Trump?  Those Allies will reciprocate and impose Tariffs targeting Republican controlled states (Kentucky Bourbon, Mr. McConnell).  Meanwhile Trump wants to save jobs for Chinese company ZTE for his  BFF, president Xi. Next week, Tump meets with Kim Jong-Un, an honorable man, who murdered his uncle, his half-brother and has starved his country while building his toy nukes.

Yes, Trump is the black sheep but only because he is mostly clueless on issues. His understanding of the deeper things required for any POTUS to lead is based on Fox News, Hannity and the other inputs for which he has no original thoughts.
He seeks attention so he stirs things up. He'll say one thing, then another. He just keeps talking, saying little. Clearly he knows he's out of his depth. Antagonize and they pay attention.

Maybe that is the only way the other world leaders will either talk to him or avoid him. Looking at the body language in this accompanying photo he is uncomfortable and alone. Merkel looks like she'd only talk to him if in a one on one meeting.
Trump seems to think that he will destroy our alliances and replace them with Putin. What he doesn't seem to get is that Putin is using him. The allies will be back when Trump is finally gone and there is a real leader in his place. Putin will stay as long as he has his hooks into our democracy and his buddy Trump.

I find it very odd how the Trump administration keeps trying to frame this as a "family" spat, or a "trade dispute" or a "disagreement between friends".

The actions of the Trump administration are not the actions of friends. They are the actions of an administration who cares so little for their own soldiers, citizens, and workers that they are willing to destroy relationships just for press.

The actions of the Trump administration are the actions of the ungrateful, who truly believe that everything should be handed to them on a silver platter. They are the actions of bullies, who push everyone else around and then start screaming for teacher as soon as another child stands up for themselves.

It's not a "family issue" when one country tries to hurt another country's jobs, industries, and people.

We sent tens of thousands of soldiers over to Afghanistan over to fight in a war caused by your country. We just promised to send another deployment of Canadian soldiers over to Mali to cover your backs in Niger. We don't stay friends after your administration pretends we never bled in your wars.

If trade is so unfair and loaded against the USA how is the US, a country with only 5% of world population enjoying 25% of world Wealth? We are eating many peoples fair share of their lunch. And when China and India with 1/3 of Entire human population are only now beginning to get back their fair share of world wealth we feel like we are actually losing when we are only giving up the share that never belonged to us to begin with.

My 101 grandmother once referenced how unastute Herbert Hoover was as a president in the early 1930s  and afterwards campaigning against Roosevelt’s New Deal programs. I actually had to look Hoover up. I suppose there’s always an unfavorable president in each generation, though this one is just eye poppingly ludicrous and embarrassing, especially for our image and stance in the wider world. In a modern parallel, I would hope this administration is eventually regaled to a sad footnote in American history for us to learn from and hopefully not repeat.  Democracy is worth it and it’s terrifying to see it denigrated daily.

I'm not taking the side of other countries against ours; I'm siding with leaders who represent reason, fairness, and the rule of law against a base and mindless bully who is bent on destroying our hard-won place in the family of nations.

Since the end of World War II, our president has been at the center of the Western Alliance, but as is clear from the photos of this event, Donald Trump has so thoroughly alienated our allies that he is ignored. Could anyone imagine Eisenhower, Kennedy, Reagan, Bush, or Clinton being ignored at a group event of world leaders? That would have been unthinkable.

A man without followers, is just a guy out for a walk. That is Mr. Trump at the G-7 summit. One can only hope that his supporters here in the US understand how diminished is our standing in the world.

"He wants to destroy the Western alliance."

It is difficult for normal people to get inside the mind of a narcissist. Trump doesn't have a goal of destroying the Western alliance. He doesn't have any goals in the sense of what that means to normal functioning people.

His actions are designed to call attention to himself. Period. And when people are upset with him, well, that's attention too. And it is working. Trump's supporters give him attention, world leaders give him attention, newspaper columnists give him attention (and attention and attention), Democrats give him attention, people who hate him give him attention. And on and on.

He probably doesn't even know what the "western alliance" is, much less how to destroy it.

He acted to get attention, and it has worked.

Save yourself the effort of trying to figure out his goals in any sense having to do with politics, the country, the world, the economy, anything. There are none.

It was ominous that Trump began the G7 by announcing to reporters that Russia should be allowed back into the fold. What a slap in the face to the other participants that Trump was belittling their standards for responsible world leaders - and behind their backs, no less.
Trump's increasing hostility about tariffs were also not a good sign of what was to come. Earlier this year, Trump, in his own admission, had lied to the Canadians about trade. Last week, Trump talked about setting distinct trade policies for Canada and Mexico. He tweeted his one-sided gripes. How could there not have been a response from Trudeau?
Trump is in no way promoting America. It is he, not Trudeau, who is dishonest, who does things you don't do, and who makes the United States look weak. Trump showed himself to be more like a rude party crasher than a respectable world leader.
You want Republicans to speak out on this?  I don't even see Democrats being very loud.  It is astonishing how ALL our leaders have so abjectly failed.

This is a cogent analysis of the damage our bumbling, arrogant, incompetent president is doing to our country and the Western alliances that share our democratic and humanitarian values. Whether he colluded with the Russians or not, he might as well be an enemy agent, because he identifies with tyrants and their base instincts and actions.

He’s a disgrace to our country and to the flag he claims to love. He’s an enemy of the poor, an abuser of woman, a denier of science and Trump and his family and greedy, amoral cohorts exemplify the swamp he said he would clean up.

Dear America,

I know you are better than this current president and that he does not represent the vast majority of you. Your Constitution has checks and balances , please use them to rein this man in before he does serious damage to the world.

All the best,

D. Knight, Canada

Thank you Mr Leonhardt! I've been reading about this issue all over the map but hardly anyone, (excepting Peter Baker, also NYT) has done what you just did. Call the lie a lie. Now Trump is lying about our trade relationships. It is all a lie and I am really tired of being lied to. I'm tired of news quoting the President who lies constantly without fact-checking. So this is refreshing. Trade is complicated. Most of don't follow it in detail. So when Trump is lying about trade it is really important for people like yourself to say so and explain it. Thank you for doing this.

I read the comments here and ask myself: can we as a country assert ourselves? Can we receive reciprocity when we sell our products abroad? Is it fair to expect to receive the benefit thatvother countries have received for years?
How is it OK for Canada to imposse tarif of 290%, on our dairy products and when thheybsend their products across the border we charge zero?
Why do they get so offended when we want to do the same? Why does Angela Merkel expects that we continue to provide security for her country with us footing the bill, and when her country sends cars for us to buy we pay her tariffs and yet when our products enter Germany we need to pay tariffs? Fair is fair is that simple. The only thing theybluke about us is our money. I say let’s expect to be treated as we treat them. It is not personal... it is just about equality.

As A canadian farmers daughter, my family has done well in the dairy business. Small farmers nuture their soil, their animals and sell milk only in Canada. Our cows are not given Bovine Hormone growth... yours are so the govt does not allow American milk directly into the market indirectly in the we have American driedmilk in many other products ..unfortunately . Money is not the only goal of life. Health of citizens and farms are also to be considered. I know that many American dairy farmers would love to have a similar management system . I asked my relatives in LA and Pennslyvania what they pay for milk and It was a few cents less then we do...I dont know how a tariff of 290 % was pulled out of the hat . would someone please explain. i understand that America has a trade surplus in agriculture ....

I tend to think that Trump feels belittled by Trudeau, Merkel, Macron et alia. They are everything that he is not and he knows it.
As a result, Trump feels compelled to assert himself, if he is to exist. This would explain his puerile reaction towards Trudeau.
The problem for Europeans is that our very real sense of kinship with Americans is being tested by Trump. Americans will I hope understand that whatever our reaction towards Trump, the warmth of our relationship with Americans must endure.

No, the GOP  has to speak up. At this point, the Dems are in a delicate place. Conventional wisdom says opposition to trump is not enough  for the Dems to win seats. They need to concentrate on issues. The GOP  needs to hammer trump for the sake of the country. Don't expect the neighborhood to police your bad kid. He's yours, GOP. You discipline him and let the Dems go about saving the country by concentrating on the issues and taking back Congress.

Why are we trying to second guess your leader, when it is patently obvious that he is only dimly aware of particularly the finest details of diplomacy, or the history and theory of democracy.  He behaves like a spoiled child whose tantrums always have got his way for him up to now.  The problem seems to me to be that because he is president, no-one can take up the authority of parent, and correct him.  It is surely not surprising that economic rationalism has produced this travesty of leadership of the free world, based as it is on self interest.  I wonder, does Mr Trump care about the world, or only a small part of it?  Winning votes, being in the spotlight, these are his drivers.

Assume the best case: he's taken this action due to his clear misapprehension of the role and rules of NATO, what a trade imbalance actually looks like, and how little trust anyone has in his word. Assume the worst case: that Trump is compromised and has leapt into this destruction as a result. Either way: we're doing real damage to much-needed alliances.There can be no question but that his behavior harms this nation, as much as it harms our allies. The winners here? Russia, for certain. China and potentially North Korea, by extension.

And yet still no Republican leaders act. A few (Senators Collins and Flake) has whined on twitter. But no one is ACTING to turn the tide. That behavior, I do not understand. They can look the other way to stack the courts with uber-conservative judges (some of whom are profoundly unqualified). They can look the other way while they dismantle decades worth of environmental protections and the last vestiges of the ACA.

But THIS stuff? World order? Economic order? What the heck are they so afraid of that they won't act? I simply don't see a benign explanation for their hands-off attitude. At this point they are complicit in the destruction of the US as a nation anyone can trust or rely on -- including its own citizens.

I knew Trump would be a disaster, but I never counted on the party leadership's active assistance toward that end. Its horrifying.
What I see in the German photo is Donald Trump sitting in a chair with everyone else — whatever their opinion of him might be — paying total attention to him. That's really all that he wants.

We already knew who the clown was, and djt just confirmed who the ringmaster is Putin. Just consider Cicero's words "cui bono", who is to benefit? The destruction  of the Atlantic Alliance would benefit no-one more than Putin.

I'd like to believe that Trump is acting out of his narcissism and willful ignorance; until lately, I believed that was true.  Now, I can almost believe that he is actually trying to destroy the Country as well as the western alliance.  Why is Trump picking fights on trade imbalances when he happily signed a "tax cut" bill that will skyrocket our national debt?  Who will invest in the USA after we anger our allies?  At best, out interest rates will rise significantly without any concurrent significant economic growth (see "stagflation").  Why, too, is he severely limiting immigration when, demographically, we soon won't have enough working people to grow our economy and support the retiring baby boomers?  Can someone better versed in economics tell me how Trump's actions will actually make our country great?

Yeah it's a complete coincidence that everything he does benefits Putin.
Come on.
The very revealing thing about all of this is how weak and inconsequential Congress is. The myth of checks and balances has been shown.

It was always clear to us in Australia that Trump was ready to smash long-standing international relationships for his own petty, childish, ego-driven reasons. What wasn’t so clear to us was that the Republican establishment would go along with Trump’s excesses with barely a whimper. That is the truly sad aspect of where we find ourselves now.

Trump wants to "destroy" the European-Western alliance? How could he possibly accomplish that even if he wanted to -- given the longstanding and deep cultural and political affinities among the G7 nations? This is either hyperbolical silliness or genuine paranoia on the part of the writer.

The disaster we are experiencing today is another reason we really need to get rid of the electoral college. The Russian sabotage that left us with a leader we can’t trust due to incompetence and/or treasonous motives (take your pick or choose both, but either way we lose) would have been far less likely if we had one person one vote presidential elections. This is not the first time we’ve had a president who doesn’t reflect the will of the people and the results have gone from bad to Trump. It’s a stain on our democracy and every day it becomes more painful to contemplate how far apart Trump’s total votes were from Clinton’s in the popular vote.
America's future lies with the vast and undeveloped Russian Federation.  Western Europe is a failed experiment in socialism.  A US/Russian alliance would dominate the world for centuries to come.

Trump's words and actions seem so utterly irrational to me that it's hard to believe there is any coherent plan behind them.

Republicans, media commentators, toadies can rave to absurdity about the pattern and the stitching and the fabric. But the reality is that this emperor has no clothes on.

No matter Mr. Trump's motives in destroying the strong alliances that the United States has had for the last century, the fact is that he IS destroying them. We need to heed that fact and take action.

But the Republican majority in the House and the Senate are sitting back saying little, except for a few who are retiring. Even they vote with Trump, regardless of their words.

If actions speak louder than words, then we must counter Mr. Trump's actions. The United States should not be the politically isolated country it was before WWI. We need to continue to be a strong, moral leader.

To do that, we need to replace Republicans who are aiding and abetting Mr. Trump. Vote!

Dear America,

As a Canadian I am dismayed and shocked at what has become of your country in such a short time. Only two years ago we knew that we could count on you in times of emergency and you knew that we would always be there for you.

Today, when I meet with my friends and family, the topic always turns towards Trump. We are shocked, angered, saddened and most of all dumbfounded. How could you elect such and obviously unqualified person to lead your country? How did America fall so quickly and when does the freefall end?

Our talks always end with a debate on whether to boycott all American companies and products or to just boycott supporters of the Republican Party or just supporters of Trump. We can't quite agree. I'm personally boycotting all supporters of the Republican Party as Congress and the Senate have shown themselves to be weak, cowardly and incapable of standing up for basic American and human values. We used to call you our cousins to the south, but now I can't even print what we now call you and we don't do so lightly. For the sake of America and the world please find some inner strength and find your way back to the decent, trustworthy country that you once were. I'm honestly not holding my breathe, but I am holding back my money.

Yours truly,

An old friend

Navarro was recently interviewed on NPR. He adamantly stated that the US needs to impose steel tariffs for "security". This was the big problem with Trudeau. But when asked about why the ZTE sanctions was reversed when that is a computer component which could threaten security, he refused to answer why there is a difference. You have to read/listen to this to believe it.

“INSKEEP: Well, then why is it that the president then suddenly said that he wanted to cut a break to ZTE, this Chinese tech company that repeatedly violated U.S. rules and was sanctioned and then violated even the agreement to get out of the sanctions. Why does the president want to cut them a break, given everything you've just said?
NAVARRO: Forgive me, Steve. As a U.S. government official, I cannot comment on that matter as of yet because it's a law enforcement matter. I can't say any more than that. That's my instructions.
INSKEEP: You can't comment in any way on the president's...
NAVARRO: No, no. As a U.S. government official - on the ZTE case, it's clear. It's a law enforcement issue. I simply can't comment on it. So if we can, it'd be best to move on.
INSKEEP: It doesn't fit with your strategy at all, though?
NAVARRO: It's a law enforcement matter. Justice Department is involved, Commerce is involved...
INSKEEP: OK.

Let us all pledge our allegiance by vowing to "support and defend" the Constitution of the United States.

In 1967, The Promethian, an alternate campus newspaper at Syracuse University had  inscribed beneath its logo:  Dante reserves a special place in hell for those who remain neutral in times of moral crisis.  Perhaps this is what Peter Navarro was paraphrasing.  Heed Dante.  B

There actually is a bit of humor in this sad story. If you take the time to listen to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's press conference immediately following the G-7 and then hear the responses from Trump, Kudlow and Navarro you can't help but laugh.
Mr. Trudeau's comments were polite, statesmanlike, and very appropriate. On the other hand, the comments from our people were totally unwarranted and disgraceful. It is one thing for Trump to make a fool of himself but for Kudlow and Navarro to follow suit is shameful. One would never guess that Kudlow and Navarro are college graduates and we're not talking graduates of Trump University. Both Kudlow and Navarro are graduates of accredited American Universities.

Kudos to Mr. Navarro for apologizing to our best friend and most important trading partner.

Sounding like Trump is no feather in this advisor’s hat. His apology is as unacceptable as is his nasty tongue.
He has betrayed Canada (our best ally) and betrayed America. He has been bought and paid for like Kudlow by our erratic psychotic president.
There also appears to be a special place in hell for anyone who spends any amount of time listening to Peter Navarro talk about it.
Once again the administration speaks for God.  Someone they have never met.

Donald Trump called Justin Trudeau a "back-stabber" and a "liar." Donald Trump is a back-stabber and a liar......and totally lacking in self-awareness. And Navarro is just another bully.  And now he apologizes.   Another worthless apology.  There is not one redeeming quality that anyone in this administration has.
Navarro should resign, he is obviously not fit for the job.

Too late. That vituperative comment about Mr. Trudeau is already seared into the minds of Canadians and Americans alike -- as is the vehemence with which it was pronounced.
There is no walking this one back. Especially since this is not a single occurance, but rather endemic of the entire Trump administration's disregard for common courtesy and diplomacy.
Peter Navarro is just another symptom of a far greater problem, that unfortunately, is ours.

Weak "apology", but I am more concerned about how these trade policies are going to affect Cdn and US families.  Thousands will lose jobs, costs will go up and citizens of our great North American neighborhood will be hurt the most.  I am concerned that the rhetoric coming from the WH and it's sycophants  does not match the reality of the complexity in trade .  They are vilifying allies with lies and painting the USA as some kind of victim and many citizens are buying it.

Well, it was not the administration's finest hour, but we Canadians can take it. And Trudeau has taken a lot of flak over the years, so I don't worry about his ego being bruised.

Trudeau and his team are doing their best to navigate the ever-shifting sands of the Trump agenda. Even Trudeau's political opponents supported his remarks,and I am very proud that Canadian politicians took the "country over party" approach to this unfortunate episode.

All of us, Canadians and Americans alike, have no choice but to live through this tumultuous time, and when it is eventually over, we can do some heavy duty damage control. And still be friends.

"Mr. Trump, who has since threatened to impose tariffs on Canada, added: 'He learned. That’s going to cost a lot of money for the people of Canada. He learned. You can’t do that. You can’t do that.'"

That's essentially what Alejandro Sosa told Tony Montana in "Scarface." And it's the worldview that drives Trump's use of the deceptively positive-sounding phrase, "America first."

That style is far from "great" and it's not America. But the Republicans in Congress think it's how our country ought to be.

And instead of focusing on infrastructure, health care, gun violence, or Russian interference in our elections and democracy, our President and his lickspittle toadies fight with Canada. Canada.
I'm curious if this is another example of the "healing" that so many Trump voters hoped for after 8 years of Obama's unprecedented "abuse" of his office??
The supportive comments are appreciated, but what is happening to actually ensure that political action happens to rid this man of power?

Navarro caught the Trump Virus, some people are lucky that it only lasts for 24 hours. Unfortunately for most it is incurable.
Named after a 21st century president, who was forced from office, this virus causes the victim to loose all sense of morality, reason and humanity. In in many cases victims become incapable of speaking in complete sentences.

Once you make a statement that shows your stupidity all the apologies in the world can't make it go away. Of course that does not apply to Trump who will just lie that he never sais it and then lie about the lie.

Probably his whole adult life Peter wanted to surface feelings that drive his politics. Rather than just let the ugliness of those policies speak for themselves, he now feels permission to let it all come out.
I've noticed all these right wing types keep talking about that special place in hell reserved for the rest of us. Although Ivanka, to her father's bewilderment, did place Roy Moore there. And then after Roy lost the election, a furious Steve Bannon placed her there without mentioning her name. Why is it that this phrase has such currency now. What does it mean to these horrible people. Is it a place they wish to be themselves and feel excluded. So they call it hell. I am always about five steps behind. So is there anyone who can help me out here.

The president is the problem, his staff feels that it is ok to use language like that used by Mr. Navarro on Sunday because the president talks like that.  The president behaves like a bully and speaks like a thug when he feels disrespected.  It wasn't the Canadian PM that spoke because he thought the president was gone, it was the president who always attacks people behind their backs.  He spoke ill of the Canadian PM when he was on his plane.  He attacks and fires people via twitter.  He is the most unpresidental occupant of the White House ever and is an embarrassment to all Americans.
Have you noticed how the comments by this guy and Kudlow do not talk about Canada and the United States? It's all about what was "done" to Trump.

Liberals just assume it is natural and a requirement to show your bonafides and your self-righteousness.

The preferred way to announce your purity is to criticize Trump whenever a speaking opportunity presents itself.

Could be at an awards ceremony, a speech, doesn’t matter.

Trudeau surfed on the Liberal wave of anti-Trumpism, trying to be cool, like all the other stars, and a shark bit him.

Trump has done something that seldom happens; the vast majority of Canadian agree on something. We are united in outrage towards the US. Individual Canadians are saying they will buy less US products, reduce US vacations and do less cross border shopping. Mr Trump - your words are going to cost the US a lot of money. Are you happy now?

For any high level official, whether in public or private service, who makes such an obnoxious statement, an apology is de minimis at best.  Mr. Navarro was apparently trying to win the favor of Donald Trump.  But Mr. Navarro is a man who appears to be at least 60 years old, but to utter the statement he made is more befitting an 8 year old.   Further, If he wants to use the "special place in hell" thought, save it for a truly horrendous person, a brutal dictator or the like.   There simply is no place in officialdom for the sort of insult he made, particularly to an American ally.  His comment is insulting to our government and to the people he purports to represent, American citizens.
"Apologizing"? On TV? With weasel words? He should resign.

Mr. Navarro exemplifies the on-going special feature of Donald's reign: surrounding himself with completely unfit persons. The biggest danger of such an obtuse person like DT in a position of power is the inability to learn from better-informed people. So instead he surrounds himself withe extremist cranks.

Can't wait for this sack of potatoes we call President Trump to get heaved out of the White House. His post-White House life promises to be a "special place in hell".
No.  Getting whole milk instead of 2% is a "mistake".  What Navarro said was atrocious and completely unbefitting a White House Administration official.

What next? Will Canada need to start accepting refugees from the United States saying “Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, The wretched refuse of your teeming shore."

At our local co-op, I regularly find many Canadian products,not because they are less expensive than comparable American products but because they are of higher quality and consistently meet the demands of the specialized marketplace---vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, allergen-free, GMO-free,  etc.  Though I lack the statistical information, I  suspect that the  upstate New York and Ontario economies are closely interwoven.  Until recently, we even had a Tim Horton's coffee and pastry kiosk in some of  our local supermarkets.
Wow, we might lose Canada?  So what?

Trump is a wrecking ball - hell bent on wrecking the environment, trade, alliances, civic spirit, race relations, and American unity. He has the reverse Midas touch: Everything he touches turns into a stinky mess. Trump revels in being an unpredictable jerk - but he is not unpredictable, he is just a jerk.

As should be obvious now to even the most die-hard Trump supporters, Trump is not capable of "acting presidential." He never was, he never will be.

"There's a special place in hell for any foreign leader that engages in bad faith diplomacy with President Donald J. Trump and then tries to stab him in the back on the way out the door,"

Mr Navarro manages to combine cliché, arrogance, sycophancy and of course falsehood in a single short statement.

He can't be suggesting - surely? - that engaging in "bad faith diplomacy" with Trump is inherently worse than doing so with anyone else.

No doubt like anyone who has to work for Trump Navarro can speak authoritatively on the subject of Hell - but my amateur opinion is that "a special place" is more likely to be found for lickspittles like Navarro who fawn to their master Trump and lie to the American public.

Instead of flying back to America, Trump should carry on to Vietnam, at the taxpayers' expense.

The last time he had an opportunity to go there at the taxpayers' expense, some nasty bone spurs appeared.
America will lose Trump before it loses Canada.

I don't think that the "War of 1812" statement was a joke.
I think that Trump is ignorant of history

Hello Wisconsin...please tell Mr Trump that the 25%
Mexican tariff makes your Costco cheddar and mozzarella uneconomic for my restaurant.

I am looking for Mexican suppliers.

Mexico is the biggest US export market for dairy products.Cheese is probably the highest value added US food export.

The US exports pigs ears, snouts and trotters to
China. Definitely not high value.

Please read "Why Goliath Can't Export" written by an American with long experience in Asia. In short,
Americans don't understand other cultures.
(Economist circa 1985)

Responding to the title "Will America lose Canada", let me answer in a way that reflects the attitude of Canadians as people to Americans as people.  The answer is "Yes".  It's not irreversible.  But you're getting close.  Let me point out that my great-grandmother was from Iowa; her brothers fought during the Civil War.  My grandpa's brother settled in New York, and I know his descendants.  My ancestors have deep roots on both sides of our border, so I've viewed our peoples as one family living under different political systems.  We smile when we find ourselves the brunt of jokes on late-night TV shows about our mild, apologetic nature ... but our good nature is intelligently measured ... we can get our backs up, we're prepared to deal with fools, and we are more resolute than you may believe.  We fought in both world wars and the Korean war.  We (including my dad and uncles and other relatives) fought in World War II earlier than your country (you were dragged in unwillingly) ... one uncle lost a lung when he was machine-gunned off his motorcycle as a dispatch rider; another was murdered as a P.O.W.  I come from a history of miners and loggers and smelter workers, as well as homesteading farmers.  My home town manufactured "heavy water" (deuterium dioxide) for your Manhattan Project during WW II.  We're tough; we're loyal; don't get our backs up.   Get your President under control.  You'll rue the day when we begin to seriously question our affection for you as neighbours.

Yes, you will lose us.  Most Canadians have urged PM Trudeau to aggressively develop trade with partners other than the U.S.  We are already doing this, and will continue to do so rather than put up with more of Trump's childish temper tantrums.  We have been patient, but enough is enough.  The unfortunate fall-out of all this is that he will hurt U.S. workers as much if not more than he will hurt Canada.

Oh please. Lose Canada? In the 1860s annexing Canada was still openly considered in the United States as the natural evolution of the country's manifest destiny. As late as 1938 Roosevelt warned Canada that the United States had the right to invade to protect itself against any other power having undue influence. A country of 36 million where most of the population lives within one hundred miles of the United States with a population ten times larger, and whose prosperity depends on access to the US market, has very little bargaining power. Canada has benefited from multilateral treaties and institutions because in any bilateral negotiations with the US Canada is always in a weaker position. It isn't far from the truth that Canada is a historical accident, and even today survives by the grace of the United States. In the emerging world of regional hegemonies Canada has no alternative but to put up with most of the US dictates. What would be the alternative, turning to Russia for help? Trudeau the first was right, the correct metaphor is elephant and mouse. And don't forget it.

I am always impressed by how diplomats to a person always favor good relations over bad even when the interests of the two countries diverge. I am tempted to conclude Mr. Kelly is a beta male put off by Trump's alpha, but maybe it is just Mr. Kelly's need to use the revolving door at State to make his living as a Canadian lap dog, I mean, lobbyist.

I find that one thing I have taken from my past is in time one gets to leave the kindergarten bullies behind and take the best revenge possible - 'Live well!"

I take further comfort in seeing that most Americans I meet, while they may wish to put America First, do not quite care for his style.

I have also been developing a kinder reflection towards the Bushes and even Reagan.
My sympathy for Andrew Scheer, since it is his job to call Trudeau dishonest and weak.

After applying equal and measured counter tariff on American imports, the first thing Canadian government should do is to pull all military personnel working with American military overseas immediately. Why risk the most valuable Canadian asset to assist such ungrateful & unsavory characters? Next, cancel all military purchases from American Military-Industrial complex. Canadian tax dollars should only buy from countries who appreciate Canada as a favored customer. Finally, Canadian consumers should look at the product labels carefully and decide if their own wallet should support a country dead-set on punishing a friendly nation.

Trump is ignorant about all things.  His “businessman” credentials are worth nothing when you consider a large portion of his wealth was made through corrupt means.  He’s a grifter, a phony, a con man and a hateful, immoral fool.

As someone who has loved visiting Canada and it's people for half a century, I can't begin to explain how embarrassed and ashamed for my country this state of affairs makes me. We have a ruling political party that doesn't appreciate Canadians. Unbelievable!

USA and Canada have a very profound bond that I do not think this president, or those around him, can destroy. This is all rather disappointing I think for and to both sides - but I like to think that rational minds and shared respect and interest will continue to form the basis of any relationship - trade, foreign policy, etc. I for one am a big fan of the US.

Ironically (and there is way too much irony with this administration), Trump's economist Navarro claimed that German car companies assembling cars in the US didn't count as beneficial to the US because the components were made in Germany.  What do you think they are assembling in Canada or Mexico?  American cars!  These guys can't even keep their story straight except that somehow none of this trade stuff works to our advantage.
Will America lose Canada? No. The American and Canadian peoples will be be friends and allies long after Trump and his foolishness are forgotten. How could good neighbors not be?

"America" has already lost Canada.  Job done!  Good work!  The G7 rant of your president and his subsequent unadulterated threats to make all Canadians "pay" for the supposed insult has convinced many that the friendship is over, if not the required cohabitation of a shared continent.  Something truly broke in the Canadian psyche this weekend.  We feel like Poland in 1939, knowing it will only get worse.  The #ThanksCanada hashtag is a nice effort, but it will change nothing of the horror of the war to come, be it about trade or otherwise.  It's been nice to know you.  Sorry it had to end this way.  We'll be moving on now.  Don't bother to write.

"He called the Canadian prime minister, Justin Trudeau, dishonest and weak."

Aren't there always two sides of every story?

I thought that the American system was one of checks and balances. Why are there so few checks on this megalomaniac and apparently little to no balance in the current american political system?
Let us hope the midterm elections provide some relief to this absurdity.
The U.S. administration may lose Canada, but U.S. citizens won't.

Trump is not “a man with a business background”.  He has a lifelong background in lying, cheating, and stealing — including the 2016 presidential election and his subsequent administration.  Which is how they do “business” in, say, Russia.  Have you ever heard the term “oligarch” without its accompanying descriptor “Russian”?  Who else but Trump could so spectacularly fail to make money running a casino?  As several historical figures have written, we get the government we deserve.

This is what you get when you elect a businessman to a political position. The language of diplomacy has evolved to where calling someone "unhelpful" is a major insult. This allows politicians to disagree in public statements while not leaving entire populations insulted and demanding war. Trump, the businessman, has swept this diplomacy aside and used direct language to throw meat to his base.

The result, predictably, is that Canadians are outraged and the trade war has already started. The long tariff list created by Canadian politicians will be meaningless and generate no revenue. Canadians will not buy any of the products on the list, or anything else from the US, for any tariffs to be collected. Already started. Done deal. Our politicians couldn't turn off this trade war even if they wanted to. Good job Mr. Trump. You have been most unhelpful.

He can't be suggesting - surely? - that engaging in "bad faith diplomacy" with Trump is inherently worse than doing so with anyone else.

No doubt like anyone who has to work for Trump Navarro can speak authoritatively on the subject of Hell - but my amateur opinion is that "a special place" is more likely to be found for lickspittles like Navarro who fawn to their master Trump and lie to the American public.

Instead of flying back to America, Trump should carry on to Vietnam, at the taxpayers' expense.

The last time he had an opportunity to go there at the taxpayers' expense, some nasty bone spurs appeared.
America will lose Trump before it loses Canada.

I don't think that the "War of 1812" statement was a joke.
I think that Trump is ignorant of history

Hello Wisconsin...please tell Mr Trump that the 25%
Mexican tariff makes your Costco cheddar and mozzarella uneconomic for my restaurant.

I am looking for Mexican suppliers.

Mexico is the biggest US export market for dairy products.Cheese is probably the highest value added US food export.

The US exports pigs ears, snouts and trotters to
China. Definitely not high value.

Please read "Why Goliath Can't Export" written by an American with long experience in Asia. In short,
Americans don't understand other cultures.
(Economist circa 1985)

Responding to the title "Will America lose Canada", let me answer in a way that reflects the attitude of Canadians as people to Americans as people.  The answer is "Yes".  It's not irreversible.  But you're getting close.  Let me point out that my great-grandmother was from Iowa; her brothers fought during the Civil War.  My grandpa's brother settled in New York, and I know his descendants.  My ancestors have deep roots on both sides of our border, so I've viewed our peoples as one family living under different political systems.  We smile when we find ourselves the brunt of jokes on late-night TV shows about our mild, apologetic nature ... but our good nature is intelligently measured ... we can get our backs up, we're prepared to deal with fools, and we are more resolute than you may believe.  We fought in both world wars and the Korean war.  We (including my dad and uncles and other relatives) fought in World War II earlier than your country (you were dragged in unwillingly) ... one uncle lost a lung when he was machine-gunned off his motorcycle as a dispatch rider; another was murdered as a P.O.W.  I come from a history of miners and loggers and smelter workers, as well as homesteading farmers.  My home town manufactured "heavy water" (deuterium dioxide) for your Manhattan Project during WW II.  We're tough; we're loyal; don't get our backs up.   Get your President under control.  You'll rue the day when we begin to seriously question our affection for you as neighbours.

Yes, you will lose us.  Most Canadians have urged PM Trudeau to aggressively develop trade with partners other than the U.S.  We are already doing this, and will continue to do so rather than put up with more of Trump's childish temper tantrums.  We have been patient, but enough is enough.  The unfortunate fall-out of all this is that he will hurt U.S. workers as much if not more than he will hurt Canada.

Oh please. Lose Canada? In the 1860s annexing Canada was still openly considered in the United States as the natural evolution of the country's manifest destiny. As late as 1938 Roosevelt warned Canada that the United States had the right to invade to protect itself against any other power having undue influence. A country of 36 million where most of the population lives within one hundred miles of the United States with a population ten times larger, and whose prosperity depends on access to the US market, has very little bargaining power. Canada has benefited from multilateral treaties and institutions because in any bilateral negotiations with the US Canada is always in a weaker position. It isn't far from the truth that Canada is a historical accident, and even today survives by the grace of the United States. In the emerging world of regional hegemonies Canada has no alternative but to put up with most of the US dictates. What would be the alternative, turning to Russia for help? Trudeau the first was right, the correct metaphor is elephant and mouse. And don't forget it.

I am always impressed by how diplomats to a person always favor good relations over bad even when the interests of the two countries diverge. I am tempted to conclude Mr. Kelly is a beta male put off by Trump's alpha, but maybe it is just Mr. Kelly's need to use the revolving door at State to make his living as a Canadian lap dog, I mean, lobbyist.

I find that one thing I have taken from my past is in time one gets to leave the kindergarten bullies behind and take the best revenge possible - 'Live well!"

I take further comfort in seeing that most Americans I meet, while they may wish to put America First, do not quite care for his style.

I have also been developing a kinder reflection towards the Bushes and even Reagan.
My sympathy for Andrew Scheer, since it is his job to call Trudeau dishonest and weak.

After applying equal and measured counter tariff on American imports, the first thing Canadian government should do is to pull all military personnel working with American military overseas immediately. Why risk the most valuable Canadian asset to assist such ungrateful & unsavory characters? Next, cancel all military purchases from American Military-Industrial complex. Canadian tax dollars should only buy from countries who appreciate Canada as a favored customer. Finally, Canadian consumers should look at the product labels carefully and decide if their own wallet should support a country dead-set on punishing a friendly nation.

Trump is ignorant about all things.  His “businessman” credentials are worth nothing when you consider a large portion of his wealth was made through corrupt means.  He’s a grifter, a phony, a con man and a hateful, immoral fool.

As someone who has loved visiting Canada and it's people for half a century, I can't begin to explain how embarrassed and ashamed for my country this state of affairs makes me. We have a ruling political party that doesn't appreciate Canadians. Unbelievable!

USA and Canada have a very profound bond that I do not think this president, or those around him, can destroy. This is all rather disappointing I think for and to both sides - but I like to think that rational minds and shared respect and interest will continue to form the basis of any relationship - trade, foreign policy, etc. I for one am a big fan of the US.

Ironically (and there is way too much irony with this administration), Trump's economist Navarro claimed that German car companies assembling cars in the US didn't count as beneficial to the US because the components were made in Germany.  What do you think they are assembling in Canada or Mexico?  American cars!  These guys can't even keep their story straight except that somehow none of this trade stuff works to our advantage.
Will America lose Canada? No. The American and Canadian peoples will be be friends and allies long after Trump and his foolishness are forgotten. How could good neighbors not be?

"America" has already lost Canada.  Job done!  Good work!  The G7 rant of your president and his subsequent unadulterated threats to make all Canadians "pay" for the supposed insult has convinced many that the friendship is over, if not the required cohabitation of a shared continent.  Something truly broke in the Canadian psyche this weekend.  We feel like Poland in 1939, knowing it will only get worse.  The #ThanksCanada hashtag is a nice effort, but it will change nothing of the horror of the war to come, be it about trade or otherwise.  It's been nice to know you.  Sorry it had to end this way.  We'll be moving on now.  Don't bother to write.

"He called the Canadian prime minister, Justin Trudeau, dishonest and weak."

Aren't there always two sides of every story?

I thought that the American system was one of checks and balances. Why are there so few checks on this megalomaniac and apparently little to no balance in the current american political system?
Let us hope the midterm elections provide some relief to this absurdity.
The U.S. administration may lose Canada, but U.S. citizens won't.

Trump is not “a man with a business background”.  He has a lifelong background in lying, cheating, and stealing — including the 2016 presidential election and his subsequent administration.  Which is how they do “business” in, say, Russia.  Have you ever heard the term “oligarch” without its accompanying descriptor “Russian”?  Who else but Trump could so spectacularly fail to make money running a casino?  As several historical figures have written, we get the government we deserve.

This is what you get when you elect a businessman to a political position. The language of diplomacy has evolved to where calling someone "unhelpful" is a major insult. This allows politicians to disagree in public statements while not leaving entire populations insulted and demanding war. Trump, the businessman, has swept this diplomacy aside and used direct language to throw meat to his base.

The result, predictably, is that Canadians are outraged and the trade war has already started. The long tariff list created by Canadian politicians will be meaningless and generate no revenue. Canadians will not buy any of the products on the list, or anything else from the US, for any tariffs to be collected. Already started. Done deal. Our politicians couldn't turn off this trade war even if they wanted to. Good job Mr. Trump. You have been most unhelpful.

At our local co-op, I regularly find many Canadian products,not because they are less expensive than comparable American products but because they are of higher quality and consistently meet the demands of the specialized marketplace---vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, allergen-free, GMO-free,  etc.  Though I lack the statistical information, I  suspect that the  upstate New York and Ontario economies are closely interwoven.  Until recently, we even had a Tim Horton's coffee and pastry kiosk in some of  our local supermarkets.
Wow, we might lose Canada?  So what?

Trump is a wrecking ball - hell bent on wrecking the environment, trade, alliances, civic spirit, race relations, and American unity. He has the reverse Midas touch: Everything he touches turns into a stinky mess. Trump revels in being an unpredictable jerk - but he is not unpredictable, he is just a jerk.

As should be obvious now to even the most die-hard Trump supporters, Trump is not capable of "acting presidential." He never was, he never will be.

The last time he had an opportunity to go there at the taxpayers' expense, some nasty bone spurs appeared.
America will lose Trump before it loses Canada.

In one of my conversations with my Russian friends, some of whom are Putin supporters, I asked them one question: What good did it do to Russia to intervene in U.S elections?

Since then, Russia has been slammed with sanctions. Sanctions that will cause enormous damages to Russia in a long run.
If a Democrat wins in 2020 , stronger sanctions will be taken against Russia on top of those already in place.
Putin in my opinion totally miscalculated. Putin like most dictators made a mistake of thinking that a President in the US has the same type of absolute power He has in Russia. Most of the sanctions taken against Russia will not be waived any time soon.
So my question is Why did Putin do it? what does he expect from his aggressive policies. They might make Putin look good and strong but what about Russia?
When do we think this will actually be implemented?
Does Trump know about it?

Trump acts only in his own self interest , he's more interested in doing business with Putin and the rest of the oligarchs , not necessarily Russia . These sanctions are a nothing burger as he'll reverse the decision at some point . Nothing new under Trump , it's not the governing side that interests him , more the gain from it .
Do we need to put up billboards to announce that America is deep into a new McCarthyism era?
Trump is criticized if he applies sanctions, is also criticized if he does not. I guess libs know only one thing: criticize.

Mr Trump has personal and private issues to deal with .

The issues concerning the" South China Sea" and Russian chemical attacks on the UK are obviously not a priority.

Vote Democratic in November.
