Trump is so tuff slapping tariffs and sanctions on everybody.  He should change his name to Donald Steel.

Keep in MIND at all times how Trump has sought to BLOCK Sanctions. There is now before us an attempt to delete sanctions on Deripaska, Manaford's friend and accomplice. Tell your reps to stop flirting with Treason.

But Putin has Really Strongly Denied that Russia poisoned their former spy.

If that's good enough for Trump to withhold consequences for Putin's controlling of America's 2016 election, why respond to this more recent act with consequences?

Apparently Putin has issued a particular list of rules that his puppet is obligated to obey.

Maybe they should impose the first, second and third round of sanctions first.  The administration thinks the entire country has the same IQ and brain capacity as people who were devoted to the "Apprentice".
mid terms approaching, trump wants to look tough.
another trump ddiversion from his real problem, corruption  raised to the n'th power.
It's about time the U.S. boycotts EVERYTHING Russian: completely shut them out.

The rule-based order not only guarantees peace. It also guarantees American prosperity.

It has made the dollar the world's only reserve currency, which is an extraordinary privilege. As a result, most trade surpluses - not just with the US - are invested in US treasury bonds and in the US financial system. This gives American businesses and consumers access to easy credit, and allows the US government to run trillion dollar deficits.

In addition, the rule-based system protects American property rights abroad. China provides a good example of what will happen to America's service industries and its corporate profits, if the Europeans and Japanese no longer play ball on IP and other issues.

Trump is gambling all of this away. He can't turn America's alliances in protection rackets, because neither the EU nor Japan will forgo retaliatory tariffs in exchange for empty US security guarantees. Instead, he'll bring about a multipolar world, in which a wary EU will work with a rising China to deter Russia from further aggression, and limit American influence, first and foremost by setting up a payment system that bypasses the dollar and the American banking system.

I know this is too hard for Trump and his followers to understand, and that it doesn't square with the hubris peddled by the Hoover Institution. But it's the reality of the 21st century, in which the US economy is only as big as that of the Europe, and in which China's economy will be soon.

The Trump Doctrine: Embrace your enemies; alienate you allies. It's a throwback to the 1930's where the first axis of strongmen dictators conspired to rule the world.  And with its anti-immigrant, xenophobic nationalism and overt racism it's all too frightening for those old enough to remember the cost the world endured in defeating the forces of fascism.  [Disclosure: I'm 78 and a member of a Holocaust family.] The question we're confronting today in America is:  Who will rescue us if we don't or won't rescue ourselves from an autocrat?

Those of us under 70 watch these developments with a mix of sadness, anxiety, and extreme anger. It's almost as if Trump was saying to us, well, the system that enormously benefited me and my generation was wonderful, but you don't need it and can't have it.

Most infuriating, most of the people now rapidly trying to destroy what took generations to build and maintain won't be around to see the aftermath. But we will, and so will our children.

We need to vote all of these people out in November and start the hard work of repairing the damage.

I agree with some of what is said here and disagree with other points. For example, China's conduct in East Asia is, to date, considerably less disruptive and abrasive than American conduct in Latin America for most of the past 200 years. The article also greatly exaggerates both the positive effects and overall competence of the American-led order. Indeed, US foreign policy has most often been characterized by gross incompetence. Also, the "surge" in Iraq accomplished nothing other than giving the US cover under which to escape Iraq. All of this being said, the article fails to consider an important point: the US simply spends far too much on its military. It is not that other states are free-riders or need to spend more; it is that other states have a more reasonable sense of threat and a more realistic understanding of what levels of military spending are necessary. The US could easily cut its military budget in half, free up huge resources for social and health spending, and still be the most militarily powerful country in the world. Trump's vicious nationalism, if carried out to its logical extremes, will make the world a much worse place. But this did not happen overnight and the American political system has been stumbling towards this kind of disaster for a long time.

How have ordinary Americans benefitted by the US being world cop and world sugar daddy for decades? Most western countries have much, much, much more generous social benefits than the US, precisely because US taxpayers have been covering all their security/defense needs, basically since the Marshall Plan. What do Americans get out of that arrangement?

This article bashes Trump as if his unique, crazy views are destroying the old world order. But it's a bipartisan fact that our allies are completely ripping us off.

Indeed, Obama himself called NATO and EU countries "free riders." He stated that "free riders aggravate me." According to The Atlantic, which reported these statements, Obama explained that "the defense of the liberal international order against jihadist terror, Russian adventurism, and Chinese bullying depends ... on the willingness of other nations to share the burden with the U.S."

Obama then instituted what he called an "anti-free rider campaign." Good idea, but it was ignored by our allies because it was toothless, so it accomplished nothing. So Trump has simply taken Obama's campaign, put some teeth in, and turbo-charged it to get results.

We defend spend a ton on our military so we can defend our allies. They see our protective umbrella, spend next to nothing, and then used the trillions saved to provide their citizens with free health care and free college, while we can't even provide proper health care to our vets.

It's normal that people will get upset when you take away their freebies. But we've got to do it, and I'm glad Trump has the courage to stand up for Americans.

"He wants the United States to pull back from its alliances and let its partners fend for themselves, and devote its money to its domestic needs."

No, not true. He wants the United States to pull back from its alliances and let its partners fend for themselves, but he has no interest in devoting money to our domestic needs.

Exhibit A: The "Tax Cuts and Jobs" Act.

Exhibit B: Mar a Lago.

Exhibit C: Gross inflation of the military budget.

There are two possible explanations for his behavior. One, he has no idea what he's doing policy-wise, just gets himself rich while enacting random stuff from Fox and Friends, or he's a foreign agent. Neither is good.

The key element of Trump’s remake of the international order is not alliances or trade but his suspicion of free speech, his condemnation of criticism of him and his whims, and his corresponding affection for totalitarian, strongman forms of government. Kim, remember, is a talented leader who is not murderously brutal but simply “tough.”

My father spent his career as a diplomat of the United States Foreign Service, serving over the course of three decades in Germany, Pakistan, Austria, Switzerland and in the State Department in Washington D.C.  He died three years ago.  My family and I miss him greatly, but we are grateful he did not live to see the degradation and denigration of our foreign policy by the current administration. Trump is a vulgar man and a misery but the true disgrace rests with his Republican enablers who encourage all his chaos and destruction and who do nothing to stop it.

Although I agree almost entirely with Ms Schake’s column in the immediate threats posed to the world by Trump, I think she affords too much credence to an implication of an applied ideology rather than sheer buffoonery. Trump managed to get himself a job that he never wanted: his entire tainted existence is now subject to public scrutiny and he defends it by uttering mendacities that cannot hope to endure. He has employed individuals equally if not actually more nefarious than himself to circle the wagons and shore up the ramparts. He has sought fealty and has sought to punish those who deny it, the only real power he has being to terminate their employment. Annoyingly, they get jobs elsewhere.

Is this the end of the liberal order? If Trump was competent, possibly. But, the order won’t end on his incompetent watch. It could, however, crash if someone inherits the nihilist mantle and knows what to do with it. At present, Trump is the proverbial child with a box of matches. Beware the capable tyrant that may lurk in the wings.

The plaintive "won't someone think of the status quo?" thesis is comical, given the givens.

When are the great minds going to get this through their heads? The Trump presidency is a direct result of the status quo. The status quo was not working.

You want to talk history? Cool beans! Looks like you missed a few of our gobal greatest hits, post-WWII, so let me chime in: selling Mexico a bill of goods in the form of NAFTA so multinational corporations could exploit its people as cheap labor, triggering mass immigration to the U.S. as a direct result; creating the Israel/Palestine conflict; spending $20 billion to train and arm the Taliban so they could fight the Soviets;that dust-up in the 60s called... what was it, Vietnam?

Trump is not fixing anything, but the least the left could do is spare us their refrains of "keep America great." It wasn't; it isn't; and it won't be, until you start acknowledging the problems that have been here all along.

Trump is a symptom of a deeper problem. If the President of the United States can deliberately dismantle the liberal world order that presided over the past 70 years, it's because an incredible number of American voters don't particularly mind the world becoming a zero-sum, rule-of-the-strong jungle.

It hits me right in the guy to say that, but lets remember that American conservatives of the WW2 era didn't much care about the human rights abuses Nazis were committing either. Remember that the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, Congress declared war on Japan, then Germany declared war on US. Such was our entry into the defining moral conflict of the 20th century.

Regarding Trump, he could disappear tomorrow, and the fervor to destroy the "globalist" project would not miss a beat. The problem runs deeper than one misogynistic demagogue. The wave of populism that props him up is obviously playing out in countries from Canada (Toronto Mayor Rob Ford was nothing if not a Trump prototype) to the Philippines. So it's not "Trump's Doctrine," at least not exclusively.

No one appreciates the NYT's thorough investigation into this administration's malpractices more than I, but perhaps you should be taking a page out of the Economist's book and open a series that, among other things, puts Trump in the larger context (to which he obviously belongs) than just the US political experience.

What alternate universe is this article from? The Liberal world order is very good at spending money and kicking the can down the road. Festering problems like Iran, Israel/PA, Yemen, Noko, China, Russia/Ukraine -Liberal diplomacy was complicit and has failed each and every time.

As with all nations that tilt toward tyranny and authoritarianism the fundamental element are always the people who are willing participants. This is the Republican Party, or now the party of Trump and it is they who are complicit in what's now taking place in America. Perhaps they think their silence in the face of corruption, lies, obstruction and criminal activity to include the destruction of what so many Americans paid for in blood and treasure along with the democratic institutions once revered by the citizens being minimized will help their agenda but it will end badly. Just like all the other dictatorial nations that embraced tyranny the very people that willingly supported it will suffer along with the rest of us. Donald Trump and his now cult like Republican Party are a stain on everything we once proudly stood for and what really did make America great. And the world painfully looks on as we spiral down to the filthy pit of corrupt totalitarianism.

Sickening.

Is Schake seriously arguing that the biggest problem with Trump is military retrenchment? Trump might be threatening to withdraw from foreign commitments, but so far it's just bluster, and whether he tries or not, there's no indication he wants to reduce military spending. Quite the opposite--he gave the DoD more than it requested this year. Trump's biggest threat to our nation is his fundamental hostility to liberalism everywhere, including domestically, not his unwillingness to defend it abroad. He wants to bring militarism home, parades included--to our borders, to our cities, to "homeland security."

The United States cannot defend democracy abroad when its institutions are under attack within the US. This is where the greatest threat lies. Our power abroad was always based on the projection of our internal strength and our commitment to the rule of law. Despite the sins of our history, we aspired to a more just world. This is what those of us who oppose Trump and the ascendant reactionary, nativist wing of the Republican party see slipping away, with potentially horrifying consequences. Stop worrying that we don't spend enough of our GDP on the military. Worry that, after years of pumping up American nationalism to better support adventurism abroad, our political leaders have created a monster they cannot control--an ugly nationalism increasingly obsessed with abusing the weak "other."

I think it's a fallacy for anyone to believe Trumps end game is to free up funds spent abroad on post WW2 alliances and use it to make life better for working class Americans. It's simply not part of his or the GOPs DNA to improve or expand existing institutions and support those in need. We will never have the improved infastructure or quality of social services our allies offer their citizens. With tax cuts for the rich and corporations accomplished, all we're left with is villifying immigrants, racist dogwhistling and the ongoing erosion of free speech.

I wake up to the nightmare of Trump every day. I start my day with a good cry, throw water on my face and go out into my community and practice benevolence with a passion like never before.

The US holds children as prisoners of war. A crime against humanity created by Trump for extortion against the Dems.

Did I miss the war we lost because our country has been taken over by a dictator? Trump is drunk with power and his underlings now bow to his every wish. Yes, this is more than frightening.

Kori Schake is largely correct. But apparently without realizing it, she explains why Trump is no aberration, but a predictable outcome of decades of American policy supported without question by Republicans and almost without question by Democrats.

"America established a set of global norms that solidified its position atop a rules-based international system. These included promoting democracy, making enduring commitments to countries that share its values, protecting allies, advancing free trade and building institutions and patterns of behavior that legitimize American power by giving less powerful countries a say."

The devil is in the details of the norms and rules. The US clearly thought they allowed destruction of democracy in the Middle East (especially Iran), Latin America (Chile, Guatemala, etc.) and elsewhere. Free trade excluded labor, pharmaceuticals, intellectual property — all areas where the rules were skewed in favor of major powers or ignored by those powers as whim and profit dictated. The US order ignored justice.

Less powerful nations were given a say — which was ignored as needed.

The American-led order (more accurately, the "American order" — Pax Americana) was horribly expensive for Latin Americans, Iranians, Vietnamese, Laotians, Cambodians, Palestinians, and many millions of others.

What has Kori Schake so concerned now is that the Trumpian order — the American order taken to its illogical extreme — is that it may prove expensive for the haves.

The rule-based order not only guarantees peace. It also guarantees American prosperity.

It has made the dollar the world's only reserve currency, which is an extraordinary privilege. As a result, most trade surpluses - not just with the US - are invested in US treasury bonds and in the US financial system. This gives American businesses and consumers access to easy credit, and allows the US government to run trillion dollar deficits.

In addition, the rule-based system protects American property rights abroad. China provides a good example of what will happen to America's service industries and its corporate profits, if the Europeans and Japanese no longer play ball on IP and other issues.

Trump is gambling all of this away. He can't turn America's alliances in protection rackets, because neither the EU nor Japan will forgo retaliatory tariffs in exchange for empty US security guarantees. Instead, he'll bring about a multipolar world, in which a wary EU will work with a rising China to deter Russia from further aggression, and limit American influence, first and foremost by setting up a payment system that bypasses the dollar and the American banking system.

I know this is too hard for Trump and his followers to understand, and that it doesn't square with the hubris peddled by the Hoover Institution. But it's the reality of the 21st century, in which the US economy is only as big as that of the Europe, and in which China's economy will be soon.

And with its anti-immigrant, xenophobic nationalism and overt racism it's all too frightening for those old enough to remember the cost the world endured in defeating the forces of fascism. Most infuriating, most of the people now rapidly trying to destroy what took generations to build and maintain won't be around to see the aftermath. But we will, and so will our children.

We need to vote all of these people out in November and start the hard work of repairing the damage.

The North Korea- United States Summit in Singapore was publicity and propaganda for Kim Jong Un and North Korea. It demonstrated to his people and neighboring countries that North Korea is a force to be reckoned with in international politics. He successfully duped Trump and his administration into making concessions to North Korea without producing any concrete evidence of his countries denuclearization. To make matters worse, the U.S. is acting unilaterally, without the support of key actors in the region such as China, who are key in ensuring that North Korea fulfills its side of the deal.
As a result, the governments in countries close to North Korea, like Japan and South Korea, are doubting the U.S.’ efforts to denuclearize North Korea. Trump and his administration are expecting a big win with little compromise. The negotiations will not have a positive result if the U.S. is not willing to compromise. Both sides need to be willing to compromise and sacrifice some of their self- interest for any meaningful deal to be made. Nuclear weapons are North Korea’s only security and provides them leverage in international relations. North Korea needs a lot of assurance before they let it go.
The U.S. and North Korea needs to concede some of their interests in order to get what they want. Neither party will accept the deal unless they feel they are getting the fairest deal possible.That can only be achieved with total compliance and honesty from North Korea and the U.S.

Donald Trump is betting that Kim Jong Un wants to trade his nuclear weapons for economic help and security guarantees. That's a pretty safe bet. Spending a quarter of your GDP on your military when your total GDP is half that of Vermont (America's least productive state) is not a recipe for progress.

What will Kim Jong Un do? Like Donald Trump likes to say, we have to see what happens. We can't force him to do anything. We shouldn't try.

If Kim Jong Un does what we want, we will reward him with economic ties instead of sanctions, and with a peace treaty instead of bluster. If he doesn't, we're back to where we were. His choice.

The idea that Donald Trump gave up a lot for nothing is silly. A meeting in Singapore cost us nothing, really. And the war games that were suspended can be unsuspended in 24 hours.

Credit Donald Trump and Moon Jae-in with a little sense. The two men are smart enough to play the long game. And neither one is a fool, nor is Kim Jong Un.

Bluff and bluster help no one. In the end, I'll bet all parties opt instead for a win-win-win solution. But we'll see what happens.

This just goes to show that the Dealmaker-in-Chief was played for a sucker by a petty tyrant ten times smarter than he is.  Kim is playing to his own captive audience in North Korea, and he succeeded in doing so.  The  occupant of the White House thought he could bribe him into denuclearizing, which shows his ignorance of the realities of world politics.  The danger now is that Bolton's voice will be amplified, and that war could result.

Trump gave away everything he could. He got absolutely nothing in return. In other words, we lost a summit. A new low in USA history.

Trump ignorantly decried the Iran deal as the worst deal ever. Yet here he doesn't even have a deal for North Korea to be breaking. We're the laughingstock of the world.

If the president thinks that North Korea will give up its prized nuclear arsenal out of fear of "fire and fury" from the US he has another thought coming. Even John Bolton doesn't believe Kim's promises and mistrusts the NK regime. The president conceded everything to Kim at their summit just to boast that he achieved something no other US president ever did, with his eyes on a Nobel Prize. Kim outnegotiated the president and picked his pocket while they shook hands on the nuclear "deal".

Trump met with North Korea for a very good reason in his own mind: to further align himself with authoritarian governments.  He admires China, North Korea and Russia, and has been honored to meet with them because he aspires to one day rule over his people as they rule over theirs.  He still has the power of the American nuclear arsenal behind him, with which he can threaten anyone he wants.  He has done so via Twitter before. When Steve Bannon indicated that Trump was going to shake up the world order, he wasn't lying.  Why don't Democrats start believing what this administration is directly telling everyone?
Bolton is on assignment to sustain Trumpian confusion and chaos as Trump surrenders to any paying entity for any policy. He says all sorts of things that have no connection to any other reality.
Reality does not matter.  All that counts is the lie of the day (lie d'jour) and the press coverage it is able to secure.

Nothing new here... another Trump regime over-promise, under delivered... with Fox spin to keep the base happy. All is well in Trumpville.

At this point, you know, the point where we actually get to some details that matter, Trump and his base have long since moved on -- the base awarded, and Trump accepted his Nobel.

As Trump said, 'the North Korea thing is done; Kim is a good guy.'

In truth, Kim knows he off the hook now - he got what he wanted out of Trump, now he'll go back to stringing this along, all the while working with the Chinese to augment his country economically. Trump made all this possible. Form over function.

This is an interesting article; Mr. Bolton has consistently believed the DPRK will not denuclearize. His interview would indicate to me that he suggests this to show that the North will not denuclearize, or it indicates he's smoking something. The article accurately cites Sig Hecker, 5th director of Los Alamos National Laboratory who has been to Yongbyon at least 4 times and met with DPRK's counterparts who head its nuclear program. Sig is quoted in a NYT article as estimated the needed time to denuclearize as 15 years.
There have been several recent media articles showing satellite photos of improvements at the Yongbyon site. I recommend the article and overhead collection in 38 NORTH's "Infrastructure Improvements at North Korea’s Yongbyon Nuclear Research Facility."
The so-called agreement signed by Trump and Kim contains much less than that in 3 earlier agreements: 1992 Joint Declaration of Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, 1994 Agreed Framework, and the 2004 6-Party Talks.
The future of the denuclearization of North Korea is rather uncertain.
doug reilly

Reality lags?  Yes, it sure does.     North Korea is not going to denuclearize. They never said they would.   The U.S. keeps talking about timetables without identifying exactly what the heck we're talking about -- so is it 2 sites, 12 sites, 16 missiles, 65 missiles,  how much nuclear material, how will inspections be conducted, how often will inspections be conducted, who will conduct the inspections, is it all or none or some, etc?  This is just noise.

There is no reason to for anyone believe anything that emanates from the mouth of Vietnam Chickenhawk and disgrace of a human being, John Bolton, except his take on his refusal to fight for his country in a war that he championed so loudly while he was an undergraduate at Yale and afterward("I couldn't see myself dying in a rice paddy in Southeast Asia.") when he found a rare empty slot in the National Guard to avoid being drafted at which time he surely would have been sent to Vietnam. (See his biography.)

I, on the other hand am a Vietnam Navy veteran [Fire Control Technician(Gunnery) 3rd Class] ('65-'69)] and a retired federal prosecuting attorney (1995-2010). I am 10 months older than Bolton and joined the Navy when I was 17.One of my high school classmates, ( I grew up in a small town in northeastern Pennsylvania.), out of class of 190, was killed at age 20 (shot in the head while trying to rescue a wounded comrade) in the village of An Le, Vietnam on November 14, 1967. I will never forget my friend, Robert Douglas.

Thus, I would argue that any veteran who supports (or supported) Trump ("bone spur" draft dodger) also supports the disgraceful and cowardly Bolton. Finally, I would further argue that these "so-called" veterans have forfeited their right to be called a veteran.

This is just more from the Reality TV foreign policy ignoring the actual complex reality of denuclearization that some experts claim could take up to 15 years. So far lots of words "signifying nothing" especially from the silence of North Korea.  Mr. Bolton now joins Larry Kudlow as the latest TV actor posing as policy expert in a supporting role as Professor Pangloss.

Simple as this: lies.
And when it doesn't happen, he will still claim success, and call everything else fake news.
This is the man who brought us Iraq and weapons of mass destruction stories. Even now he does not see this as a disaster. Why would anyone even begin to believe anything he says?

First disarm the US. It's the only country on earth that has ever used nuclear bombs, pretending that it would shorten the war. In fact it was to test a plutonium (Hiroshima) and an uranium (Nagasaki) device. That it killed hundreds of thousand innocent people was only "collateral damage".

Wow -- where were we when Trump's promised and "done" total denuclearization off North Korea agreement happened?  Where's the meat, Folks?  Bolton and Pompeo are going to be hard-pressed to fulfill Trump's extravagant promises with Kim Jong-un at their photo-op Summit last month!

This president is the most easily conned negotiator that ever represented us, not counting Chamberlain.  I won't feel easy until the next administration goes to work and does some sound and intelligent bargaining. As all who encounter the draft dodging resident of the white house, "he's all bluster and double-talk."

After this administration, lying to the American people needs to be held to account. Many other democratic countries already do this quite successfully; dragging transgressors to parliament for a very public ribbing or, if the lies are deemed serious enough, to be thrown out of office.

Once trust is broken in anything, there is no credibility left. This pathological lying needs to be stopped before it gets us into another recession or another war. The nearest truth currently is that if the administration opens its mouth, it is lying. No country can survive on such immoral, criminal lunacy.

No matter how many of our allies Trump trashes en route to his mad rush to cut a 'deal' with North Korea, Kim Jong-un will never, ever give up building more advanced, more far-reaching, and just plain more nuclear weapons of mass destruction. Period. How Trump fails to realize this is anybody's guess.

Maybe Trump actually cannot sit down and read a briefing or background information, or does not have the patience to let someone from NSA or CIA walk him through a 10 page powerpoint, on the topic.

Or maybe Trump just adores other dictators and wants to be their buddy, since like his dad taught him, the only people who get respect in this world are bullies.

I really don't care. Do U?

The midterms are in four months. Maybe that will show how much support republicans have in putting this bloke into office.
Hmmmmm, doesn't this approach seem awfully similar to what was being following by Iran? Oh wait, right, that was negotiated by Obama, my bad.  The hypocrisy lives on and Trump supports eat it all up.
I have a local bridge I could sell to Trump and Bolton.
Trump has spent his entire life doing things hap hazardly and having people clean up his disasters. Look at the photo he's totally bemused and in his own little world.

Only Trump and the idiots he has working for him are stupid enough to think the North Korea has any intention of disarming at all.

Everyone else knows that Kim Jong-Un is just playing Trump for the fool, making unverifiable and empty promises that only Trump believes.

Trump knows that the people who will elect Republicans in the Fall want to believe that he is a great and effective leader and that if he confidently assures them that he is being successful, they will continue to give them their loyalty. He also knows that they will want to believe it so badly that he need not bother whether anything he says is true.

He is pretty confident that the rest of the voters simply will not make the effort to replace enough Republicans to make any difference. He knows that by staying center stage he will control the national dialogue and just keep everyone so distracted they will just never offer any alternatives that attract support to any effective challengers. He’s right. The media needs audiences to prosper and the silly melodrama that he offers sucks up nearly all the time and electronic frequencies available for news and current events.

The North Korea- United States Summit in Singapore was publicity and propaganda for Kim Jong Un and North Korea. It demonstrated to his people and neighboring countries that North Korea is a force to be reckoned with in international politics. He successfully duped Trump and his administration into making concessions to North Korea without producing any concrete evidence of his countries denuclearization. To make matters worse, the U.S. is acting unilaterally, without the support of key actors in the region such as China, who are key in ensuring that North Korea fulfills its side of the deal.
As a result, the governments in countries close to North Korea, like Japan and South Korea, are doubting the U.S.’ efforts to denuclearize North Korea. Trump and his administration are expecting a big win with little compromise. The negotiations will not have a positive result if the U.S. is not willing to compromise. Both sides need to be willing to compromise and sacrifice some of their self- interest for any meaningful deal to be made. Nuclear weapons are North Korea’s only security and provides them leverage in international relations. North Korea needs a lot of assurance before they let it go.
The U.S. and North Korea needs to concede some of their interests in order to get what they want. Neither party will accept the deal unless they feel they are getting the fairest deal possible.That can only be achieved with total compliance and honesty from North Korea and the U.S.

Donald Trump is betting that Kim Jong Un wants to trade his nuclear weapons for economic help and security guarantees. That's a pretty safe bet. Spending a quarter of your GDP on your military when your total GDP is half that of Vermont (America's least productive state) is not a recipe for progress.

What will Kim Jong Un do? Like Donald Trump likes to say, we have to see what happens. We can't force him to do anything. We shouldn't try.

If Kim Jong Un does what we want, we will reward him with economic ties instead of sanctions, and with a peace treaty instead of bluster. If he doesn't, we're back to where we were. His choice.

The idea that Donald Trump gave up a lot for nothing is silly. A meeting in Singapore cost us nothing, really. And the war games that were suspended can be unsuspended in 24 hours.

Credit Donald Trump and Moon Jae-in with a little sense. The two men are smart enough to play the long game. And neither one is a fool, nor is Kim Jong Un.

Bluff and bluster help no one. In the end, I'll bet all parties opt instead for a win-win-win solution. But we'll see what happens.

This just goes to show that the Dealmaker-in-Chief was played for a sucker by a petty tyrant ten times smarter than he is.  Kim is playing to his own captive audience in North Korea, and he succeeded in doing so.  The  occupant of the White House thought he could bribe him into denuclearizing, which shows his ignorance of the realities of world politics.  The danger now is that Bolton's voice will be amplified, and that war could result.

Trump gave away everything he could. He got absolutely nothing in return. In other words, we lost a summit. A new low in USA history.

Trump ignorantly decried the Iran deal as the worst deal ever. Yet here he doesn't even have a deal for North Korea to be breaking. We're the laughingstock of the world.

If the president thinks that North Korea will give up its prized nuclear arsenal out of fear of "fire and fury" from the US he has another thought coming. The president conceded everything to Kim at their summit just to boast that he achieved something no other US president ever did, with his eyes on a Nobel Prize. When you're a republican, you have to support your Republican President. It's pretty simple. He is a doing an amazing job even if you disagree with his personal morals / tactics. He's killing Obamacare. He bloodied Assad twice when Obama refused to lift a finger even after he imposed an unnecessary red line and we saw hundreds of children attacked with nerve agent, foaming at the mouth. He is nominating great judges who will hopefully overturn the racist policy called affirmative action, e.g. Asian kids, on the sole basis of their last names, have a 4.6x less chance of being accepted into top colleges than an otherwise equivalent Black or a Latino kid. He is making more progress on N.Korea in 1.5 years than Obama did in 8 years. He is putting the heat on NATO countries to hit the 2% minimum military spending by criticizing them and hitting them with tariffs - Obama called them "freeloaders" but did nothing. He is overseeing an economy with some of the lowest unemployment numbers in history. He has lowered taxes without a single vote from Dems, who want to increase taxes. He is protecting 2nd amendment rights.

With such an amazing track record, Republican candidates need to look past Trump's unconventional style and poor moral character and support him 110%.

Say what one will about Sanford, but at least he had the courage to stand up against the Trump 'cult'.
I grew up in a Republican family, but any lingering respect I had (little to begin with) for the GOP has been permanently dashed.
They are the lowest-common-denominator party, stocked with charlatans like Corey.

This is good news, the Republicans lost one of the best politicians in the history of the republic. Mark Sanford, could have lost many times given his baggage in the past but somehow could pull the rabbit out of the hat and win. This set's up a win for the democrats in the general, where if Sanford had won, it would have been very unlikely.

Trump is getting too much credit for Sanford's defeat.  South Carolinians elected him after he was revealed to be a conniving two timer philanderer.  South Carolina is a rural, segregated state with low voter turnout.  The non-voters dont know and dont care.  In these red states, people vote party, not person.

I'm not sure Republicans lashed-out so much as waded-in. If you look at the primary results, the vote is split about 50-50. Dimitri Cherny is the unexpected contestant for the Republican nomination. As you might know, Cherny is an outspoken Bernie Sanders supporter. That should raise a few eyebrows about his underlying intentions.

I'm speculating here but I would think Cherny voters would not have supported Arrington regardless. Therefore, Cherny's presence seems more like an intentional spoiler built to advance a Democratic candidate in the fall. If you take Cherny out of the equation, the Republican vote is divided almost equally. Sandford's past antics probably knocked off a few more points too. Although, Trump is one to criticize on infidelity.

Therefore, I wouldn't take this so much as a referendum on Trump as a signal Republicans really are divided. I'm sure red-meat-eating Republicans want a Republican president but I think the verdict on Trump is still undecided. Those popularity ratings might be confusing approval of *a* Republican president with approval for *this* Republican president. Only time will tell.

One of the most important jobs of any President is to display the honesty and personal character that can help to create a sense of unity among ALL the people of this very diverse nation.  Moral character is not just important; it is essential.    Fomenting hatred does not Make American Great Again. Grand stand actions such as the two bombings in Syria or the photo-op summit in Singapore should be discouraged rather than upheld as wonderful accomplishments.

If anyone continues to wonder why the Republicans in Congress are such Trump lapdogs, look no further than Mark Sanford. The South Carolinian has backed the President's agenda upwards of 90% of the time, but he had the temerity to allege that Trump has increased the coarseness of political discourse. Imagine that.
Previous presidents, from Clinton to Bush to Obama, have had strangleholds over their parties at various times. For example, following the 9/11 attacks, President Bush held the nation and the certainly the GOP in the palm of his hand. And yes, I am sure he used that leverage to pass legislation and curry support for his initiatives. Who wouldn't? But the level of retribution and cult-of-personality politics clearly on display in the current GOP is different. Trump has, practically, the entire Republican Party eating out of his hand, and he has not qualm against using that power in very vindictive and uncivil ways.
We are moving toward authoritarianism. Both political movements, liberal and conservative, are trending to their bases, nominating more extreme candidates for office. Political debate has devolved into little more than a lunchroom food fight.
Trump did not cause this, but he has certainly exploited it. We need a leader, and he is a divider.

Trump has eviscerated the Republican party’s conservative rationale and mocked its emphasis on the Constitution.
1. Yes, he is making great progress in killing Obamacare. He has made no progress replacing it with a “better, cheaper” system. The so-called elites will still have good health care but not middle-class part of his base. The latest: the Justice Department is no longer going to defend the requirement to insure those with pre-existing conditions.
2. His attacks on Syria were more theater than any meaningful reduction in Syrian military capability. Assad is still solidly in place.
3. Asian students are doing very well getting degrees from elite colleges. The benefit to our country to increase the number of black and Latino students getting such degrees is obvious.
4. He has brought us back from the brink with North Korea that he brought us to. It is completely unknowable what North Korea will do, as Kim promised much less at this summit than even in the past. But now, thanks to our Great Leader, our allies in the area are weaker and China is stronger, so push back will be much harder. And our NATO allies...
5. He lowered taxes on the very rich who didn’t need it and increased the deficit. His promise—a very good one for the economy- of desperately needed infra-structure projects is fading away.
7. He is protecting made-up second amendment rights and throwing children, the majority of the population (urban), and potential suicides under the bus.

Sure, Trump can damage you if you are a Republican if he wants to; that is what the Republicans in Congress are afraid of. But to them I say, be willing to lose your job if you want to hang on to your reputation and your convictions. Trump will not last and when he is gone what will you be able to say then to defend your current cowardice? If I were a Republican with even a shred of integrity, rather than cower and tremble in Trump's shadow, I would leave Congress (as Corker and other Reps are doing), become an Independent, and run against Trump and his ideologies down the road. Being silent on Trump is the same as being with Trump.

Republican voters in South Carolina gave Mark Sanford a second chance after he was no longer governor. South Caolina elected Nikki Haley who turned out to be a great governor and currently serving the nation very well as the UN ambassador of the US. Sanford is certainly a smart politician but not the best representative of the conservative state with attachment to family values. Wrecking his marriage to his former wife and a good mother who was instrumental in his rise to Governor and then betraying her for a"soulmate" is his personal business but for a person who is seeking public office, character, family values and loyalty matters. Sanford's  flakyness and lack of a significant positive contribution possibly resulted in a primary loss by a wide margin. In the absence of term limits and dissatisfaction with Sanford, I think the South Carolina Republicans have made a good choice in an experienced woman, Kattie Arrington. Sanford can join other challengers to Trump in the Republican primary for 2020 along with Sen. Flake and possibly Sen. Corker.

South Korea has a mlitary-aged population, industrial plant and wealth far exceeding that of North Korea. They also have nuclear reactors and the scientific know-how to more than match North Korea even in nuclear weapon capacity. They might be well advised to do so -- and we might be well advised to help them on the QT, just as China and Russia did North Korea. Then US forces would no longer be needed in South Korea. Of course the same applies to Western Europe versus Russia.

US military base on foreign land--imagine what that took: politicians defending the need--sheepishly, townsmen complaining of losing the land while being employed at the base, the sleazy streets and the inevitable babies without fathers.

But things have changed as host countries become richer. Local economic dependence on the base declines while the exchange rate reduces GI purchasing power and their time and money spent off base. While the number of bases decline, US troops are concentrated into small town USA with wide streets and burger joints--often paid for by host countries. This applies in Korea as well as Germany, Japan or UK.
This is written like an anti-American editorial.  C'mon NYC, you can do better than E. Tammy Kim.

It is a decent article. I believe the size of U.S. military in South Korea will gets smaller gradually. Yet it will take many years to get to zero. The Korean peninsula borders China, Russia, and Japan. Even the former head of North Korea said U.S. military might stay in South Korea for the sake of power balance there.

It is like a checklist of political cal corrrctness based on a cartoon in which the US is the world villian. And for no apparent reason.

“In July 1950, the second month of the Korean War, American soldiers shot and killed an estimated 400 civilians in the southern village of No Gun Ri, a massacre that was not widely covered until 1999. And long after the war’s end, in the gijichon outside every American military base, servicemen abused waitresses and sex workers and left wives and children behind when they rotated out of the country.”

Check. Moral awareness and superiority confirmed. Gosh just what was going on in July 1950? Other than American soldiers shooting and killing civilians? Never mind. Doesn’t matter. The villian is known.

And gosh what was going on during those Korean military dictatorships? Never mind. The US is the villian who massacred civilians. Just because.

Then democracy arrived fitfully??????

Really???

Just arrived did it.

Shameless. Beyond words. Shameless.

In a just world Kim could take a ride back in time to that wonderful winter in Chosin Reservoir and share the good times with a bunch of untrained soldiers thrown into combat without winter gear with one hundred percent casualty rates after the US had demobilized and wasn’t ready for war. Facts and human reality ruin the villian narrative. But who cares? Kim likes cartoons the cartoon villian. Feels good. Omniscient yet ignorant. Cheating is better than opioids.

Trump is an outsider but some of what he says makes a lot of sense.  Blowback: The Costs and Consequences of American Empire by Chalmers Johnson should be required reading for every citizen.  Even though this was written over 10 years ago it is on point.  The national security apparatus seems to be threatened by some of what Trump asks.  Our citizens and congress should be making these decisions.  War is too important to leave to generals.  They always want more.

Lost in the cost of our military on foreign bases is the cost we pay to transport people and items related to the military to these bases.   Twenty-seven thousand civilians?  And if you are an officer, and want your furniture and your car overseas, the US military will ship it there, provided by the tax-paying citizens of the US.  But we need to stay there.  The "Republic of Korea" was our creation, in frightened response to the many "citizens groups" that had sprung up throughout North AND South Korea in the late 40's, hoping to be allowed to chart their own course and reclaim their history.  Unfortunately, they were not allowed to do that--the United States had different plans and they did not include unnecessary interference from the Korean people.  Chances are pretty high that the United States military will still  be in Korea when my 2 year old grandson reaches my age, 63 years from now.  What a sad legacy for the Korean peninsula.

A good article with sufficient facts and figures.

What's missing is a map.

Hard to imagine all these places with proximity to the North with no maps.

Kushner will arrive in Yemen in a few days with a Sheeite plan to divide the country with the Houthies. That is if he can persuade the UN at its emergency meeting to approve the plan. Kushner, as always, is working in secret with Gen Mattis. I wish him good luck.

The rebels needed to remember the adage, If you shoot at the King, be certain to kill the King. They did not, the Saudis formed a coalition to restore the government to power, and the storm broke.
